\chapter{Introduction}
\label{\detokenize{intro/index:introduction}}\label{\detokenize{intro/index::doc}}
LVGL (Light and Versatile Graphic Library) is a free and open-source graphics library providing everything you need to create embedded GUI with easy-to-use graphical elements, beautiful visual effects and low memory footprint.


\section{Key features}
\label{\detokenize{intro/index:key-features}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Powerful building blocks such as buttons, charts, lists, sliders, images etc.

\item {} 
Advanced graphics with animations, anti-aliasing, opacity, smooth scrolling

\item {} 
Various input devices such as touchpad, mouse, keyboard, encoder etc.

\item {} 
Multi-language support with UTF-8 encoding

\item {} 
Multi-display support, i.e. use more TFT, monochrome displays simultaneously

\item {} 
Fully customizable graphic elements

\item {} 
Hardware independent to use with any microcontroller or display

\item {} 
Scalable to operate with little memory (64 kB Flash, 16 kB RAM)

\item {} 
OS, External memory and GPU supported but not required

\item {} 
Single frame buffer operation even with advanced graphical effects

\item {} 
Written in C for maximal compatibility (C++ compatible)

\item {} 
Simulator to start embedded GUI design on a PC without embedded hardware

\item {} 
Binding to MicroPython

\item {} 
Tutorials, examples, themes for rapid GUI design

\item {} 
Documentation is available as online and offline

\item {} 
Free and open-source under MIT license

\end{itemize}


\section{Requirements}
\label{\detokenize{intro/index:requirements}}
Basically, every modern controller  (which is able to drive a display( is suitable to run LVGL. The minimal requirements are:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
16, 32 or 64 bit microcontroller or processor

\item {} 
\textgreater{} 16 MHz clock speed is recommended

\item {} 
Flash/ROM: \textgreater{} 64 kB for the very essential components (\textgreater{} 180 kB is recommended)

\item {} 
RAM:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Static RAM usage: \textasciitilde{}2 kB depending on the used features and objects types

\item {} 
Stack: \textgreater{} 2kB (\textgreater{} 8 kB is recommended)

\item {} 
Dynamic data (heap): \textgreater{} 2 KB (\textgreater{} 16 kB is recommended if using several objects).
Set by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_MEM\_SIZE}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}.

\item {} 
Display buffer:  \textgreater{} \sphinxstyleemphasis{"Horizontal resolution"} pixels (\textgreater{} 10 × \sphinxstyleemphasis{"Horizontal resolution"} is recommended)

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
One frame buffer in the MCU or in external display controller

\item {} 
C99 or newer compiler

\item {} 
Basic C (or C++) knowledge: \sphinxhref{https://www.tutorialspoint.com/cprogramming/c\_pointers.htm}{pointers}, \sphinxhref{https://www.tutorialspoint.com/cprogramming/c\_structures.htm}{structs}, \sphinxhref{https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/callbacks-in-c/}{callbacks}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxstyleemphasis{Note that the memory usage might vary depending on the architecture, compiler and build options.}

\section{Release policy}
\label{\detokenize{intro/index:release-policy}}
LVGL follows the rules of \sphinxhref{https://semver.org/}{Semantic versioning}:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Major versions for incompatible API changes. E.g. v5.0.0, v6.0.0

\item {} 
Minor version for new but backward-compatible functionalities. E.g. v6.1.0, v6.2.0

\item {} 
Patch version for backward-compatible bug fixes. E.g. v6.1.1, v6.1.2

\end{itemize}

Branches:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{master}} most recent version, patches are merged directly here.

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dev}} merge new features here until they are merged into \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{master}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{release/vX}} there is a branch for every major version to allow adding specific, not forward compatible fixes.

\end{itemize}

LVGL has a monthly periodic release cycle.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{1st Tuesday of the month}
   - Make a major, minor, or patch release from \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{master}} depending on the new features.
   - After that merge only patches into \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{master}} and add new features into the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dev}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{3rd Tuesday of the month}
   - Make a patch release from \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{master}}.
   - After that merge the new features from the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dev}} to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{master}} branch.
   - In the rest of the month merge only patches into \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{master}} and new features into \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dev}} branch.

\end{itemize}

\section{FAQ}
\label{\detokenize{intro/index:faq}}

\subsection{Where to get started?}
\label{\detokenize{intro/index:where-to-get-started}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
For a general overview of LVGL visit \sphinxhref{https://lvgl.io}{lvgl.io}

\item {} 
Go to the {\hyperref[\detokenize{get-started/index::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Get started}}}} section to learn the basics of LVGL

\item {} 
A detailed porting guide can be found in the {\hyperref[\detokenize{porting/index::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Porting}}}} section

\item {} 
To learn how LVGL works go to the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/index::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Overview}}}}

\item {} 
To see the source code of the library check it on GitHub: \sphinxurl{https://github.com/lvgl/lvgl/}

\item {} 
To read tutorials or share your own experiences go to the \sphinxhref{https://blog.lvgl.io}{Blog}

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Where can I ask questions?}
\label{\detokenize{intro/index:where-can-i-ask-questions}}
You ask questions in the Forum: \sphinxurl{https://forum.lvgl.io/}.

We use \sphinxhref{https://github.com/lvgl/lvgl/issues}{GitHub issues} for development related discussion.
So you should use them only if your question or issue is tightly related to the development of the library.


\subsection{Is my MCU/hardware supported?}
\label{\detokenize{intro/index:is-my-mcu-hardware-supported}}
Every MCU which is capable of driving a display via Parallel port, SPI, RGB interface or anything else and fulfills the {\hyperref[\detokenize{intro/index:Requirements}]{\emph{Requirements}}} is supported by LLVGL.

It includes:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
"Common" MCUs like STM32F, STM32H, NXP Kinetis, LPC, iMX, dsPIC33, PIC32 etc.

\item {} 
Bluetooth, GSM, WiFi modules like Nordic NRF and Espressif ESP32

\item {} 
Linux frame buffer like /dev/fb0 which includes Single board computers too like Raspberry Pi

\item {} 
And anything else with a strong enough MCU and a periphery to drive a display

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Is my display supported?}
\label{\detokenize{intro/index:is-my-display-supported}}
LVGL needs just one simple driver function to copy an array of pixels into a given area of the display.
If you can do this with your display then you can use that display with LVGL.

Some examples of the supported display types:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
TFTs with 16 or 24 bit color depth

\item {} 
Monitors with HDMI port

\item {} 
Small monochrome displays

\item {} 
Gray-scale displays

\item {} 
even LED matrices

\item {} 
or any other display where you can control the color/state of the pixels

\end{itemize}

See the {\hyperref[\detokenize{porting/display::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Porting}}}} section to learn more.


\subsection{Is LVGL free? How can I use it in a commercial product?}
\label{\detokenize{intro/index:is-lvgl-free-how-can-i-use-it-in-a-commercial-product}}
LVGL comes with \sphinxhref{https://github.com/lvgl/lvgl/blob/master/LICENCE.txt}{MIT license} which means you can download and use it for any purpose you want.

The only thing you need to do is to add a notice about you are using LVGL in you product.
This notice can be placed in the user guide, on you website, on an about screen, or anywhere else where users might see it.


\subsection{Nothing happens, my display driver is not called. What have I missed?}
\label{\detokenize{intro/index:nothing-happens-my-display-driver-is-not-called-what-have-i-missed}}
Be sure you are calling \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_tick\_inc(x)}} in an interrupt and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler()}} in your main \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{while(1)}}.

Learn more in the {\hyperref[\detokenize{porting/tick::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Tick}}}} and {\hyperref[\detokenize{porting/task-handler::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Task handler}}}} section.


\subsection{Why the display driver is called only once? Only the upper part of the display is refreshed.}
\label{\detokenize{intro/index:why-the-display-driver-is-called-only-once-only-the-upper-part-of-the-display-is-refreshed}}
Be sure you are calling \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_flush\_ready(drv)}} at the end of your "\sphinxstyleemphasis{display flush callback}".

\subsection{Why I see non-sense colors on the screen?}
\label{\detokenize{intro/index:why-i-see-non-sense-colors-on-the-screen}}
Probably LVGL's color format is not compatible with your displays color format. Check \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_DEPTH}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}.

If you are using 16 bit colors with SPI (or other byte-oriented interface) probably you need to set \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_16\_SWAP  1}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}.
It swaps the upper and lower bytes of the pixels.


\subsection{How to speed up my UI?}
\label{\detokenize{intro/index:how-to-speed-up-my-ui}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Turn on compiler optimization and enable cache if your MCU has

\item {} 
Increase the size of the display buffer

\item {} 
Use 2 display buffers and flush the buffer with DMA (or similar periphery) in the background

\item {} 
Increase the clock speed of the SPI or Parallel port if you use them to drive the display

\item {} 
If your display has SPI port consider changing to a model with parallel because it has much higher throughput

\item {} 
Keep the display buffer in the internal RAM (not in external SRAM) because LVGL uses it a lot and it should have a small access time

\end{itemize}


\subsection{How to reduce flash/ROM usage?}
\label{\detokenize{intro/index:how-to-reduce-flash-rom-usage}}
You can disable all the unused feature (such as animations, file system, GPU etc.) and object types in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}.

If you are using GCC you can add
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{-fdata-sections -ffunction-sections}} compiler flags

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{-{-}gc-sections}} linker flag

\end{itemize}

to remove unused functions and variables from the final binary


\subsection{How to reduce the RAM usage}
\label{\detokenize{intro/index:how-to-reduce-the-ram-usage}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Lower the size of the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Display buffer}

\item {} 
Reduce \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_MEM\_SIZE}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}. This memory used when you create objects like buttons, labels, etc.

\item {} 
To work with lower \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_MEM\_SIZE}} you can create the objects only when required and deleted them when they are not required anymore

\end{itemize}


\subsection{How to work with an operating system?}
\label{\detokenize{intro/index:how-to-work-with-an-operating-system}}
To work with an operating system where tasks can interrupt each other you should protect LVGL related function calls with a mutex. S
ee the {\hyperref[\detokenize{porting/os::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Operating system and interrupts}}}} section to learn more.


\subsection{How to contribute to LVGL?}
\label{\detokenize{intro/index:how-to-contribute-to-lvgl}}
There are several ways to contribute to LVGL:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Write a few lines about your project to inspire others in the \sphinxhref{https://forum.lvgl.io.com/c/my-projects}{Forum}

\item {} 
Help others questions in the {[}Froum{]}

\item {} 
Report and/or fix bugs

\item {} 
Suggest and/or implement new features

\item {} 
Improve and/or translate the documentation

\item {} 
Write a blog post about your experiences

\end{itemize}

To learn more see \sphinxhref{https://github.com/lvgl/lvgl/blob/master/docs/CONTRIBUTING}{Contributing guide}


\chapter{Get started}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/index:get-started}}\label{\detokenize{get-started/index::doc}}

\section{Quick overview}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/quick-overview:quick-overview}}\label{\detokenize{get-started/quick-overview::doc}}
Here you can learn the most important things about LVGL.
You should read it first to get a general impression and read the detailed {\hyperref[\detokenize{porting/index::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Porting}}}} and {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/index::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Overview}}}} sections after that.


\subsection{Get started in a simulator}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/quick-overview:get-started-in-a-simulator}}
Instead of porting LVGL to an embedded hardware, it's highly recommended to get started in a simulator first.

LVGL is ported to many IDEs to be sure you will find your faviourite one. Go to {\hyperref[\detokenize{get-started/pc-simulator::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Simulators}}}} to get ready-to-use projects which can be run on your PC. This way you can save the porting for now and make some experience with LVGL immediately.


\subsection{Add LVGL into your project}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/quick-overview:add-lvgl-into-your-project}}
The following steps show how to setup LVGL on an embedded system with a display and a touchpad.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxhref{https://github.com/lvgl/lvgl/archive/master.zip}{Download} or Clone the library from GitHub with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{git clone https://github.com/lvgl/lvgl.git}}

\item {} 
Copy the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lvgl}} folder into your project

\item {} 
Copy \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lvgl/lv\_conf\_templ.h}} as \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_conf.h}} next to the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lvgl}} folder, change the first \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\#if 0}} to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{1}} to enable the file's content and set at least \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_HOR\_RES\_MAX}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_VER\_RES\_MAX}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_DEPTH}} defines.

\item {} 
Include \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lvgl/lvgl.h}} where you need to use LVGL related functions.

\item {} 
Call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_tick\_inc(x)}} every \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{x}} milliseconds \sphinxstylestrong{in a Timer or Task} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{x}} should be between 1 and 10). It is required for the internal timing of LVGL.

\item {} 
Call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_init()}}

\item {} 
Create a display buffer for LVGL. LVGL will render the graphics here first, and seed the rendered image to the display. The buffer size can be set freely but 1/10 screen size is a good starting point.

\end{itemize}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{static} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}buf\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{disp\PYGZus{}buf}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{k}{static} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{buf}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}HOR\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}MAX} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}VER\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}MAX} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{;}                     \PYG{c+cm}{/*Declare a buffer for 1/10 screen size*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}buf\PYGZus{}init}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{disp\PYGZus{}buf}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{buf}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}HOR\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}MAX} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}VER\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}MAX} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}    \PYG{c+cm}{/*Initialize the display buffer*/}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Implement and register a function which can \sphinxstylestrong{copy the rendered image} to an area of your display:

\end{itemize}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}init}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{disp\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}          \PYG{c+cm}{/*Basic initialization*/}
\PYG{n}{disp\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{flush\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}flush}\PYG{p}{;}    \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set your driver function*/}
\PYG{n}{disp\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{buffer} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{disp\PYGZus{}buf}\PYG{p}{;}          \PYG{c+cm}{/*Assign the buffer to the display*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}register}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{disp\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}      \PYG{c+cm}{/*Finally register the driver*/}

\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{n+nf}{my\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}flush}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{disp}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{const} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}area\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{area}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{color\PYGZus{}p}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{k+kt}{int32\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{y}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{k}{for}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{y} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{area}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{y1}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{n}{y} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{area}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{y2}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{n}{y}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{k}{for}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{area}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{x1}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{n}{x} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{area}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{x2}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{n}{x}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
            \PYG{n}{set\PYGZus{}pixel}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{y}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{color\PYGZus{}p}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}  \PYG{c+cm}{/* Put a pixel to the display.*/}

    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}flush\PYGZus{}ready}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{disp}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}         \PYG{c+cm}{/* Indicate you are ready with the flushing*/}

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{;}                  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Descriptor of a input device driver*/}

\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{read\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}touchpad\PYGZus{}read}\PYG{p}{;}      \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set your driver function*/}

\PYG{k+kt}{bool} \PYG{n+nf}{my\PYGZus{}touchpad\PYGZus{}read}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{indev}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}data\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{state} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{touchpad\PYGZus{}is\PYGZus{}pressed}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{?} \PYG{n+nl}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}PR} \PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}REL}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{state} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}PR}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n}{touchpad\PYGZus{}get\PYGZus{}xy}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{point}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{point}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{y}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

    \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nb}{false}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{c+cm}{/*Return {}`false{}` because we are not buffering and no more data to read*/}

\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler()}} periodically every few milliseconds in the main \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{while(1)}} loop, in Timer interrupt or in an Operation system task.
It will redraw the screen if required, handle input devices etc.

\end{itemize}

For a more detailed guide go to the \sphinxhref{https://docs.lvgl.io/v7/en/html/porting/index.html}{Porting} section.


\subsection{Learn the basics}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/quick-overview:learn-the-basics}}

\subsubsection{Widgets}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/quick-overview:widgets}}
The graphical elements like Buttons, Labels, Sliders, Charts etc are called objects or widgets in LVGL. Go to {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/index::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Widgets}}}} to see the full list of available widgets.

Every object has a parent object where it is create. For example if a label is created on a button, the button is the parent of label.
The child object moves with the parent and if the parent is deleted the children will be deleted too.

Children can be visible only on their parent. It other words, the parts of the children out of the parent are clipped.

A \sphinxstyleemphasis{screen} is the "root" parent. You can have any number of screens. To get the current screen call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_scr\_act()}}, and to load a screen use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_scr\_load(scr1)}}.

You can create a new object with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_\textless{}type\textgreater{}\_create(parent, obj\_to\_copy)}}. It will return an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_t *}} variable which should be used as a reference to the object to set its parameters.
The first parameter is the desired \sphinxstyleemphasis{parent}, the second parameters can be an object to copy (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} if unused).
For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{slider1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}slider\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}scr\PYGZus{}act}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

To set some basic attribute \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_\textless{}paramters\_name\textgreater{}(obj, \textless{}value\textgreater{})}} function can be used. For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}x}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{btn1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{30}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}y}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{btn1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}size}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{btn1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{200}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{50}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

The objects has type specific parameters too which can be set by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_\textless{}type\textgreater{}\_set\_\textless{}paramters\_name\textgreater{}(obj, \textless{}value\textgreater{})}} functions. For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}slider\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}value}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{slider1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{70}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}ANIM\PYGZus{}ON}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

To see the full API visit the documentation of the widgets or the related header file (e.g. \sphinxhref{https://github.com/lvgl/lvgl/blob/master/src/lv\_widgets/lv\_slider.h}{lvgl/src/lv\_widgets/lv\_slider.h}).


\subsubsection{Events}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/quick-overview:events}}
Events are used to inform the user if something has happened with an object. You can assign a callback to an object which will be called if the object is clicked, released, dragged, being deleted etc. It should look like this:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}event\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{btn}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{btn\PYGZus{}event\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}                 \PYG{c+cm}{/*Assign a callback to the button*/}

\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}

\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{n}{btn\PYGZus{}event\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{btn}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}event\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{event}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{event} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}EVENT\PYGZus{}CLICKED}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{n}{printf}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Clicked}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Learn more about the events in the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Event overview}}}} section.


\subsubsection{Parts}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/quick-overview:parts}}
Widgets might be built from one or more parts. For example a button has only one part called \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BTN\_PART\_MAIN}}.
However, a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/page::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Page}}}} has \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_PAGE\_PART\_BG}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_PAGE\_PART\_SCROLLABLE}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_PAGE\_PART\_SCROLLBAR}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_PAGE\_PART\_EDGE\_FLASG}}.

Some parts are \sphinxstyleemphasis{virtual} (they are not real object, just drawn on the fly, such as the scrollbar of a page) but other parts are \sphinxstyleemphasis{real} (they are real object, such as the scrollable part of the page).

Parts come into play when you want to set the styles and states of a given part of an object. (See below)


\subsubsection{States}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/quick-overview:states}}
The objects can be in a combination of the following states:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_DEFAULT} Normal, released

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_CHECKED} Toggled or checked

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_FOCUSED} Focused via keypad or encoder or clicked via touchpad/mouse

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_EDITED} Edit by an encoder

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_HOVERED} Hovered by mouse (not supported now)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_PRESSED} Pressed

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_DISABLED} Disabled or inactive

\end{itemize}

For example if you press an object is automatically get the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_STATE\_PRESSED}} state and when you release is it will be removed.

To get the current state use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_get\_state(obj, part)}}. It will return the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{OR}}ed states.
For example it's a valid state for a checkbox: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_STATE\_CHECKED \textbar{} LV\_STATE\_PRESSED \textbar{} LV\_STATE\_FOCUSED}}


\subsubsection{Styles}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/quick-overview:styles}}
Styles can be assigned to the parts objects to changed their appearance.
A style can describe for example the background color, border width, text font and so on. See the full list \sphinxhref{https://docs.lvgl.io/v7/en/html/overview/style.html\#properties}{here}.

The styles can be cascaded (similarly to CSS). It means you can add more styles to a part of an object.
For example \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style\_btn}} can set a default button appearance, and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style\_btn\_red}} can overwrite some properties to make the button red-

Every style property you set is specific to a state. For example is you can set different background color for \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_STATE\_DEFAULT}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_STATE\_PRESSED}}.
The library finds the best match between the state of the given part and the available style properties. For example if the object is in pressed state and the border width is specified for pressed state, then it will be used.
However, if it's nt specified for pressed state, the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_STATE\_DEFAULT}}'s border width will be used. If the border width not defined for \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_STATE\_DEFAULT}} either, a default value will be used.

Some properties (typically the text-related ones) can be inherited. It means if a property is not set in an object it will be searched in its parents too.
For example you can set the font once in the screen's style and every text will inherit it by default.

Local style properties also can be added to the objects.


\subsubsection{Themes}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/quick-overview:themes}}
Themes are the default styles of the objects.
The styles from the themes are applied automatically when the objects are created.

You can select the theme to use in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_conf.h}}.


\subsection{Examples}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/quick-overview:examples}}

\subsubsection{Button with label}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/quick-overview:button-with-label}}
\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{lv_ex_get_started_1}.png}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{event} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}EVENT\PYGZus{}CLICKED}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{k}{static} \PYG{k+kt}{uint8\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{cnt} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{;}

    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{c+cm}{/**}

\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{n+nf}{lv\PYGZus{}ex\PYGZus{}get\PYGZus{}started\PYGZus{}1}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{k+kt}{void}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}size}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{btn}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{120}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{50}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}                          \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set its size*/}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}event\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{btn}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{btn\PYGZus{}event\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}                 \PYG{c+cm}{/*Assign a callback to the button*/}

    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{label} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}label\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{btn}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}          \PYG{c+cm}{/*Add a label to the button*/}

\PYG{n}{label} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{label}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{btn}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{label}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{set\PYGZus{}text}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Button}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Load the screen}
\PYG{n}{lv}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{scr\PYGZus{}load}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{scr}\PYG{p}{)}

\section{Simulator on PC}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/pc-simulator:simulator-on-pc}}\label{\detokenize{get-started/pc-simulator::doc}}
You can try out the LVGL \sphinxstylestrong{using only your PC} (i.e. without any development boards). The LVGL will run on a simulator environment on the PC where anyone can write and experiment the real LVGL applications.

Simulator on the PC have the following advantages:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Hardware independent - Write a code, run it on the PC and see the result on the PC monitor.

\item {} 
Cross-platform - Any Windows, Linux or OSX PC can run the PC simulator.

\item {} 
Portability - the written code is portable, which means you can simply copy it when using an embedded hardware.

\item {} 
Easy Validation - The simulator is also very useful to report bugs because it means common platform for every user. So it's a good idea to reproduce a bug in simulator and use the code snippet in the \sphinxhref{https://forum.lvgl.io}{Forum}.

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Select an IDE}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/pc-simulator:select-an-ide}}
The simulator is ported to various IDEs (Integrated Development Environments). Choose your favorite IDE, read its README on GitHub, download the project, and load it to the IDE.



You can use any IDEs for the development but, for simplicity, the configuration for Eclipse CDT is focused in this tutorial.
The following section describes the set-up guide of Eclipse CDT in more details.

\sphinxstylestrong{Note: If you are on Windows, it's usually better to use the Visual Studio or CodeBlocks projects instead. They work out of the box without requiring extra steps.}


\subsection{Set-up Eclipse CDT}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/pc-simulator:set-up-eclipse-cdt}}

\subsubsection{Install Eclipse CDT}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/pc-simulator:install-eclipse-cdt}}
\sphinxhref{https://eclipse.org/cdt/}{Eclipse CDT} is a C/C++ IDE.

Eclipse is a Java based software therefore be sure \sphinxstylestrong{Java Runtime Environment} is installed on your system.

On Debian-based distros (e.g. Ubuntu): \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sudo apt-get install default-jre}}

Note: If you are using other distros, then please refer and install 'Java Runtime Environment' suitable to your distro.
Note: If you are using macOS and get a "Failed to create the Java Virtual Machine" error, uninstall any other Java JDK installs and install Java JDK 8u. This should fix the problem.

You can download Eclipse's CDT from: \sphinxurl{https://www.eclipse.org/cdt/downloads.php}. Start the installer and choose \sphinxstyleemphasis{Eclipse CDT} from the list.


\subsubsection{Install SDL 2}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/pc-simulator:install-sdl-2}}
The PC simulator uses the \sphinxhref{https://www.libsdl.org/download-2.0.php}{SDL 2} cross platform library to simulate a TFT display and a touch pad.


\paragraph{Linux}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/pc-simulator:linux}}
On \sphinxstylestrong{Linux} you can easily install SDL2 using a terminal:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
Find the current version of SDL2: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{apt-cache search libsdl2 (e.g. libsdl2-2.0-0)}}

\item {} 
Install SDL2: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sudo apt-get install libsdl2-2.0-0}} (replace with the found version)

\item {} 
Install SDL2 development package: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sudo apt-get install libsdl2-dev}}

\item {} 
If build essentials are not installed yet: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sudo apt-get install build-essential}}

\end{enumerate}


\paragraph{Windows}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/pc-simulator:windows}}
If you are using \sphinxstylestrong{Windows} firstly you need to install MinGW (\sphinxhref{http://mingw-w64.org/doku.php/download}{64 bit version}). After installing MinGW, do the following steps to add SDL2:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
Download the development libraries of SDL.Go to \sphinxurl{https://www.libsdl.org/download-2.0.php} and download \sphinxstyleemphasis{Development Libraries: SDL2-devel-2.0.5-mingw.tar.gz}

\item {} 
Decompress the file and go to \sphinxstyleemphasis{x86\_64-w64-mingw32} directory (for 64 bit MinGW) or to \sphinxstyleemphasis{i686-w64-mingw32} (for 32 bit MinGW)

\item {} 
Copy \_...\sphinxstyleemphasis{mingw32/include/SDL2} folder to \sphinxstyleemphasis{C:/MinGW/.../x86\_64-w64-mingw32/include}

\item {} 
Copy \_...\sphinxstyleemphasis{mingw32/lib/} content to \sphinxstyleemphasis{C:/MinGW/.../x86\_64-w64-mingw32/lib}

\item {} 
Copy \_...\sphinxstyleemphasis{mingw32/bin/SDL2.dll} to \sphinxstyleemphasis{\{eclipse\_worksapce\}/pc\_simulator/Debug/}.  Do it later when Eclipse is installed.

\end{enumerate}

Note: If you are using \sphinxstylestrong{Microsoft Visual Studio} instead of Eclipse then you don't have to install MinGW.


\paragraph{OSX}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/pc-simulator:osx}}
On \sphinxstylestrong{OSX} you can easily install SDL2 with brew: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{brew install sdl2}}

If something is not working, then please refer \sphinxhref{http://lazyfoo.net/tutorials/SDL/01\_hello\_SDL/index.php}{this tutorial} to get started with SDL.


\subsubsection{Pre-configured project}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/pc-simulator:pre-configured-project}}
A pre-configured graphics library project (based on the latest release) is always available to get started easily.
You can find the latest one on \sphinxhref{https://github.com/lvgl/lv\_sim\_eclipse\_sdl}{GitHub}.
(Please note that, the project is configured for Eclipse CDT).


\subsubsection{Add the pre-configured project to Eclipse CDT}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/pc-simulator:add-the-pre-configured-project-to-eclipse-cdt}}
Run Eclipse CDT. It will show a dialogue about the \sphinxstylestrong{workspace path}. Before accepting the path, check that path and copy (and unzip) the downloaded pre-configured project there. After that, you can accept the workspace path. Of course you can modify this path but, in that case copy the project to the corresponding location.

Close the start up window and go to \sphinxstylestrong{File-\textgreater{}Import} and choose \sphinxstylestrong{General-\textgreater{}Existing project into Workspace}. \sphinxstylestrong{Browse the root directory} of the project and click \sphinxstylestrong{Finish}

On \sphinxstylestrong{Windows} you have to do two additional things:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Copy the \sphinxstylestrong{SDL2.dll} into the project's Debug folder

\item {} 
Right click on the project -\textgreater{} Project properties -\textgreater{} C/C++ Build -\textgreater{} Settings -\textgreater{} Libraries -\textgreater{} Add ... and add \sphinxstyleemphasis{mingw32} above SDLmain and SDL. (The order is important: mingw32, SDLmain, SDL)

\end{itemize}


\subsubsection{Compile and Run}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/pc-simulator:compile-and-run}}
Now you are ready to run the LVGL Graphics Library on your PC. Click on the Hammer Icon on the top menu bar to Build the project. If you have done everything right, then you will not get any errors. Note that on some systems additional steps might be required to "see" SDL 2 from Eclipse but, in most of cases the configurations in the downloaded project is enough.

After a success build, click on the Play button on the top menu bar to run the project. Now a window should appear in the middle of your screen.

Now everything is ready to use the LVGL in the practice or begin the development on your PC.

\section{Micropython}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/micropython:micropython}}\label{\detokenize{get-started/micropython::doc}}

\subsection{What is Micropython?}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/micropython:what-is-micropython}}
\sphinxhref{http://micropython.org/}{Micropython} is Python for microcontrollers.Using Micropython, you can write Python3 code and run it even on a bare metal architecture with limited resources.


\subsubsection{Highlights of Micropython}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/micropython:highlights-of-micropython}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Compact} - Fits and runs within just 256k of code space and 16k of RAM. No OS is needed, although you can also run it with an OS, if you want.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Compatible} - Strives to be as compatible as possible with normal Python (known as CPython).

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Versatile} - Supports many architectures (x86, x86-64, ARM, ARM Thumb, Xtensa).

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Interactive} - No need for the compile-flash-boot cycle. With the REPL (interactive prompt) you can type commands and execute them immediately, run scripts etc.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Popular} - Many platforms are supported. The user base is growing bigger. Notable forks: \sphinxhref{https://github.com/micropython/micropython}{MicroPython}, \sphinxhref{https://github.com/adafruit/circuitpython}{CircuitPython}, \sphinxhref{https://github.com/loboris/MicroPython\_ESP32\_psRAM\_LoBo}{MicroPython\_ESP32\_psRAM\_LoBo}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Embedded Oriented} - Comes with modules specifically for embedded systems, such as the \sphinxhref{https://docs.micropython.org/en/latest/library/machine.html\#classes}{machine module} for accessing low-level hardware (I/O pins, ADC, UART, SPI, I2C, RTC, Timers etc.)

\end{itemize}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\subsection{Why Micropython + LVGL?}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/micropython:why-micropython-lvgl}}
Currently, Micropython \sphinxhref{https://forum.micropython.org/viewtopic.php?f=18\&t=5543}{does not have a good high-level GUI library} by default. LVGL is an \sphinxhref{https://blog.lvgl.io/2018-12-13/extend-lvgl-objects}{Object Oriented Component Based} high-level GUI library, which seems to be a natural candidate to map into a higher level language, such as Python. LVGL is implemented in C and its APIs are in C.


\subsubsection{Here are some advantages of using LVGL in Micropython:}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/micropython:here-are-some-advantages-of-using-lvgl-in-micropython}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Develop GUI in Python, a very popular high level language. Use paradigms such as Object Oriented Programming.

\item {} 
Usually, GUI development requires multiple iterations to get things right. With C, each iteration consists of \sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Change code}} \textgreater{} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Build}} \textgreater{} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Flash}} \textgreater{} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Run}}}.In Micropython it's just \sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Change code}} \textgreater{} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Run}}} ! You can even run commands interactively using the \sphinxhref{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Read\%E2\%80\%93eval\%E2\%80\%93print\_loop}{REPL} (the interactive prompt)

\end{itemize}


\subsubsection{Micropython + LVGL could be used for:}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/micropython:micropython-lvgl-could-be-used-for}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Fast prototyping GUI.

\item {} 
Shorten the cycle of changing and fine-tuning the GUI.

\item {} 
Model the GUI in a more abstract way by defining reusable composite objects, taking advantage of Python's language features such as Inheritance, Closures, List Comprehension, Generators, Exception Handling, Arbitrary Precision Integers and others.

\item {} 
Make LVGL accessible to a larger audience. No need to know C in order to create a nice GUI on an embedded system.This goes well with \sphinxhref{https://learn.adafruit.com/welcome-to-circuitpython/what-is-circuitpython}{CircuitPython vision}. CircuitPython was designed with education in mind, to make it easier for new or unexperienced users to get started with embedded development.

\item {} 
Creating tools to work with LVGL at a higher level (e.g. drag-and-drop designer).

\end{itemize}


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip



\subsection{So what does it look like?}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/micropython:so-what-does-it-look-like}}\begin{quote}

TL;DR:
It's very much like the C API, but Object Oriented for LVGL components.
\end{quote}

Let's dive right into an example!


\subsubsection{A simple example}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/micropython:a-simple-example}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{lvgl} \PYG{k+kn}{as} \PYG{n+nn}{lv}
\PYG{n}{lv}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{init}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{scr} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{obj}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{btn} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{btn}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{scr}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{btn}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{align}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{scr\PYGZus{}act}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{ALIGN}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{CENTER}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{label} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{label}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{btn}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{label}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{set\PYGZus{}text}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Button}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{lv}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{scr\PYGZus{}load}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{scr}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{How can I use it?}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/micropython:how-can-i-use-it}}

\subsubsection{Online Simulator}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/micropython:online-simulator}}
If you want to experiment with LVGL + Micropython without downloading anything - you can use our online simulator!It's a fully functional LVGL + Micropython that runs entirely in the browser and allows you to edit a python script and run it.

\sphinxhref{https://sim.lvgl.io/v6/micropython/ports/javascript/bundle\_out/index.html}{Click here to experiment on the online simulator}

\sphinxhref{https://sim.lvgl.io/v6/micropython/ports/javascript/bundle\_out/index.html?script=https://gist.githubusercontent.com/amirgon/51299ce9b6448328a855826149482ae6/raw/0f235c6d40462fd2f0e55364b874f14fe3fd613c/lvgl\_hello\_world.py\&script\_startup=https://gist.githubusercontent.com/amirgon/7bf15a66ba6d959bbf90d10f3da571be/raw/8684b5fa55318c184b1310663b187aaab5c65be6/init\_lv\_mp\_js.py}{Hello World}

Note: examples don't work with v7 yet, so v6 is used.


\subsubsection{PC Simulator}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/micropython:pc-simulator}}
Micropython is ported to many platforms. One notable port is "unix", which allows you to build and run Micropython (+LVGL) on a Linux machine. (On a Windows machine you might need Virtual Box or WSL or MinGW or Cygwin etc.)

\sphinxhref{https://github.com/lvgl/lv\_micropython}{Click here to know more information about building and running the unix port}


\subsubsection{Embedded platform}
\label{\detokenize{get-started/micropython:embedded-platform}}
At the end, the goal is to run it all on an embedded platform.Both Micropython and LVGL can be used on many embedded architectures, such as stm32, ESP32 etc.You would also need display and input drivers. We have some sample drivers (ESP32+ILI9341, as well as some other examples), but most chances are you would want to create your own input/display drivers for your specific purposes.Drivers can be implemented either in C as Micropython module, or in pure Micropython!

\chapter{Porting}
\label{\detokenize{porting/index:porting}}\label{\detokenize{porting/index::doc}}

\section{System overview}
\label{\detokenize{porting/sys:system-overview}}\label{\detokenize{porting/sys::doc}}
\sphinxincludegraphics{{sys}.png}

\sphinxstylestrong{Application}
Your application which creates the GUI and handles the specific tasks.

\sphinxstylestrong{LVGL}
The graphics library itself. Your application can communicate with the library to create a GUI. It contains a HAL (Hardware Abstraction Layer) interface to register your display and input device drivers.

\sphinxstylestrong{Driver}
Besides your specific drivers, it contains functions to drive your display, optionally to a GPU and to read the touchpad or buttons.


\bigskip\hrule\bigskip


Depending on the MCU, there are two typical hardware set-ups. One with built-in LCD/TFT driver periphery and another without it. In both cases, a frame buffer will be required to store the current image of the screen.
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{MCU with TFT/LCD driver}
If your MCU has a TFT/LCD driver periphery then you can connect a display directly via RGB interface.
In this case, the frame buffer can be in the internal RAM (if the MCU has enough RAM) or in the external RAM (if the MCU has a memory interface).

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{External display controller}
If the MCU doesn't have TFT/LCD driver interface then an external display controller (E.g. SSD1963, SSD1306, ILI9341) has to be used.
In this case, the MCU can communicate with the display controller via Parallel port, SPI or sometimes I2C.
The frame buffer is usually located in the display controller which saves a lot of RAM for the MCU.

\end{enumerate}


\section{Set-up a project}
\label{\detokenize{porting/project:set-up-a-project}}\label{\detokenize{porting/project::doc}}

\subsection{Get the library}
\label{\detokenize{porting/project:get-the-library}}
LVGL Graphics Library is available on GitHub: \sphinxurl{https://github.com/lvgl/lvgl}.

You can clone it or download the latest version of the library from GitHub.

The graphics library is the \sphinxstylestrong{lvgl} directory which should be copied into your project.


\subsection{Configuration file}
\label{\detokenize{porting/project:configuration-file}}
There is a configuration header file for LVGL called \sphinxstylestrong{lv\_conf.h}. It sets the library's basic behaviour, disables unused modules and features, adjusts the size of memory buffers in compile-time, etc.

Copy \sphinxstylestrong{lvgl/lv\_conf\_template.h} next to the \sphinxstyleemphasis{lvgl} directory and rename it to \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}. Open the file and change the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\#if 0}} at the beginning to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\#if 1}} to enable its content.

\sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h} can be copied other places as well but then you should add \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_CONF\_INCLUDE\_SIMPLE}} define to your compiler options (e.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{-DLV\_CONF\_INCLUDE\_SIMPLE}} for gcc compiler) and set the include path manually.

In the config file comments explain the meaning of the options. Check at least these three configuration options and modify them according to your hardware:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_HOR\_RES\_MAX} Your display's horizontal resolution.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_VER\_RES\_MAX} Your display's vertical resolution.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_COLOR\_DEPTH} 8 for (RG332), 16 for (RGB565) or 32 for (RGB888 and ARGB8888).

\end{enumerate}


\subsection{Initialization}
\label{\detokenize{porting/project:initialization}}
To use the graphics library you have to initialize it and the other components too. The order of the initialization is:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
Call \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_init()}.

\item {} 
Initialize your drivers.

\item {} 
Register the display and input devices drivers in LVGL.  More about {\hyperref[\detokenize{porting/display::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Display}}}} and {\hyperref[\detokenize{porting/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Input device}}}} registration.

\item {} 
Call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_tick\_inc(x)}} in every \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{x}} milliseconds in an interrupt to tell the elapsed time. {\hyperref[\detokenize{porting/tick::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Learn more}}}}.

\item {} 
Call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler()}} periodically in every few milliseconds to handle LVGL related tasks. {\hyperref[\detokenize{porting/task-handler::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Learn more}}}}.

\end{enumerate}


\section{Display interface}
\label{\detokenize{porting/display:display-interface}}\label{\detokenize{porting/display::doc}}
To set up a display an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_buf\_t}} and an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_drv\_t}} variable has to be initialized.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_disp\_buf\_t} contains internal graphics buffer(s).

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_disp\_drv\_t} contains callback functions to interact with the display and manipulate drawing related things.

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Display buffer}
\label{\detokenize{porting/display:display-buffer}}
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_buf\_t}} can be initialized like this:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
    \PYG{c+cm}{/*A static or global variable to store the buffers*/}
    \PYG{k}{static} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}buf\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{disp\PYGZus{}buf}\PYG{p}{;}

    \PYG{c+cm}{/*Static or global buffer(s). The second buffer is optional*/}
    \PYG{k}{static} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{buf\PYGZus{}1}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{MY\PYGZus{}DISP\PYGZus{}HOR\PYGZus{}RES} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{k}{static} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{buf\PYGZus{}2}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{MY\PYGZus{}DISP\PYGZus{}HOR\PYGZus{}RES} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{;}

    \PYG{c+cm}{/*Initialize {}`disp\PYGZus{}buf{}` with the buffer(s) */}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}buf\PYGZus{}init}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{disp\PYGZus{}buf}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{buf\PYGZus{}1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{buf\PYGZus{}2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{MY\PYGZus{}DISP\PYGZus{}HOR\PYGZus{}RES}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

There are 3 possible configurations regarding the buffer size:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{One buffer} LVGL draws the content of the screen into a buffer and sends it to the display.
The buffer can be smaller than the screen. In this case, the larger areas will be redrawn in multiple parts.
If only small areas changes (e.g. button press) then only those areas will be refreshed.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Two non-screen-sized buffers} having two buffers LVGL can draw into one buffer while the content of the other buffer is sent to display in the background.
DMA or other hardware should be used to transfer the data to the display to let the CPU draw meanwhile.
This way the rendering and refreshing of the display become parallel.
Similarly to the \sphinxstyleemphasis{One buffer}, LVGL will draw the display's content in chunks if the buffer is smaller than the area to refresh.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Two screen-sized buffers}.
In contrast to \sphinxstyleemphasis{Two non-screen-sized buffers} LVGL will always provide the whole screen's content not only chunks.
This way the driver can simply change the address of the frame buffer to the buffer received from LVGL.
Therefore this method works the best when the MCU has an LCD/TFT interface and the frame buffer is just a location in the RAM.

\end{enumerate}


\subsection{Display driver}
\label{\detokenize{porting/display:display-driver}}
Once the buffer initialization is ready the display drivers need to be initialized. In the most simple case only the following two fields of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_drv\_t}} needs to be set:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{buffer} pointer to an initialized \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_buf\_t}} variable.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{flush\_cb} a callback function to copy a buffer's content to a specific area of the display.

\end{itemize}

There are some optional data fields:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{hor\_res} horizontal resolution of the display. (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_HOR\_RES\_MAX}} by default from \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}).

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{ver\_res} vertical resolution of the display. (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_VER\_RES\_MAX}} by default from \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}).

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{color\_chroma\_key} a color which will be drawn as transparent on chrome keyed images. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_TRANSP}} by default from \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}).

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{user\_data} custom user data for the driver. Its type can be modified in lv\_conf.h.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{anti-aliasing} use anti-aliasing (edge smoothing). \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_ANTIALIAS}} by default  from \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{rotated} if \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{1}} swap \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{hor\_res}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ver\_res}}. LVGL draws in the same direction in both cases (in lines from top to bottom) so the driver also needs to be reconfigured to change the display's fill direction.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{screen\_transp} if \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{1}} the screen can have transparent or opaque style. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_SCREEN\_TRANSP}} needs to enabled in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}.

\end{itemize}

To use a GPU the following callbacks can be used:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{gpu\_fill\_cb} fill an area in memory with colors.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{gpu\_blend\_cb} blend two memory buffers using opacity.

\end{itemize}

Note that, these functions need to draw to the memory (RAM) and not your display directly.

Some other optional callbacks to make easier and more optimal to work with monochrome, grayscale or other non-standard RGB displays:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{rounder\_cb} round the coordinates of areas to redraw. E.g. a 2x2 px can be converted to 2x8.
It can be used if the display controller can refresh only areas with specific height or width (usually 8 px height with monochrome displays).

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{set\_px\_cb} a custom function to write the \sphinxstyleemphasis{display buffer}.
It can be used to store the pixels more compactly if the display has a special color format. (e.g. 1-bit monochrome, 2-bit grayscale etc.)
This way the buffers used in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_buf\_t}} can be smaller to hold only the required number of bits for the given area size. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{set\_px\_cb}} is not working with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Two screen-sized buffers}} display buffer configuration.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{monitor\_cb} a callback function tells how many pixels were refreshed in how much time.

\end{itemize}

To set the fields of \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_disp\_drv\_t} variable it needs to be initialized with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_drv\_init(\&disp\_drv)}}.
And finally to register a display for LVGL \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_drv\_register(\&disp\_drv)}} needs to be called.

All together it looks like this:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{disp\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{;}                 \PYG{c+cm}{/*A variable to hold the drivers. Can be local variable*/}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}init}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{disp\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}            \PYG{c+cm}{/*Basic initialization*/}
    \PYG{n}{disp\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{buffer} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{disp\PYGZus{}buf}\PYG{p}{;}            \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set an initialized buffer*/}
    \PYG{n}{disp\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{flush\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}flush\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}        \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set a flush callback to draw to the display*/}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{disp}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{disp} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}register}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{disp\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{c+cm}{/*Register the driver and save the created display objects*/}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\section{Input device interface}
\label{\detokenize{porting/indev:input-device-interface}}\label{\detokenize{porting/indev::doc}}

\subsection{Types of input devices}
\label{\detokenize{porting/indev:types-of-input-devices}}
To set up an input device an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_indev\_drv\_t}} variable has to be initialized:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}init}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}      \PYG{c+cm}{/*Basic initialization*/}
\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{type} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}                 \PYG{c+cm}{/*See below.*/}
\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{read\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}              \PYG{c+cm}{/*See below.*/}
\PYG{c+cm}{/*Register the driver in LVGL and save the created input device object*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}indev} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}register}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxstylestrong{type} can be
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_INDEV\_TYPE\_POINTER} touchpad or mouse

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_INDEV\_TYPE\_KEYPAD} keyboard or keypad

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_INDEV\_TYPE\_ENCODER} encoder with left, right, push options

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_INDEV\_TYPE\_BUTTON} external buttons pressing the screen

\end{itemize}

\sphinxstylestrong{read\_cb} is a function pointer which will be called periodically to report the current state of an input device.
It can also buffer data and return \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{false}} when no more data to be read or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{true}} when the buffer is not empty.

Visit {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Input devices}}}} to learn more about input devices in general.


\subsubsection{Touchpad, mouse or any pointer}
\label{\detokenize{porting/indev:touchpad-mouse-or-any-pointer}}
Input devices which can click points of the screen belong to this category.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{type} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}TYPE\PYGZus{}POINTER}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{read\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}input\PYGZus{}read}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}

\PYG{k+kt}{bool} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}input\PYGZus{}read}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}data\PYGZus{}t}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{data}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{point}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{x} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{touchpad\PYGZus{}x}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{point}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{y} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{touchpad\PYGZus{}y}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{state} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}PR} \PYG{n}{or} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}REL}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nb}{false}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{c+cm}{/*No buffering now so no more data read*/}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{important}{Important:}
Touchpad drivers must return the last X/Y coordinates even when the state is \sphinxstyleemphasis{LV\_INDEV\_STATE\_REL}.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

To set a mouse cursor use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_indev\_set\_cursor(my\_indev, \&img\_cursor)}}. (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{my\_indev}} is the return value of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_indev\_drv\_register}})


\subsubsection{Keypad or keyboard}
\label{\detokenize{porting/indev:keypad-or-keyboard}}
Full keyboards with all the letters or simple keypads with a few navigation buttons belong here.

To use a keyboard/keypad:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Register a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{read\_cb}} function with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_INDEV\_TYPE\_KEYPAD}} type.

\item {} 
Enable \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_USE\_GROUP}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}

\item {} 
An object group has to be created: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_group\_t * g = lv\_group\_create()}}  and objects have to be added to it with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_group\_add\_obj(g, obj)}}

\item {} 
The created group has to be assigned to an input device: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_indev\_set\_group(my\_indev, g)}} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{my\_indev}} is the return value of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_indev\_drv\_register}})

\item {} 
Use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_KEY\_...}} to navigate among the objects in the group. See \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_core/lv\_group.h}} for the available keys.

\end{itemize}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{type} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}TYPE\PYGZus{}KEYPAD}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{read\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{keyboard\PYGZus{}read}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}

\PYG{k+kt}{bool} \PYG{n}{keyboard\PYGZus{}read}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}data\PYGZus{}t}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{data}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{key} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{last\PYGZus{}key}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}            \PYG{c+cm}{/*Get the last pressed or released key*/}

  \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{key\PYGZus{}pressed}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{state} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}PR}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{k}{else} \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{state} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}REL}\PYG{p}{;}

  \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nb}{false}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{c+cm}{/*No buffering now so no more data read*/}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsubsection{Encoder}
\label{\detokenize{porting/indev:encoder}}
With an encoder you can do 4 things:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
Press its button

\item {} 
Long-press its button

\item {} 
Turn left

\item {} 
Turn right

\end{enumerate}

In short, the Encoder input devices work like this:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
By turning the encoder you can focus on the next/previous object.

\item {} 
When you press the encoder on a simple object (like a button), it will be clicked.

\item {} 
If you press the encoder on a complex object (like a list, message box, etc.) the object will go to edit mode whereby turning the encoder you can navigate inside the object.

\item {} 
To leave edit mode press long the button.

\end{itemize}

To use an \sphinxstyleemphasis{Encoder} (similarly to the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keypads}) the objects should be added to groups.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{type} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}TYPE\PYGZus{}ENCODER}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{read\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{encoder\PYGZus{}read}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}

\PYG{k+kt}{bool} \PYG{n}{encoder\PYGZus{}read}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}data\PYGZus{}t}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{data}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{enc\PYGZus{}diff} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{enc\PYGZus{}get\PYGZus{}new\PYGZus{}moves}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

  \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{enc\PYGZus{}pressed}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{state} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}PR}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{k}{else} \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{state} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}REL}\PYG{p}{;}

  \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nb}{false}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{c+cm}{/*No buffering now so no more data read*/}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\paragraph{Using buttons with Encoder logic}
\label{\detokenize{porting/indev:using-buttons-with-encoder-logic}}
In addition to standar encoder behavior, you can also utilise its logic to navigate(focus) and edit widgets using buttons.
This is especialy handy if you have only few buttons avalible, or you want to use other buttons in addition to encoder wheel.

You need to have 3 buttons avalible:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_ENTER} will simulate press or pushing of the encoder button

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_LEFT} will simulate turnuing encoder left

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_RIGHT} will simulate turnuing encoder right

\item {} 
other keys will be passed to the focused widget

\end{itemize}

If you hold the keys it will simulate encoder click with period specified in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{indev\_drv.long\_press\_rep\_time}}.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{type} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}TYPE\PYGZus{}ENCODER}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{read\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{encoder\PYGZus{}with\PYGZus{}keys\PYGZus{}read}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}

\PYG{k+kt}{bool} \PYG{n}{encoder\PYGZus{}with\PYGZus{}keys\PYGZus{}read}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}data\PYGZus{}t}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{data}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{key} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{last\PYGZus{}key}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}            \PYG{c+cm}{/*Get the last pressed or released key*/}
                                     \PYG{c+cm}{/* use LV\PYGZus{}KEY\PYGZus{}ENTER for encoder press */}
  \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{key\PYGZus{}pressed}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{state} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}PR}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{k}{else} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
      \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{state} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}REL}\PYG{p}{;}
      \PYG{c+cm}{/* Optionally you can also use enc\PYGZus{}diff, if you have encoder*/}
      \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{enc\PYGZus{}diff} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{enc\PYGZus{}get\PYGZus{}new\PYGZus{}moves}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

  \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nb}{false}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{c+cm}{/*No buffering now so no more data read*/}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsubsection{Button}
\label{\detokenize{porting/indev:button}}
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Buttons} mean external "hardware" buttons next to the screen which are assigned to specific coordinates of the screen.
If a button is pressed it will simulate the pressing on the assigned coordinate. (Similarly to a touchpad)

To assign buttons to coordinates use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_indev\_set\_button\_points(my\_indev, points\_array)}}.\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{points\_array}} should look like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{const lv\_point\_t points\_array{[}{]} =  \{ \{12,30\},\{60,90\}, ...\}}}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{important}{Important:}
The points\_array can't go out of scope. Either declare it as a global variable or as a static variable inside a function.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{type} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}TYPE\PYGZus{}BUTTON}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{read\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{button\PYGZus{}read}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}

\PYG{k+kt}{bool} \PYG{n}{button\PYGZus{}read}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}data\PYGZus{}t}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{data}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{k}{static} \PYG{k+kt}{uint32\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{last\PYGZus{}btn} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{;}   \PYG{c+cm}{/*Store the last pressed button*/}
    \PYG{k+kt}{int} \PYG{n}{btn\PYGZus{}pr} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}btn\PYGZus{}read}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}     \PYG{c+cm}{/*Get the ID (0,1,2...) of the pressed button*/}
    \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{btn\PYGZus{}pr} \PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}               \PYG{c+cm}{/*Is there a button press? (E.g. \PYGZhy{}1 indicated no button was pressed)*/}
       \PYG{n}{last\PYGZus{}btn} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{btn\PYGZus{}pr}\PYG{p}{;}           \PYG{c+cm}{/*Save the ID of the pressed button*/}
       \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{state} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}PR}\PYG{p}{;}  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set the pressed state*/}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}} \PYG{k}{else} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
       \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{state} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}INDEV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}REL}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set the released state*/}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

    \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{btn} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{last\PYGZus{}btn}\PYG{p}{;}            \PYG{c+cm}{/*Save the last button*/}

    \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nb}{false}\PYG{p}{;}                    \PYG{c+cm}{/*No buffering now so no more data read*/}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Other features}
\label{\detokenize{porting/indev:other-features}}
Besides \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{read\_cb}} a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{feedback\_cb}} callback can be also specified in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_indev\_drv\_t}}.
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{feedback\_cb}} is called when any type of event is sent by the input devices. (independently from its type). It allows making feedback for the user e.g. to play a sound on \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_EVENT\_CLICK}}.

The default value of the following parameters can be set in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h} but the default value can be overwritten in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_indev\_drv\_t}}:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{drag\_limit} Number of pixels to slide before actually drag the object

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{drag\_throw}  Drag throw slow-down in {[}\%{]}. Greater value means faster slow-down

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{long\_press\_time} Press time to send \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_EVENT\_LONG\_PRESSED}} (in milliseconds)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{long\_press\_rep\_time} Interval of sending \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_EVENT\_LONG\_PRESSED\_REPEAT}} (in milliseconds)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{read\_task} pointer to the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task}} which reads the input device. Its parameters can be changed by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_...()}} functions

\end{itemize}

Every Input device is associated with a display. By default, a new input device is added to the lastly created or the explicitly selected (using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_set\_default()}}) display.
The associated display is stored and can be changed in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{disp}} field of the driver.


\subsection{API}
\label{\detokenize{porting/indev:api}}
Input Device HAL interface layer header file 
\subsubsection*{Typedefs}
\index{lv\_indev\_type\_t (C++ type)@\spxentry{lv\_indev\_type\_t}\spxextra{C++ type}}

\begin{fulllineitems}

\section{Tick interface}
\label{\detokenize{porting/tick:tick-interface}}\label{\detokenize{porting/tick::doc}}
The LVGL needs a system tick to know the elapsed time for animation and other tasks.

You need to call the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_tick\_inc(tick\_period)}} function periodically and tell the call period in milliseconds. For example, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_tick\_inc(1)}} for calling in every millisecond.

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_tick\_inc}} should be called in a higher priority routine than \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler()}} (e.g. in an interrupt) to precisely know the elapsed milliseconds even if the execution of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler}} takes longer time.

With FreeRTOS \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_tick\_inc}} can be called in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{vApplicationTickHook}}.

On Linux based operating system (e.g. on Raspberry Pi) \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_tick\_inc}} can be called in a thread as below:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n+nf}{tick\PYGZus{}thread} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{args}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
      \PYG{k}{while}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{n}{usleep}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1000}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}   \PYG{c+cm}{/*Sleep for 5 millisecond*/}
        \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}tick\PYGZus{}inc}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}      \PYG{c+cm}{/*Tell LVGL that 5 milliseconds were elapsed*/}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{API}
\label{\detokenize{porting/tick:api}}
Provide access to the system tick with 1 millisecond resolution
