\section{Task Handler}
\label{\detokenize{porting/task-handler:task-handler}}\label{\detokenize{porting/task-handler::doc}}
To handle the tasks of LVGL you need to call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler()}} periodically in one of the followings:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{while(1)} of \sphinxstyleemphasis{main()} function

\item {} 
timer interrupt periodically (low priority then \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_tick\_inc()}})

\item {} 
an OS task periodically

\end{itemize}

The timing is not critical but it should be about 5 milliseconds to keep the system responsive.

Example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{while}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}task\PYGZus{}handler}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}delay\PYGZus{}ms}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

To learn more about task visit the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/task::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Tasks}}}} section.


\section{Sleep management}
\label{\detokenize{porting/sleep:sleep-management}}\label{\detokenize{porting/sleep::doc}}
The MCU can go to sleep when no user input happens. In this case, the main \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{while(1)}} should look like this:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{while}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Normal operation (no sleep) in \PYGZlt{} 1 sec inactivity*/}
  \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}disp\PYGZus{}get\PYGZus{}inactive\PYGZus{}time}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1000}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
	  \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}task\PYGZus{}handler}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Sleep after 1 sec inactivity*/}
  \PYG{k}{else} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
	  \PYG{n}{timer\PYGZus{}stop}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}   \PYG{c+cm}{/*Stop the timer where lv\PYGZus{}tick\PYGZus{}inc() is called*/}
	  \PYG{n}{sleep}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}		    \PYG{c+cm}{/*Sleep the MCU*/}
  \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
  \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}delay\PYGZus{}ms}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

You should also add below lines to your input device read function if a wake-up (press, touch or click etc.) happens:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}tick\PYGZus{}inc}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}DISP\PYGZus{}DEF\PYGZus{}REFR\PYGZus{}PERIOD}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Force task execution on wake\PYGZhy{}up*/}
\PYG{n}{timer\PYGZus{}start}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}                         \PYG{c+cm}{/*Restart the timer where lv\PYGZus{}tick\PYGZus{}inc() is called*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}task\PYGZus{}handler}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}                     \PYG{c+cm}{/*Call {}`lv\PYGZus{}task\PYGZus{}handler(){}` manually to process the wake\PYGZhy{}up event*/}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

In addition to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_get\_inactive\_time()}} you can check \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_anim\_count\_running()}} to see if every animations are finished.


\section{Operating system and interrupts}
\label{\detokenize{porting/os:operating-system-and-interrupts}}\label{\detokenize{porting/os::doc}}
LVGL is \sphinxstylestrong{not thread-safe} by default.

However, in the following conditions it's valid to call LVGL related functions:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
In \sphinxstyleemphasis{events}. Learn more in {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.

\item {} 
In \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_tasks}. Learn more in {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/task::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Tasks}}}}.

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Tasks and threads}
\label{\detokenize{porting/os:tasks-and-threads}}
If you need to use real tasks or threads, you need a mutex which should be invoked before the call of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler}} and released after it.
Also, you have to use the same mutex in other tasks and threads around every LVGL (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_...}}) related function calls and codes.
This way you can use LVGL in a real multitasking environment. Just make use of a mutex to avoid the concurrent calling of LVGL functions.


\subsection{Interrupts}
\label{\detokenize{porting/os:interrupts}}
Try to avoid calling LVGL functions from the interrupts (except \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_tick\_inc()}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_flush\_ready()}}). But, if you need to do this you have to disable the interrupt which uses LVGL functions while \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler}} is running.
It's a better approach to set a flag or some value and periodically check it in an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task}}.


\section{Logging}
\label{\detokenize{porting/log:logging}}\label{\detokenize{porting/log::doc}}
LVGL has built-in \sphinxstyleemphasis{log} module to inform the user about what is happening in the library.


\subsection{Log level}
\label{\detokenize{porting/log:log-level}}
To enable logging, set \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_USE\_LOG  1}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h} and set \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LOG\_LEVEL}} to one of the following values:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LOG\_LEVEL\_TRACE} A lot of logs to give detailed information

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LOG\_LEVEL\_INFO}  Log important events

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LOG\_LEVEL\_WARN}  Log if something unwanted happened but didn't cause a problem

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LOG\_LEVEL\_ERROR} Only critical issue, when the system may fail

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LOG\_LEVEL\_NONE}  Do not log anything

\end{itemize}

The events which have a higher level than the set log level will be logged too. E.g. if you \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LOG\_LEVEL\_WARN}}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{errors} will be also logged.


\subsection{Logging with printf}
\label{\detokenize{porting/log:logging-with-printf}}
If your system supports \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{printf}}, you just need to enable \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LOG\_PRINTF}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h} to send the logs with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{printf}}.


\subsection{Custom log function}
\label{\detokenize{porting/log:custom-log-function}}
If you can't use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{printf}} or want to use a custom function to log, you can register a "logger" callback with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_log\_register\_print\_cb()}}.

For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{n+nf}{my\PYGZus{}log\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}log\PYGZus{}level\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{level}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{const} \PYG{k+kt}{char} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{file}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k+kt}{int} \PYG{n}{line}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{const} \PYG{k+kt}{char} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{fn\PYGZus{}name}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k}{const} \PYG{k+kt}{char} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{dsc}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Send the logs via serial port*/}
  \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{level} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}LOG\PYGZus{}LEVEL\PYGZus{}ERROR}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n}{serial\PYGZus{}send}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{ERROR: }\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{level} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}LOG\PYGZus{}LEVEL\PYGZus{}WARN}\PYG{p}{)}  \PYG{n}{serial\PYGZus{}send}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{WARNING: }\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{level} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}LOG\PYGZus{}LEVEL\PYGZus{}INFO}\PYG{p}{)}  \PYG{n}{serial\PYGZus{}send}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{INFO: }\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{level} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}LOG\PYGZus{}LEVEL\PYGZus{}TRACE}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n}{serial\PYGZus{}send}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{TRACE: }\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

  \PYG{n}{serial\PYGZus{}send}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{File: }\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{n}{serial\PYGZus{}send}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{file}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

  \PYG{k+kt}{char} \PYG{n}{line\PYGZus{}str}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{n}{sprintf}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{line\PYGZus{}str}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZpc{}d}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{line}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{n}{serial\PYGZus{}send}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsh{}}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{n}{serial\PYGZus{}send}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{line\PYGZus{}str}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

  \PYG{n}{serial\PYGZus{}send}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{: }\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{n}{serial\PYGZus{}send}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{fn\PYGZus{}name}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{n}{serial\PYGZus{}send}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{: }\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{n}{serial\PYGZus{}send}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{dsc}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{n}{serial\PYGZus{}send}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}log\PYGZus{}register\PYGZus{}print\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}log\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Add logs}
\label{\detokenize{porting/log:add-logs}}
You can also use the log module via the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LOG\_TRACE/INFO/WARN/ERROR(description)}} functions.


\chapter{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{overview/index:overview}}\label{\detokenize{overview/index::doc}}

\section{Objects}
\label{\detokenize{overview/object:objects}}\label{\detokenize{overview/object::doc}}
In the LVGL the \sphinxstylestrong{basic building blocks} of a user interface are the objects, also called \sphinxstyleemphasis{Widgets}.
For example a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/btn::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Button}}}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/label::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Label}}}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/img::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Image}}}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/list::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{List}}}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/chart::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Chart}}}} or {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/textarea::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Text area}}}}.

Check all the {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/index::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Object types}}}} here.


\subsection{Object attributes}
\label{\detokenize{overview/object:object-attributes}}

\subsubsection{Basic attributes}
\label{\detokenize{overview/object:basic-attributes}}
All object types share some basic attributes:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Position

\item {} 
Size

\item {} 
Parent

\item {} 
Drag enable

\item {} 
Click enable etc.

\end{itemize}

You can set/get these attributes with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_...}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_get\_...}} functions. For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+cm}{/*Set basic object attributes*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}size}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{btn1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{100}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{50}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}	 \PYG{c+cm}{/*Button size*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}pos}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{btn1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{20}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{30}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}      \PYG{c+cm}{/*Button position*/}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

To see all the available functions visit the Base object's {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/obj::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{documentation}}}}.


\subsubsection{Specific attributes}
\label{\detokenize{overview/object:specific-attributes}}
The object types have special attributes too. For example, a slider has
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Min. max. values

\item {} 
Current value

\item {} 
Custom styles

\end{itemize}

For these attributes, every object type have unique API functions. For example for a slider:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+cm}{/*Set slider specific attributes*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}slider\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}range}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{slider1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{100}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}	   \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set min. and max. values*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}slider\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}value}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{slider1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{40}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}ANIM\PYGZus{}ON}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}	\PYG{c+cm}{/*Set the current value (position)*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}slider\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}action}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{slider1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}action}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}     \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set a callback function*/}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

The API of the object types are described in their {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/index::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Documentation}}}} but you can also check the respective header files (e.g. \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_objx/lv\_slider.h})


\subsection{Object's working mechanisms}
\label{\detokenize{overview/object:object-s-working-mechanisms}}

\subsubsection{Parent-child structure}
\label{\detokenize{overview/object:parent-child-structure}}
A parent object can be considered as the container of its children. Every object has exactly one parent object (except screens), but a parent can have an unlimited number of children.
There is no limitation for the type of the parent but, there are typical parent (e.g. button) and typical child (e.g. label) objects.


\subsubsection{Moving together}
\label{\detokenize{overview/object:moving-together}}
If the position of the parent is changed the children will move with the parent.
Therefore all positions are relative to the parent.

The (0;0) coordinates mean the objects will remain in the top left-hand corner of the parent independently from the position of the parent.

\sphinxincludegraphics{{par_child1}.png}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{par} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}scr\PYGZus{}act}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{c+cm}{/*Create a parent object on the current screen*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}size}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{par}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{100}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{80}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}	                   \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set the size of the parent*/}

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{obj1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{par}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}	         \PYG{c+cm}{/*Create an object on the previously created parent object*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}pos}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{obj1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}	                   \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set the position of the new object*/}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Modify the position of the parent:

\sphinxincludegraphics{{par_child2}.png}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}pos}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{par}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{50}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{50}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}	\PYG{c+cm}{/*Move the parent. The child will move with it.*/}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

(For simplicity the adjusting of colors of the objects is not shown in the example.)


\subsubsection{Visibility only on the parent}
\label{\detokenize{overview/object:visibility-only-on-the-parent}}
If a child is partially or fully out of its parent then the parts outside will not be visible.

\sphinxincludegraphics{{par_child3}.png}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}x}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{obj1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{30}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}	\PYG{c+cm}{/*Move the child a little bit of the parent*/}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsubsection{Create - delete objects}
\label{\detokenize{overview/object:create-delete-objects}}
In LVGL objects can be created and deleted dynamically in run-time.
It means only the currently created objects consume RAM.
For example, if you need a chart, you can create it when required and delete it when it is not visible or necessary.

Every object type has its own \sphinxstylestrong{create} function with a unified prototype.
It needs two parameters:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
A pointer to the \sphinxstyleemphasis{parent} object. To create a screen give \sphinxstyleemphasis{NULL} as parent.

\item {} 
Optionally, a pointer to \sphinxstyleemphasis{copy} object with the same type to copy it. This \sphinxstyleemphasis{copy} object can be \sphinxstyleemphasis{NULL} to avoid the copy operation.

\end{itemize}

All objects are referenced in C code using an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_t}} pointer as a handle. This pointer can later be used to set or get the attributes of the object.

The create functions look like this:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{type}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{parent}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{copy}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

There is a common \sphinxstylestrong{delete} function for all object types. It deletes the object and all of its children.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{n+nf}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}del}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{obj}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_del}} will delete the object immediately.
If for any reason you can't delete the object immediately you can use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_del\_async(obj)}}.
It is useful e.g. if you want to delete the parent of an object in the child's \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_EVENT\_DELETE}} signal.

You can remove all the children of an object (but not the object itself) using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_clean}}:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{n+nf}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}clean}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{obj}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsubsection{Screen \textendash{} the most basic parent}
\label{\detokenize{overview/object:screen-the-most-basic-parent}}
The screens are special objects which have no parent object. So it is created like:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{scr1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

There is always an active screen on each display. By default, the library creates and loads a "Base object" as the screen for each display.To get the currently active screen use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_scr\_act()}} function. To load a new one, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_scr\_load(scr1)}}.

Screens can be created with any object type. For example, a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/obj::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Base object}}}} or an image to make a wallpaper.

Screens are created on the currently selected \sphinxstyleemphasis{default display}.
The \sphinxstyleemphasis{default screen} is the last registered screen with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_drv\_register}} or you can explicitly select a new default display using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_set\_default(disp)}}.
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_scr\_act()}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_scr\_load()}} operate on the currently default screen.

Visit {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/display::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Multi-display support}}}} to learn more.


\subsection{Parts}
\label{\detokenize{overview/object:parts}}
The widgets can have multiple parts. For example a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/btn::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Button}}}} has only a main part but a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/slider::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Slider}}}} is built from a background, an indicator and a knob.

The name of the parts is constructed like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_ + \textless{}TYPE\textgreater{} \_PART\_ \textless{}NAME\textgreater{}}}. For example \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BTN\_PART\_MAIN}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_SLIDER\_PART\_KNOB}}. The parts are usually used when styles are add to the objects.
Using parts different styles can be assigned to the different parts of the objects.

To learn more about the parts read the related section of the \sphinxhref{/overview/style\#parts}{Style overview}.


\subsubsection{States}
\label{\detokenize{overview/object:states}}
The object can be in a combinations of the following states:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_DEFAULT}  Normal, released

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_CHECKED} Toggled or checked

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_FOCUSED} Focused via keypad or encoder or clicked via touchpad/mouse

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_EDITED}  Edit by an encoder

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_HOVERED} Hovered by mouse (not supported now)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_PRESSED} Pressed

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_DISABLED} Disabled or inactive

\end{itemize}

The states are usually automatically changed by the library as the user presses, releases, focuses etc an object.
However, the states can be changed manually too. To completely overwrite the current state use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_state(obj, part, LV\_STATE...)}}.
To set or clear given state (but leave to other states untouched) use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_add/clear\_state(obj, part, LV\_STATE\_...)}}
In both cases ORed state values can be used as well. E.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_state(obj, part, LV\_STATE\_PRESSED \textbar{} LV\_PRESSED\_CHECKED)}}.

To learn more about the states read the related section of the \sphinxhref{/overview/style\#states}{Style overview}.


\section{Layers}
\label{\detokenize{overview/layer:layers}}\label{\detokenize{overview/layer::doc}}

\subsection{Order of creation}
\label{\detokenize{overview/layer:order-of-creation}}
By default, LVGL draws old objects on the background and new objects on the foreground.

For example, assume we added a button to a parent object named button1 and then another button named button2. Then button1 (with its child object(s)) will be in the background and can be covered by button2 and its children.

\sphinxincludegraphics{{layers}.png}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+cm}{/*Create a screen*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{scr} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}scr\PYGZus{}load}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{scr}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}          \PYG{c+cm}{/*Load the screen*/}

\PYG{c+cm}{/*Create 2 buttons*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{btn1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}btn\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{scr}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}         \PYG{c+cm}{/*Create a button on the screen*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}btn\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}fit}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{btn1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{true}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{true}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}                   \PYG{c+cm}{/*Enable to automatically set the size according to the content*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}pos}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{btn1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{60}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{40}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}              	   \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set the position of the button*/}

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{btn2} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}btn\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{scr}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{btn1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}         \PYG{c+cm}{/*Copy the first button*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}pos}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{btn2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{180}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{80}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}                    \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set the position of the button*/}

\PYG{c+cm}{/*Add labels to the buttons*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{label1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}label\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{btn1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}	\PYG{c+cm}{/*Create a label on the first button*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}label\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}text}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{label1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Button 1}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}          	\PYG{c+cm}{/*Set the text of the label*/}

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{label2} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}label\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{btn2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}  	\PYG{c+cm}{/*Create a label on the second button*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}label\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}text}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{label2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Button 2}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}            	\PYG{c+cm}{/*Set the text of the label*/}

\PYG{c+cm}{/*Delete the second label*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}del}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{label2}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Bring to the foreground}
\label{\detokenize{overview/layer:bring-to-the-foreground}}
There are several ways to bring an object to the foreground:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_top(obj, true)}}. If \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{obj}} or any of its children is clicked, then LVGL will automatically bring the object to the foreground.
It works similarly to a typical GUI on a PC. When a window in the background is clicked, it will come to the foreground automatically.

\item {} 
Use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_move\_foreground(obj)}} to explicitly tell the library to bring an object to the foreground. Similarly, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_move\_background(obj)}} to move to the background.

\item {} 
When \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_parent(obj, new\_parent)}} is used, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{obj}} will be on the foreground on the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{new\_parent}}.

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Top and sys layers}
\label{\detokenize{overview/layer:top-and-sys-layers}}
LVGL uses two special layers named as \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{layer\_top}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{layer\_sys}}.
Both are visible and common on all screens of a display. \sphinxstylestrong{They are not, however, shared among multiple physical displays.} The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{layer\_top}} is always on top of the default screen (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_scr\_act()}}), and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{layer\_sys}} is on top of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{layer\_top}}.

The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{layer\_top}} can be used by the user to create some content visible everywhere. For example, a menu bar, a pop-up, etc. If the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{click}} attribute is enabled, then \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{layer\_top}} will absorb all user click and acts as a modal.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}click}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}layer\PYGZus{}top}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{true}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{layer\_sys}} is also using for similar purpose on LVGL. For example, it places the mouse cursor there to be sure it's always visible.


\section{Events}
\label{\detokenize{overview/event:events}}\label{\detokenize{overview/event::doc}}
Events are triggered in LVGL when something happens which might be interesting to the user, e.g. if an object:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
is clicked

\item {} 
is dragged

\item {} 
its value has changed, etc.

\end{itemize}

The user can assign a callback function to an object to see these events. In practice, it looks like this:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{btn} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}btn\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}scr\PYGZus{}act}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}event\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{btn}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}event\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}   \PYG{c+cm}{/*Assign an event callback*/}

\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}

\PYG{k}{static} \PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}event\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{obj}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}event\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{event}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{k}{switch}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{event}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{k}{case} \PYG{n+nl}{LV\PYGZus{}EVENT\PYGZus{}PRESSED}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{n}{printf}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Pressed}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
            \PYG{k}{break}\PYG{p}{;}

        \PYG{k}{case} \PYG{n+nl}{LV\PYGZus{}EVENT\PYGZus{}SHORT\PYGZus{}CLICKED}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{n}{printf}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Short clicked}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
            \PYG{k}{break}\PYG{p}{;}

        \PYG{k}{case} \PYG{n+nl}{LV\PYGZus{}EVENT\PYGZus{}CLICKED}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{n}{printf}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Clicked}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
            \PYG{k}{break}\PYG{p}{;}

        \PYG{k}{case} \PYG{n+nl}{LV\PYGZus{}EVENT\PYGZus{}LONG\PYGZus{}PRESSED}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{n}{printf}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Long press}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
            \PYG{k}{break}\PYG{p}{;}

        \PYG{k}{case} \PYG{n+nl}{LV\PYGZus{}EVENT\PYGZus{}LONG\PYGZus{}PRESSED\PYGZus{}REPEAT}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{n}{printf}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Long press repeat}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
            \PYG{k}{break}\PYG{p}{;}

        \PYG{k}{case} \PYG{n+nl}{LV\PYGZus{}EVENT\PYGZus{}RELEASED}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{n}{printf}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Released}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
            \PYG{k}{break}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

       \PYG{c+cm}{/*Etc.*/}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

More objects can use the same \sphinxstyleemphasis{event callback}.


\subsection{Event types}
\label{\detokenize{overview/event:event-types}}
The following event types exist:


\subsubsection{Generic events}
\label{\detokenize{overview/event:generic-events}}
All objects (such as Buttons/Labels/Sliders etc.) receive these generic events regardless of their type.


\paragraph{Related to the input devices}
\label{\detokenize{overview/event:related-to-the-input-devices}}
These are sent when an object is pressed/released etc. by the user. They are used not only for \sphinxstyleemphasis{Pointers} but can used for \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keypad}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{Encoder} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{Button} input devices as well. Visit the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Overview of input devices}}}} section to learn more about them.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_PRESSED} The object has been pressed

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_PRESSING} The object is being pressed (sent continuously while pressing)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_PRESS\_LOST} The input device is still being pressed but is no longer on the object

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_SHORT\_CLICKED} Released before \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_INDEV\_LONG\_PRESS\_TIME}} time. Not called if dragged.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_LONG\_PRESSED}  Pressing for \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_INDEV\_LONG\_PRESS\_TIME}} time.  Not called if dragged.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_LONG\_PRESSED\_REPEAT} Called after \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_INDEV\_LONG\_PRESS\_TIME}} in every \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_INDEV\_LONG\_PRESS\_REP\_TIME}} ms.  Not called if dragged.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_CLICKED} Called on release if not dragged (regardless to long press)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_RELEASED}  Called in every case when the object has been released even if it was dragged. Not called if slid from the object while pressing and released outside of the object. In this case, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_EVENT\_PRESS\_LOST}} is sent.

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Related to pointer}
\label{\detokenize{overview/event:related-to-pointer}}
These events are sent only by pointer-like input devices (E.g. mouse or touchpad)
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_DRAG\_BEGIN} Dragging of the object has started

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_DRAG\_END} Dragging finished (including drag throw)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_DRAG\_THROW\_BEGIN} Drag throw started (released after drag with "momentum")

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Related to keypad and encoder}
\label{\detokenize{overview/event:related-to-keypad-and-encoder}}
These events are sent by keypad and encoder input devices. Learn more about \sphinxstyleemphasis{Groups} in {[}overview/indev{]}(Input devices) section.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_KEY} A \sphinxstyleemphasis{Key} is sent to the object. Typically when it was pressed or repeated after a long press

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_FOCUSED} The object is focused in its group

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_DEFOCUSED} The object is defocused in its group

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{General events}
\label{\detokenize{overview/event:general-events}}
Other general events sent by the library.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_DELETE} The object is being deleted. Free the related user-allocated data.

\end{itemize}


\subsubsection{Special events}
\label{\detokenize{overview/event:special-events}}
These events are specific to a particular object type.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_VALUE\_CHANGED} The object value has changed (e.g. for a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/slider::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Slider}}}})

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_INSERT} Something is inserted to the object. (Typically to a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/textarea::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Text area}}}})

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_APPLY}  "Ok", "Apply" or similar specific button has clicked. (Typically from a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/keyboard::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keyboard}}}} object)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_CANCEL} "Close", "Cancel" or similar specific button has clicked. (Typically from a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/keyboard::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keyboard}}}} object)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_REFRESH} Query to refresh the object. Never sent by the library but can be sent by the user.

\end{itemize}

Visit particular {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/index::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Object type's documentation}}}} to understand which events are used by an object type.


\subsection{Custom data}
\label{\detokenize{overview/event:custom-data}}
Some events might contain custom data. For example, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_EVENT\_VALUE\_CHANGED}} in some cases tells the new value. For more information, see the particular {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/index::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Object type's documentation}}}}.
To get the custom data in the event callback use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_event\_get\_data()}}.

The type of the custom data depends on the sending object but if it's a
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
single number then it's \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{uint32\_t *}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{int32\_t *}}

\item {} 
text then \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{char * }} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{const char *}}

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Send events manually}
\label{\detokenize{overview/event:send-events-manually}}
To manually send events to an object, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_event\_send(obj, LV\_EVENT\_..., \&custom\_data)}}.

For example, it can be used to manually close a message box by simulating a button press (although there are simpler ways of doing this):

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+cm}{/*Simulate the press of the first button (indexes start from zero)*/}
\PYG{k+kt}{uint32\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{btn\PYGZus{}id} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}event\PYGZus{}send}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{mbox}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}EVENT\PYGZus{}VALUE\PYGZus{}CHANGED}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{btn\PYGZus{}id}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Or to perform refresh generically:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}event\PYGZus{}send}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{label}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}EVENT\PYGZus{}REFRESH}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\section{Styles}
\label{\detokenize{overview/style:styles}}\label{\detokenize{overview/style::doc}}
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Styles} are used to set the appearance of the objects. Styles in lvgl are heavily inspired by CSS. The concept in nutshell is the following:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
A style is an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_t}} variable which can hold properties, for example border width, text color and so on. It's similar to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{class}} in CSS.

\item {} 
Not all properties have to be specified. Unspecified properties will use a default value.

\item {} 
Styles can be assigned to objects to change their appearance.

\item {} 
A style can be used by any number of objects.

\item {} 
Styles can be cascaded which means multiple styles can be assigned to an object and each style can have different properties.  
For example \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style\_btn}} can result in a default gray button and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style\_btn\_red}} can add only a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{background-color=red}} to overwrite the background color.

\item {} 
Later added styles have higher precedence. It means if a property is specified in two styles the later added will be used.

\item {} 
Some properties (e.g. text color) can be inherited from the parent(s) if it's not specified in the object.

\item {} 
Objects can have local styles that have higher precedence than "normal" styles.

\item {} 
Unlike CSS (where pseudo-classes describes different states, e.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{:hover}}), in lvgl a property is assigned to a given state. (I.e. not the "class" is related to state but every single property has a state)

\item {} 
Transitions can be applied when the object changes state.

\end{itemize}


\subsection{States}
\label{\detokenize{overview/style:states}}
The objects can be in the following states:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_DEFAULT} (0x00): Normal, released

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_CHECKED} (0x01): Toggled or checked

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_FOCUSED} (0x02): Focused via keypad or encoder or clicked via touchpad/mouse

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_EDITED}  (0x04): Edit by an encoder

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_HOVERED} (0x08): Hovered by mouse (not supported now)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_PRESSED} (0x10): Pressed

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_DISABLED} (0x20): Disabled or inactive

\end{itemize}

Combination of states is  also possible, for example \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_STATE\_FOCUSED \textbar{} LV\_STATE\_PRESSED}}.

The style properties can be defined in every state and state combination. For example, setting a different background color for default and pressed state.
If a property is not defined in a state the best matching state's property will be used. Typically it means the property with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_STATE\_DEFAULT}} state.˛
If the property is not set even for the default state the default value will be used. (See later)

But what does the "best matching state's property" really means?
States have a precedence which is shown by their value (see in the above list). A higher value means higher precedence.
To determine which state's property to use let's use an example. Let's see the background color is defined like this:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_STATE\_DEFAULT}}: white

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_STATE\_PRESSED}}: gray

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_STATE\_FOCUSED}}: red

\end{itemize}
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
By the default the object is in default state, so it's a simple case: the property is perfectly defined in the object's current state as white

\item {} 
When the object is pressed there are 2 related properties: default with white (default is related to every state) and pressed with gray.
The pressed state has 0x10 precedence which is higher than the default state's 0x00 precedence, so gray color will be used.

\item {} 
When the object is focused the same thing happens as in pressed state and red color will be used. (Focused state has higher precedence than default state).

\item {} 
When the object is focused and pressed both gray and red would work, but the pressed state has higher precedence than focused so gray color will be used.

\item {} 
It's possible to set e.g rose color for \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_STATE\_PRESSED \textbar{} LV\_STATE\_FOCUSED}}.
In this case, this combined state has 0x02 + 0x10 = 0x12 precedence, which higher than the pressed states precedence so rose color would be used.

\item {} 
When the object is checked there is no property to set the background color for this state. So in lack of a better option, the object remains white from the default state's property.

\end{enumerate}

Some practical notes:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
If you want to set a property for all state (e.g. red background color) just set it for the default state. If the object can't find a property for its current state it will fall back to the default state's property.

\item {} 
Use ORed states to describe the properties for complex cases. (E.g. pressed + checked + focused)

\item {} 
It might be a good idea to use different style elements for different states.
For example, finding background colors for released, pressed, checked + pressed, focused, focused + pressed, focused + pressed + checked, etc states is quite difficult.
Instead, for example, use the background color for pressed and checked states and indicate the focused state with a different border color.

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Cascading styles}
\label{\detokenize{overview/style:cascading-styles}}
It's not required to set all the properties in one style. It's possible to add more styles to an object and let the later added style to modify or extend the properties in the other styles.
For example, create a general gray button style and create a new for red buttons where only the new background color is set.

It's the same concept when in CSS all the used classes are listed like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textless{}div class=".btn .btn-red"\textgreater{}}}.

The later added styles have higher precedence over the earlier ones. So in the gray/red button example above, the normal button style should be added first and the red style second.
However, the precedence coming from states are still taken into account.
So let's examine the following case:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
the basic button style defines dark-gray color for default state and light-gray color pressed state

\item {} 
the red button style defines the background color as red only in the default state

\end{itemize}

In this case, when the button is released (it's in default state) it will be red because a perfect match is found in the lastly added style (red style).
When the button is pressed the light-gray color is a better match because it describes the current state perfectly, so the button will be light-gray.


\subsection{Inheritance}
\label{\detokenize{overview/style:inheritance}}
Some properties (typically that are related to texts) can be inherited from the parent object's styles. Inheritance is applied only if the given property is not set in the object's styles (even in default state).
In this case, if the property is inheritable, the property's value will be searched in the parent too until a part can tell a value for the property. The parents will use their own state to tell the value.
So is button is pressed, and text color comes from here, the pressed text color will be used.


\subsection{Parts}
\label{\detokenize{overview/style:parts}}
Objects can have \sphinxstyleemphasis{parts} which can have their own style. For example a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/page::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{page}}}} has four parts:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Background

\item {} 
Scrollable

\item {} 
Scrollbar

\item {} 
Edge flash

\end{itemize}

!{[}page\_small.png{]}(A scrollable page in lvgl)

There is three types of object parts \sphinxstylestrong{main}, \sphinxstylestrong{virtual} and \sphinxstylestrong{real}.

The main part is usually the background and largest part of the object. Some object has only a main part. For example, a button has only a background.

The virtual parts are additional parts just drawn on the fly to the main part. There is no "real" object behind them.
For example, the page's scrollbar is not a real object, it's just drawn when the page's background is drawn.
The virtual parts always have the same state as the main part.
If the property can be inherited, the main part will be also considered before going to the parent.

The real parts are real objects created and managed by the main object. For example, the page's scrollable part is real object.
Real parts can be in different state than the main part.

To see which parts an object has visit their documentation page.


\subsection{Initialize styles and set/get properties}
\label{\detokenize{overview/style:initialize-styles-and-set-get-properties}}
Styles are stored in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_t}} variables. Style variables should be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{static}}, global or dynamically allocated. In other words they can not be local variables in functions which are destroyed when the function exists.
Before using a style it should be initialized with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_init(\&my\_style)}}.
After initializing the style properties can be set added to it.
Property set functions looks like this: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_set\_\textless{}property\_name\textgreater{}(\&style, \textless{}state\textgreater{}, \textless{}value\textgreater{});}}
For example the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/style:states}]{\emph{above mentioned}}} example looks like this:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{static} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{style1}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}bg\PYGZus{}color}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{style1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}DEFAULT}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}COLOR\PYGZus{}WHITE}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}bg\PYGZus{}color}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{style1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}PRESSED}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}COLOR\PYGZus{}GRAY}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}bg\PYGZus{}color}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{style1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}FOCUSED}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}COLOR\PYGZus{}RED}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}bg\PYGZus{}color}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{style1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}FOCUSED} \PYG{o}{\textbar{}} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}PRESSED}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color\PYGZus{}hex}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mh}{0xf88}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

It's possible to copy a style with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_copy(\&style\_destination, \&style\_source)}}. After copy properties still can be added freely.

To remove a property use:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}remove\PYGZus{}prop}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{style}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}STYLE\PYGZus{}BG\PYGZus{}COLOR} \PYG{o}{\textbar{}} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}PRESSED} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}STYLE\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}POS}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

To get the value from style in a state functions with the following prototype are available: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_get\_\textless{}prperty\_name\textgreater{}(\&style, \textless{}state\textgreater{}, \textless{}result poiner\textgreater{});}}.
The the best matching property will be selected and it's precedence will be returned. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{-1}} will be returned if the property is not found. For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{color}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{k+kt}{int16\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{res}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{res} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}get\PYGZus{}bg\PYGZus{}color}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{style1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}PRESSED}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{color}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{res} \PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{c+c1}{//the bg\PYGZus{}color is loaded into {}`color{}`}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

To reset a style (free all it's data) use

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}reset}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{style}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Managing style list}
\label{\detokenize{overview/style:managing-style-list}}
A style on its own not that useful. It should be assigned to an object to take its effect.
Every part of the objects stores a \sphinxstyleemphasis{style list} which is the list of assigned styles.

To add a style to an object use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_add\_style(obj, \textless{}part\textgreater{}, \&style)}}
For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}add\PYGZus{}style}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{btn}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}BTN\PYGZus{}PART\PYGZus{}MAIN}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{btn}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}      \PYG{c+cm}{/*Default button style*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}add\PYGZus{}style}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{btn}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}BTN\PYGZus{}PART\PYGZus{}MAIN}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{btn\PYGZus{}red}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Overwrite only a some colors to red*/}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

An objects style list can be reset with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_reset\_style\_list(obj, \textless{}part\textgreater{})}}

If a style which is already assigned to an object changes (i.e. one of it's property is set to a new value) the objects using that style should be notified with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_refresh\_style(obj)}}

To get a final value of property, including cascading, inheritance, local styles and transitions (see below), get functions like this can be used: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_get\_style\_\textless{}property\_name\textgreater{}(obj, \textless{}part\textgreater{})}}.
These functions uses the object's current state and if no better candidate returns a default value.  
For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{color} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}get\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}bg\PYGZus{}color}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{btn}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}BTN\PYGZus{}PART\PYGZus{}MAIN}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Local styles}
\label{\detokenize{overview/style:local-styles}}
In the object's style lists, so-called local properties can be stored as well. It's the same concept than CSS's \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textless{}div style="color:red"\textgreater{}}}.
The local style is the same as a normal style, but it belongs only to a given object and can not be shared with other objects.
To set a local property use functions like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_style\_local\_\textless{}property\_name\textgreater{}(obj, \textless{}part\textgreater{}, \textless{}state\textgreater{}, \textless{}value\textgreater{});}}  
For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}local\PYGZus{}bg\PYGZus{}color}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{btn}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}BTN\PYGZus{}PART\PYGZus{}MAIN}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}DEFAULT}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}COLOR\PYGZus{}RED}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Transitions}
\label{\detokenize{overview/style:transitions}}
By default, when an object changes state (e.g. it's pressed) the new properties from the new state are set immediately. However, with transitions it's possible to play an animation on state change.
For example, on pressing a button its background color can be animated to the pressed color over 300 ms.

The parameters of the transitions are stored in the styles. It's possible to set
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
the time of the transition

\item {} 
the delay before starting the transition

\item {} 
the animation path (also known as timing function)

\item {} 
the properties to animate

\end{itemize}

The transition properties can be defined for each state.
For example, setting 500 ms transition time in default state will mean that when the object goes to default state 500 ms transition time will be applied.
Setting 100 ms transition time in the pressed state will mean a 100 ms transition time when going to presses state.
So this example configuration will result in fast going to presses state and slow going back to default.


\subsection{Properties}
\label{\detokenize{overview/style:properties}}
The following properties can be used in the styles.


\subsubsection{Mixed properties}
\label{\detokenize{overview/style:mixed-properties}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{radius} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Set the radius of the background. 0: no radius, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_RADIUS\_CIRCLE}}: maximal radius.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{clip\_corner} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bool}}): \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{true}}: enable to clip the overflowed content on the rounded (radius \textgreater{} 0) corners.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{size} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Size of internal elements of the widgets. See the documentation of the widgets if this property is used or not.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{transform\_width}  (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Make the object wider on both sides with this value.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{transform\_height}  (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}) Make the object higher on both sides with this value.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{opa\_scale} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Inherited. Scale down all opacity values of the object by this factor. As it's inherited the children objects will be affected too.

\end{itemize}


\subsubsection{Padding and margin properties}
\label{\detokenize{overview/style:padding-and-margin-properties}}
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Padding} sets the space on the inner sides of the edges. It means "I don't want my children too close to my sides, so keep this space".\sphinxstyleemphasis{Padding inner} set the "gap" between the children.
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Margin} sets the space on the outer side of the edges. It means "I want this space around me".

These properties are typically used by {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/cont::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Container}}}} object if \sphinxhref{/widgets/cont\#layout}{layout} or
\sphinxhref{/widgets/cont\#auto-fit}{auto fit} is enabled.
However other widgets also use them to set spacing. See the documentation of the widgets for the details.
 - \sphinxstylestrong{pad\_top} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Set the padding on the top.
 - \sphinxstylestrong{pad\_bottom} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Set the padding on the bottom.
 - \sphinxstylestrong{pad\_left} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Set the padding on the left.
 - \sphinxstylestrong{pad\_right} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Set the padding on the right.
 - \sphinxstylestrong{pad\_inner} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Set the padding inside the object between children.
 - \sphinxstylestrong{margin\_top} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Set the margin on the top.
 - \sphinxstylestrong{margin\_bottom} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Set the margin on the bottom.
 - \sphinxstylestrong{margin\_left} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Set the margin on the left.
 - \sphinxstylestrong{margin\_right} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Set the margin on the right.


\subsubsection{Background properties}
\label{\detokenize{overview/style:background-properties}}
The background is a simple rectangle which can have gradient and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{radius}} rounding.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{bg\_color} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color\_t}}) Specifies the color of the background. Default value: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_WHITE}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{bg\_opa} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_opa\_t}}) Specifies opacity of the background. Default value: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_OPA\_TRANSP}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{bg\_grad\_color} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color\_t}}) Specifies the color of the background's gradient. The color on the right or bottom is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bg\_grad\_dir != LV\_GRAD\_DIR\_NONE}}. Default value: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_WHITE}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{bg\_main\_stop} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{uint8\_t}}): Specifies where should the gradient start. 0: at left/top most position, 255: at right/bottom most position.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{bg\_grad\_stop} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{uint8\_t}}): Specifies where should the gradient start. 0: at left/top most position, 255: at right/bottom most position. Default value: 255.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{bg\_grad\_dir} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_grad\_dir\_t}}) Specifies the direction of the gradient. Can be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_GRAD\_DIR\_NONE/HOR/VER}}. Default value: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_GRAD\_DIR\_NONE}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{bg\_blend\_mode} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_blend\_mode\_t}}): Set the blend mode the background. Can be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BLEND\_MODE\_NORMAL/ADDITIVE/SUBTRACTIVE}}). Default value: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BLEND\_MODE\_NORMAL}}.

\end{itemize}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\PYG{c+cm}{/**}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * Using the background style properties}
\PYG{c+cm}{ */}

\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{k}{static} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{style}\PYG{p}{;}

    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}radius}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{style}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}DEFAULT}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

    \PYG{c+cm}{/*Make a gradient*/}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}bg\PYGZus{}opa}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{style}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}DEFAULT}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}OPA\PYGZus{}COVER}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}bg\PYGZus{}color}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{style}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}DEFAULT}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}COLOR\PYGZus{}SILVER}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}bg\PYGZus{}grad\PYGZus{}color}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{style}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}DEFAULT}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}COLOR\PYGZus{}BLUE}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}bg\PYGZus{}grad\PYGZus{}dir}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{style}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}DEFAULT}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}GRAD\PYGZus{}DIR\PYGZus{}VER}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}bg\PYGZus{}grad\PYGZus{}stop}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{style}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}DEFAULT}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{192}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{obj} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}scr\PYGZus{}act}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\subsubsection{Border properties}
\label{\detokenize{overview/style:border-properties}}
The border in drawn on to of the \sphinxstyleemphasis{background}. It has \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{radius}} rounding.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{border\_color} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color\_t}}) Specifies the color of the border.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{border\_opa} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_opa\_t}}) Specifies opacity of the border.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{border\_width} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Set the width of the border.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{border\_side} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_border\_side\_t}}) Specifies which sides of the border to draw. Can be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BORDER\_SIDE\_NONE/LEFT/RIGHT/TOP/BOTTOM/FULL}}. ORed values are also possible. Default value: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BORDER\_SIDE\_FULL}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{border\_post} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bool}}): If \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{true}} the border will be drawn all children has been drawn.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{border\_blend\_mode} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_blend\_mode\_t}}): Set the blend mode of the border. Can be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BLEND\_MODE\_NORMAL/ADDITIVE/SUBTRACTIVE}}). Default value: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BLEND\_MODE\_NORMAL}}.

\end{itemize}

    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}add\PYGZus{}style}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{obj}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}OBJ\PYGZus{}PART\PYGZus{}MAIN}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{style}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\subsubsection{Outline properties}
\label{\detokenize{overview/style:outline-properties}}
The outline is similar to \sphinxstyleemphasis{border} but is drawn outside of the object.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{outline\_color} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color\_t}}) Specifies the color of the outline.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{outline\_opa} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_opa\_t}}) Specifies opacity of the outline.

\item {}

\subsubsection{Shadow properties}
\label{\detokenize{overview/style:shadow-properties}}
The shadow is a blurred area under the object.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{shadow\_color} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color\_t}}) Specifies the color of the shadow.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{shadow\_opa} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_opa\_t}}) Specifies opacity of the shadow.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{shadow\_width} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Set the width (blur size) of the outline.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{shadow\_ofs\_x} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Set the an X offset for the shadow.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{shadow\_ofs\_y} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Set the an Y offset for the shadow.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{shadow\_spread} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): ake the shadow larger than the background in every direction by this value.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{shadow\_blend\_mode} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_blend\_mode\_t}}): Set the blend mode of the shadow. Can be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BLEND\_MODE\_NORMAL/ADDITIVE/SUBTRACTIVE}}). Default value: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BLEND\_MODE\_NORMAL}}.

\end{itemize}

\subsubsection{Pattern properties}
\label{\detokenize{overview/style:pattern-properties}}
The pattern is an image (or symbol) drawn in the middle of the background or repeated to fill the whole background.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{pattern\_image} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{const void *}}): Pointer to an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_dsc\_t}} variable, a path to an image file or a symbol.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{pattern\_opa} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_opa\_t}}): Specifies opacity of the pattern.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{pattern\_recolor} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color\_t}}): Mix this color to the pattern image. In case of symbols (texts) it will be the text color.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{pattern\_recolor\_opa} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_opa\_t}}): Intensity of recoloring. Default value: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_OPA\_TRANSP}} (no recoloring).

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{pattern\_repeat} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bool}}): \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{true}}: the pattern will be repeated as a mosaic. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{false}}: place the pattern in the middle of the background.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{pattern\_blend\_mode} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_blend\_mode\_t}}): Set the blend mode of the pattern. Can be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BLEND\_MODE\_NORMAL/ADDITIVE/SUBTRACTIVE}}). Default value: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BLEND\_MODE\_NORMAL}}.

\end{itemize}

\subsubsection{Value properties}
\label{\detokenize{overview/style:value-properties}}
Value is an arbitrary text drawn to the background. It can be a lightweighted replacement of creating label objects.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{value\_str} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{const char *}}): Pointer to text to display. Only the pointer is saved.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{value\_color} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color\_t}}): Color of the text.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{value\_opa} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_opa\_t}}): Opacity of the text.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{value\_font} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{const lv\_font\_t *}}): Pointer to font of the text.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{value\_letter\_space} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Letter space of the text.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{value\_line\_space} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Line space of the text.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{value\_align} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_align\_t}}): Alignment of the text. Can be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_ALIGN\_...}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{value\_ofs\_x} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): X offset from the original position of the alignment.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{value\_ofs\_y} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Y offset from the original position of the alignment.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{value\_blend\_mode} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_blend\_mode\_t}}): Set the blend mode of the text. Can be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BLEND\_MODE\_NORMAL/ADDITIVE/SUBTRACTIVE}}). Default value: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BLEND\_MODE\_NORMAL}}.

\end{itemize}

\subsubsection{Text properties}
\label{\detokenize{overview/style:text-properties}}
Properties for textual object.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{text\_color} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color\_t}}): Color of the text.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{text\_opa} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_opa\_t}}): Opacity of the text.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{text\_font} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{const lv\_font\_t *}}): Pointer to font of the text.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{text\_letter\_space} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Letter space of the text.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{text\_line\_space} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Line space of the text.

\sphinxstylestrong{text\_sel\_color} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color\_t}}): Set background color of text selection.

\subsubsection{Line properties}
\label{\detokenize{overview/style:line-properties}}
Properties of lines.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{line\_color} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color\_t}}): Color of the line.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{line\_opa} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_opa\_t}}): Opacity of the line.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{line\_width} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Width of the line.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{line\_dash\_width} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Width of dash. Dashing is drawn only for horizontal or vertical lines. 0: disable dash.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{line\_dash\_gap} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Gap between two dash line. Dashing is drawn only for horizontal or vertical lines. 0: disable dash.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{line\_rounded} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bool}}): \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{true}}: draw rounded line endings.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{line\_blend\_mode} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_blend\_mode\_t}}): Set the blend mode of the line. Can be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BLEND\_MODE\_NORMAL/ADDITIVE/SUBTRACTIVE}}). Default value: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BLEND\_MODE\_NORMAL}}.

\end{itemize}

\subsubsection{Transition properties}
\label{\detokenize{overview/style:transition-properties}}
Properties to describe state change animations.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{transition\_time} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Time of the transition.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{transition\_delay} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Delay before the transition.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{transition\_1} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{property name}}): A property on which transition should be applied. Use the property name with upper case with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_STYLE\_}} prefix, e.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_STYLE\_BG\_COLOR}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{transition\_2} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{property name}}): Same as \sphinxstyleemphasis{transition\_1} just for an other property.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{transition\_3} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{property name}}): Same as \sphinxstyleemphasis{transition\_1} just for an other property.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{transition\_4} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{property name}}): Same as \sphinxstyleemphasis{transition\_1} just for an other property.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{transition\_5} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{property name}}): Same as \sphinxstyleemphasis{transition\_1} just for an other property.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{transition\_6} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{property name}}): Same as \sphinxstyleemphasis{transition\_1} just for an other property.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{transition\_path} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_anim\_path\_t}}): An animation path for the transition. (Needs to be static or global variable because only its pointer is saved).

\end{itemize}

\subsubsection{Scale properties}
\label{\detokenize{overview/style:scale-properties}}
Auxiliary properties for scale-like elements. Scales have a normal and end region.
As the name implies the end region is the end of the scale where can be critical values or inactive values. The normal region is before the end region.
Both regions could have different properties.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{scale\_grad\_color} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color\_t}}):  In normal region make gradient to this color on the scale lines.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{scale\_end\_color} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color\_t}}):  Color of the scale lines in the end region.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{scale\_width} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Width of the scale. Default value: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_DPI / 8}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{scale\_border\_width} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Width of a border drawn on the outer side of the scale in the normal region.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{scale\_end\_border\_width} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Width of a border drawn on the outer side of the scale in the end region.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{scale\_end\_line\_width} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_style\_int\_t}}): Width of a scale lines in the end region.

\end{itemize}

It the documentation of the widgets you will see sentences like "The widget use the typical background properties". The "typical background" properties are:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Background

\item {} 
Border

\item {} 
Outline

\item {} 
Shadow

\item {} 
Pattern

\item {} 
Value

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Themes}
\label{\detokenize{overview/style:themes}}
Themes are a collection of styles. There is always an active theme whose styles are automatically applied when an object is created.
It gives a default appearance to UI which can be modified by adding further styles.

The default theme is set in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_conf.h}} with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_THEME\_...}} defines. Every theme has the following properties
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
primary color

\item {} 
secondary color

\item {} 
small font

\item {} 
normal font

\item {} 
subtitle font

\item {} 
title font

\item {} 
flags (specific to the given theme)

\end{itemize}

It up to the theme how to use these properties.

There are 3 built-in themes:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
empty: no default styles are added

\item {} 
material: an impressive, modern theme - mono: simple black and white theme for monochrome displays

\item {} 
template: a very simple theme which can be copied to create a custom theme

\end{itemize}
