\section{Input devices}
\label{\detokenize{overview/indev:input-devices}}\label{\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}}
An input device usually means:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Pointer-like input device like touchpad or mouse

\item {} 
Keypads like a normal keyboard or simple numeric keypad

\item {} 
Encoders with left/right turn and push options

\item {} 
External hardware buttons which are assigned to specific points on the screen

\end{itemize}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{important}{Important:}
Before reading further, please read the {[}Porting{]}(/porting/indev) section of Input devices
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\subsection{Pointers}
\label{\detokenize{overview/indev:pointers}}
Pointer input devices can have a cursor. (typically for mouses)

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{mouse\PYGZus{}indev} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}register}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{indev\PYGZus{}drv}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}IMG\PYGZus{}DECLARE}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{mouse\PYGZus{}cursor\PYGZus{}icon}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}                          \PYG{c+cm}{/*Declare the image file.*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{cursor\PYGZus{}obj} \PYG{o}{=}  \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}scr\PYGZus{}act}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{c+cm}{/*Create an image object for the cursor */}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}src}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{cursor\PYGZus{}obj}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{mouse\PYGZus{}cursor\PYGZus{}icon}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}             \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set the image source*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}indev\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}cursor}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{mouse\PYGZus{}indev}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{cursor\PYGZus{}obj}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}               \PYG{c+cm}{/*Connect the image  object to the driver*/}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Note that the cursor object should have \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_click(cursor\_obj, false)}}.
For images, \sphinxstyleemphasis{clicking} is disabled by default.


\subsection{Keypad and encoder}
\label{\detokenize{overview/indev:keypad-and-encoder}}
You can fully control the user interface without touchpad or mouse using a keypad or encoder(s). It works similar to the \sphinxstyleemphasis{TAB} key on the PC to select the element in an application or a web page.


\subsubsection{Groups}
\label{\detokenize{overview/indev:groups}}
The objects, you want to control with keypad or encoder, needs to be added to a \sphinxstyleemphasis{Group}.
In every group, there is exactly one focused object which receives the pressed keys or the encoder actions.
For example, if a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/textarea::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Text area}}}} is focused and you press some letter on a keyboard, the keys will be sent and inserted into the text area.
Similarly, if a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/slider::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Slider}}}} is focused and you press the left or right arrows, the slider's value will be changed.

You need to associate an input device with a group. An input device can send the keys to only one group but, a group can receive data from more than one input device too.

To create a group use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_group\_t * g = lv\_group\_create()}} and to add an object to the group use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_group\_add\_obj(g, obj)}}.

The associate a group with an input device use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_indev\_set\_group(indev, g)}}, where \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{indev}} is the return value of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_indev\_drv\_register()}}


\paragraph{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{overview/indev:keys}}
There are some predefined keys which have special meaning:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_NEXT} Focus on the next object

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_PREV} Focus on the previous object

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_ENTER} Triggers \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_EVENT\_PRESSED/CLICKED/LONG\_PRESSED}} etc. events

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_UP} Increase value or move upwards

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_DOWN} Decrease value or move downwards

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_RIGHT} Increase value or move the the right

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_LEFT} Decrease value or move the the left

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_ESC}  Close or exit (E.g. close a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/dropdown::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Drop down list}}}})

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_DEL}  Delete (E.g. a character on the right in a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/textarea::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Text area}}}})

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_BACKSPACE} Delete a character on the left (E.g. in a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/textarea::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Text area}}}})

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_HOME} Go to the beginning/top (E.g. in a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/textarea::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Text area}}}})

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_END} Go to the end (E.g. in a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/textarea::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Text area}}}}))

\end{itemize}

The most important special keys are \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_KEY\_NEXT/PREV}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_KEY\_ENTER}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_KEY\_UP/DOWN/LEFT/RIGHT}}.
In your \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{read\_cb}} function, you should translate some of your keys to these special keys to navigate in the group and interact with the selected object.

Usually, it's enough to use only \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_KEY\_LEFT/RIGHT}} because most of the objects can be fully controlled with them.

With an encoder, you should use only \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_KEY\_LEFT}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_KEY\_RIGHT}}, and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_KEY\_ENTER}}.


\paragraph{Edit and navigate mode}
\label{\detokenize{overview/indev:edit-and-navigate-mode}}
Since keypad has plenty of keys, it's easy to navigate between the objects and edit them using the keypad. But, the encoders have a limited number of "keys" hence, difficult to navigate using the default options. \sphinxstyleemphasis{Navigate} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{Edit} are created to avoid this problem with the encoders.

In \sphinxstyleemphasis{Navigate} mode, the encoders \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_KEY\_LEFT/RIGHT}} is translated to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_KEY\_NEXT/PREV}}. Therefore the next or previous object will be selected by turning the encoder.
Pressing \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_KEY\_ENTER}} will change to \sphinxstyleemphasis{Edit} mode.

In \sphinxstyleemphasis{Edit} mode, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_KEY\_NEXT/PREV}} is usually used to edit the object.
Depending on the object's type, a short or long press of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_KEY\_ENTER}} changes back to \sphinxstyleemphasis{Navigate} mode.
Usually, an object which can not be pressed (like a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/slider::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Slider}}}}) leaves \sphinxstyleemphasis{Edit} mode on short click. But with object where short click has meaning (e.g. {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/btn::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Button}}}}), long press is required.


\subsubsection{Styling}
\label{\detokenize{overview/indev:styling}}
If an object is focused either by clicking it via touchpad, or focused via an encoder or keypad it goes to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_STATE\_FOCUSED}}. Hence focused styles will be applied on it.

If te object goes to edit mode it goes to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_STATE\_FOCUSED \textbar{} LV\_STATE\_EDITED}} state so these style properties will be shown.

For a moew detaild description read the \sphinxhref{https://docs.lvgl.io/v7/en/html/overview/style.html}{Style} section.

\section{Displays}
\label{\detokenize{overview/display:displays}}\label{\detokenize{overview/display::doc}}
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{important}{Important:}
The basic concept of \sphinxstyleemphasis{display} in LVGL is explained in the {[}Porting{]}(/porting/display) section. So before reading further, please read the {[}Porting{]}(/porting/display) section first.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

In LVGL, you can have multiple displays, each with their own driver and objects.

Creating more displays is easy: just initialize more display buffers and register another driver for every display.
When you create the UI, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_set\_default(disp)}} to tell the library which display to create objects on.

Why would you want multi-display support? Here are some examples:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Have a "normal" TFT display with local UI and create "virtual" screens on VNC on demand. (You need to add your VNC driver).

\item {} 
Have a large TFT display and a small monochrome display.

\item {} 
Have some smaller and simple displays in a large instrument or technology.

\item {} 
Have two large TFT displays: one for a customer and one for the shop assistant.

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Using only one display}
\label{\detokenize{overview/display:using-only-one-display}}
Using more displays can be useful, but in most cases, it's not required. Therefore, the whole concept of multi-display is completely hidden if you register only one display.
By default, the lastly created (the only one) display is used as default.

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_scr\_act()}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_scr\_load(scr)}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_layer\_top()}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_layer\_sys()}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_HOR\_RES}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_VER\_RES}} are always applied on the lastly created (default) screen.
If you pass \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} as \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{disp}} parameter to display related function, usually the default display will be used.
E.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_trig\_activity(NULL)}} will trigger a user activity on the default screen. (See below in {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/display:Inactivity}]{\emph{Inactivity}}}).


\subsection{Mirror display}
\label{\detokenize{overview/display:mirror-display}}
To mirror the image of the display to another display, you don't need to use the multi-display support. Just transfer the buffer received in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{drv.flush\_cb}} to another display too.


\subsection{Split image}
\label{\detokenize{overview/display:split-image}}
You can create a larger display from smaller ones. You can create it as below:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
Set the resolution of the displays to the large display's resolution.

\item {} 
In \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{drv.flush\_cb}}, truncate and modify the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{area}} parameter for each display.

\item {} 
Send the buffer's content to each display with the truncated area.

\end{enumerate}


\subsection{Screens}
\label{\detokenize{overview/display:screens}}
Every display has each set of \sphinxhref{overview/object\#screen-the-most-basic-parent}{Screens} and the object on the screens.

Be sure not to confuse displays and screens:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Displays} are the physical hardware drawing the pixels.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Screens} are the high-level root objects associated with a particular display. One display can have multiple screens associated with it, but not vice versa.

\end{itemize}

Screens can be considered the highest level containers which have no parent.
The screen's size is always equal to its display and size their position is (0;0). Therefore, the screens coordinates can't be changed, i.e. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_pos()}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_size()}} or similar functions can't be used on screens.

A screen can be created from any object type but, the two most typical types are the {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/obj::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Base object}}}} and the {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/img::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Image}}}} (to create a wallpaper).

To create a screen, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_t * scr = lv\_\textless{}type\textgreater{}\_create(NULL, copy)}}. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{copy}} can be an other screen to copy it.

To load a screen, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_scr\_load(scr)}}. To get the active screen, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_scr\_act()}}. These functions works on the default display. If you want to to specify which display to work on, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_get\_scr\_act(disp)}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_load\_scr(disp, scr)}}.

Screens can be deleted with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_del(scr)}}, but ensure that you do not delete the currently loaded screen.


\subsubsection{Opaque screen}
\label{\detokenize{overview/display:opaque-screen}}
Usually, the opacity of the screen is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_OPA\_COVER}} to provide a solid background for its children.

However, in some special cases, you might want a transparent screen. For example, if you have a video player that renders video frames on a lower layer, you want to create an OSD menu on the upper layer (over the video) using LVGL.

To do this, the screen should have a style that sets \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{body.opa}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{image.opa}} to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_OPA\_TRANSP}} (or another non-opaque value) to make the screen opaque.

Also, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_SCREEN\_TRANSP}} needs to be enabled. Please note that it only works with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_DEPTH = 32}}.

The Alpha channel of 32-bit colors will be 0 where there are no objects and will be 255 where there are solid objects.


\subsection{Features of displays}
\label{\detokenize{overview/display:features-of-displays}}

\subsubsection{Inactivity}
\label{\detokenize{overview/display:inactivity}}
The user's inactivity is measured on each display. Every use of an {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Input device}}}} (if \sphinxhref{/porting/indev\#other-features}{associated with the display}) counts as an activity.
To get time elapsed since the last activity, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_get\_inactive\_time(disp)}}. If \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} is passed, the overall smallest inactivity time will be returned from all displays (\sphinxstylestrong{not the default display}).

You can manually trigger an activity using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_trig\_activity(disp)}}. If \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{disp}} is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}}, the default screen will be used (\sphinxstylestrong{and not all displays}).


\subsection{Colors}
\label{\detokenize{overview/display:colors}}
The color module handles all color-related functions like changing color depth, creating colors from hex code, converting between color depths, mixing colors, etc.

The following variable types are defined by the color module:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_color1\_t} Store monochrome color. For compatibility, it also has R, G, B fields but they are always the same value (1 byte)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_color8\_t} A structure to store R (3 bit),G (3 bit),B (2 bit) components for 8-bit colors (1 byte)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_color16\_t} A structure to store R (5 bit),G (6 bit),B (5 bit) components for 16-bit colors (2 byte)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_color32\_t} A structure to store R (8 bit),G (8 bit), B (8 bit) components for 24-bit colors (4 byte)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_color\_t} Equal to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color1/8/16/24\_t}} according to color depth settings

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_color\_int\_t} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{uint8\_t}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{uint16\_t}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{uint32\_t}} according to color depth setting. Used to build color arrays from plain numbers.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_opa\_t} A simple \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{uint8\_}}t type to describe opacity.

\end{itemize}

The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color\_t}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color1\_t}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color8\_t}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color16\_t}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color32\_t}} types have got four fields:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{ch.red} red channel

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{ch.green} green channel

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{ch.blue} blue channel

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{full} red + green + blue as one number

\end{itemize}

You can set the current color depth in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}, by setting the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_DEPTH}} define to 1 (monochrome), 8, 16 or 32.


\subsubsection{Convert color}
\label{\detokenize{overview/display:convert-color}}
You can convert a color from the current color depth to another. The converter functions return with a number, so you have to use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{full}} field:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{c}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{c}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{red}   \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mh}{0x38}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{c}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{green} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mh}{0x70}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{c}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{blue}  \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mh}{0xCC}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color1\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{c1}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{c1}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{full} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color\PYGZus{}to1}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{c}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}	\PYG{c+cm}{/*Return 1 for light colors, 0 for dark colors*/}

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color8\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{c8}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{c8}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{full} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color\PYGZus{}to8}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{c}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}	\PYG{c+cm}{/*Give a 8 bit number with the converted color*/}

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color16\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{c16}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{c16}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{full} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color\PYGZus{}to16}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{c}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{c+cm}{/*Give a 16 bit number with the converted color*/}

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color32\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{c24}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{c32}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{full} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}color\PYGZus{}to32}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{c}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}	\PYG{c+cm}{/*Give a 32 bit number with the converted color*/}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsubsection{Swap 16 colors}
\label{\detokenize{overview/display:swap-16-colors}}
You may set \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_16\_SWAP}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h} to swap the bytes of \sphinxstyleemphasis{RGB565} colors. It's useful if you send the 16-bit colors via a byte-oriented interface like SPI.

As 16-bit numbers are stored in Little Endian format (lower byte on the lower address), the interface will send the lower byte first. However, displays usually need the higher byte first. A mismatch in the byte order will result in highly distorted colors.


\subsubsection{Create and mix colors}
\label{\detokenize{overview/display:create-and-mix-colors}}
You can create colors with the current color depth using the LV\_COLOR\_MAKE macro. It takes 3 arguments (red, green, blue) as 8-bit numbers.
For example to create light red color: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{my\_color = COLOR\_MAKE(0xFF,0x80,0x80)}}.

Colors can be created from HEX codes too: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{my\_color = lv\_color\_hex(0x288ACF)}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{my\_color = lv\_folro\_hex3(0x28C)}}.

Mixing two colors is possible with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mixed\_color = lv\_color\_mix(color1, color2, ratio)}}. Ration can be 0..255. 0 results fully color2, 255 result fully color1.

Colors can be created with from HSV space too using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color\_hsv\_to\_rgb(hue, saturation, value)}} . \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{hue}} should be in 0..360 range, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{saturation}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{value}} in 0..100 range.


\subsubsection{Opacity}
\label{\detokenize{overview/display:opacity}}
To describe opacity the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_opa\_t}} type is created as a wrapper to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{uint8\_t}}. Some defines are also introduced:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_OPA\_TRANSP} Value: 0, means the opacity makes the color completely transparent

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_OPA\_10} Value: 25, means the color covers only a little

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_OPA\_20 ... OPA\_80} come logically

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_OPA\_90} Value: 229, means the color near completely covers

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_OPA\_COVER} Value: 255, means the color completely covers

\end{itemize}

You can also use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_OPA\_*}} defines in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color\_mix()}} as a \sphinxstyleemphasis{ratio}.

\section{Fonts}
\label{\detokenize{overview/font:fonts}}\label{\detokenize{overview/font::doc}}
In LVGL fonts are collections of bitmaps and other information required to render the images of the letters (glyph).
A font is stored in a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_font\_t}} variable and can be set in style's \sphinxstyleemphasis{text\_font} field. For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}text\PYGZus{}font}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}style}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}DEFAULT}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}font\PYGZus{}montserrat\PYGZus{}28}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set a larger font*/}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

The fonts have a \sphinxstylestrong{bpp (bits per pixel)} property. It shows how many bits are used to describe a pixel in the font. The value stored for a pixel determines the pixel's opacity.
This way, with higher \sphinxstyleemphasis{bpp}, the edges of the letter can be smoother. The possible \sphinxstyleemphasis{bpp} values are 1, 2, 4 and 8 (higher value means better quality).

The \sphinxstyleemphasis{bpp} also affects the required memory size to store the font. For example, \sphinxstyleemphasis{bpp = 4} makes the font nearly 4 times greater compared to \sphinxstyleemphasis{bpp = 1}.


\subsection{Unicode support}
\label{\detokenize{overview/font:unicode-support}}
LVGL supports \sphinxstylestrong{UTF-8} encoded Unicode characters.
Your editor needs to be configureed to save your code/text as UTF-8 (usually this the default) and be sure that, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_TXT\_ENC}} is set to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_TXT\_ENC\_UTF8}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}. (This is the default value)

To test it try

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{label1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}label\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}scr\PYGZus{}act}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}label\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}text}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{label1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}SYMBOL\PYGZus{}OK}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

If all works well, a \(\checkmark\) character should be displayed.

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FONT\_MONTSERRAT\_24}} 24 px ASCII + built-in symbol

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FONT\_MONTSERRAT\_26}} 26 px ASCII + built-in symbol

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FONT\_MONTSERRAT\_30}} 30 px ASCII + built-in symbol

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FONT\_MONTSERRAT\_48}} 48 px ASCII + built-in symbol

\item {}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FONT\_UNSCII\_8}} 8 px pixel perfect font

\end{itemize}

The built-in fonts are \sphinxstylestrong{global variables} with names like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_font\_montserrat\_16}} for 16 px hight font. To use them in a style, just add a pointer to a font variable like shown above.

The built-in fonts have \sphinxstyleemphasis{bpp = 4}, contains the ASCII characters and uses the \sphinxhref{https://fonts.google.com/specimen/Montserrat}{Montserrat} font.

In addition to the ASCII range, the following symbols are also added to the built-in fonts from the \sphinxhref{https://fontawesome.com/}{FontAwesome} font.

\sphinxincludegraphics{{symbols}.png}

The symbols can be used as:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}label\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}text}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}label}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}SYMBOL\PYGZus{}OK}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Or with together with strings:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}label\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}text}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}label}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}SYMBOL\PYGZus{}OK} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Apply}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Or more symbols together:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}label\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}text}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}label}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}SYMBOL\PYGZus{}OK} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}SYMBOL\PYGZus{}WIFI} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}SYMBOL\PYGZus{}PLAY}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Special features}
\label{\detokenize{overview/font:special-features}}

\subsubsection{Bidirectional support}
\label{\detokenize{overview/font:bidirectional-support}}
Most of the languages use Left-to-Right (LTR for short) writing direction, however some languages (such as Hebrew, Persian or Arabic) uses Right-to-Left (RTL for short) direction.

LVGL not only supports RTL texts but supports mixed (a.k.a. bidirectional, BiDi) text rendering too. Some examples:

\sphinxincludegraphics{{bidi}.png}

The BiDi support can be enabled by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_USE\_BIDI}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}

All texts have a base direction (LTR or RTL) which determines some rendering rules and the default alignment of the text (Left or Right).
However, in LVGL, base direction is applied not only for labels. It's a general property which can be set for every object.
If unset then it will be inherited from the parent.
So it's enough to set the base direction of the screen and every object will inherit it.

The default base direction of screen can be set by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BIDI\_BASE\_DIR\_DEF}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h} and other objects inherit the base direction from their parent.

To set an object's base direction use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_base\_dir(obj, base\_dir)}}.  The possible base direction are:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BIDI\_DIR\_LTR}}: Left to Right base direction

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BIDI\_DIR\_RTL}}: Right to Left base direction

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BIDI\_DIR\_AUTO}}: Auto detect base direction

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BIDI\_DIR\_INHERIT}}: Inherit the base direction from the parent (default for non-screen objects)

\end{itemize}

This list summarizes the effect of RTL base direction on objects:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Create objects by default on the right

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_tabview}}: displays tabs from right to left

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_checkbox}}: Show the box on the right

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btnmatrix}}: Show buttons from right to left

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_list}}: Show the icon on the right

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_dropdown}}: Align the options to the right

\item {} 
The texts in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_table}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btnmatrix}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_keyboard}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_tabview}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_dropdown}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_roller}} are "BiDi processed" to be displayed correctly

\end{itemize}


\subsubsection{Arabic and Persian support}
\label{\detokenize{overview/font:arabic-and-persian-support}}
There are some special rules to display Arabic and Persian characters: the \sphinxstyleemphasis{form} of the character depends on their position in the text.
A different form of the same letter needs to be used if it isolated, start, middle or end position. Besides these some conjunction rules also should be taken into account.

LVGL supports to apply these rules if \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_USE\_ARABIC\_PERSIAN\_CHARS}} is enabled.

However, there some limitations:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Only displaying texts is supported (e.g. on labels), text inputs (e.g. text area) doesn't support this feature

\item {} 
Static text (i.e. const) are not processed. E.g. texts set by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_text()}} will "Arabic processed" but \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_lable\_set\_text\_static()}} won't.

\item {} 
Text get functions (e.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_get\_text()}}) will return the processed text.

\end{itemize}


\subsubsection{Subpixel rendering}
\label{\detokenize{overview/font:subpixel-rendering}}
Subpixel rendering means to triple the horizontal resolution by rendering on Red, Green and Blue channel instead of pixel level. It takes advantage of the position of physical color channels of each pixel.
It results in higher quality letter anti-aliasing. Lear more \sphinxhref{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subpixel\_rendering}{here}.

Subpixel rendering requires to generate the fonts with special settings:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
In the online converter tick the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Subpixel}} box

\item {} 
In the command line tool use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{-{-}lcd}} flag. Note that the generated font needs about 3 times more memory.

\end{itemize}

Subpixel rendering works only if the color channels of the pixels have a horizontal layout. That is the R, G, B channels are next each other and not above each other.
The order of color channels also needs to match with the library settings. By default the LVGL assumes \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{RGB}} order, however it can be swapped by setting \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_SUBPX\_BGR  1}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}.


\subsubsection{Compress fonts}
\label{\detokenize{overview/font:compress-fonts}}
The bitmaps of the fonts can be compressed by
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
ticking the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Compressed}} check box in the online converter

\item {} 
not passing \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{-{-}no-compress}} flag to the offline converter (applies compression by default)

\end{itemize}

The compression is more effective with larger fonts and higher bpp. However, it's about 30\% slower to render the compressed fonts.
Therefore it's recommended to compress only the largest fonts of user interface, because
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
they need the most memory

\item {} 
they can be compressed better

\item {} 
and probably they are used less frequently then the medium sized fonts. (so performance cost is smaller)

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Add new font}
\label{\detokenize{overview/font:add-new-font}}
There are several ways to add a new font to your project:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
The simplest method is to use the \sphinxhref{https://lvgl.io/tools/fontconverter}{Online font converter}. Just set the parameters, click the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Convert} button, copy the font to your project and use it. \sphinxstylestrong{Be sure to carefully read the steps provided on that site or you will get an error while converting.}

\item {} 
Use the \sphinxhref{https://github.com/lvgl/lv\_font\_conv}{Offline font converter}. (Requires Node.js to be installed)

\item {} 
If you want to create something like the built-in fonts (Roboto font and symbols) but in different size and/or ranges, you can use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{built\_in\_font\_gen.py}} script in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lvgl/scripts/built\_in\_font}} folder.
(It requires Python and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_font\_conv}} to be installed)

\end{enumerate}

To declare the font in a file, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FONT\_DECLARE(my\_font\_name)}}.

To make the fonts globally available (like the builtin fonts), add them to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FONT\_CUSTOM\_DECLARE}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}.


\subsection{Add new symbols}
\label{\detokenize{overview/font:add-new-symbols}}
The built-in symbols are created from \sphinxhref{https://fontawesome.com/}{FontAwesome} font.
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
Search symbol on \sphinxurl{https://fontawesome.com}. For example the \sphinxhref{https://fontawesome.com/icons/usb?style=brands}{USB symbol}. Copy it's Unicode ID which is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{0xf287}} in this case.

\item {} 
Open the \sphinxhref{https://lvgl.io/tools/fontconverter}{Online font converter}. Add Add \sphinxhref{https://lvgl.io/assets/others/FontAwesome5-Solid+Brands+Regular.woff}{FontAwesome.woff}. .

\item {} 
Set the parameters such as Name, Size, BPP. You'll use this name to declare and use the font in your code.

\item {} 
Add the Unicode ID of the symbol to the range field. E.g.\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ 0xf287}} for the USB symbol. More symbols can be enumerated with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{,}}.

\item {} 
Convert the font and copy it to your project. Make sure to compile the .c file of your font.

\item {} 
Declare the font using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{extern lv\_font\_t my\_font\_name;}} or simply \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FONT\_DECLARE(my\_font\_name);}}.

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxstylestrong{Using the symbol}
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
Convert the Unicode value to UTF8. You can do it e.g on \sphinxhref{http://www.ltg.ed.ac.uk/\%7Erichard/utf-8.cgi?input=f287\&mode=hex}{this site}. For \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{0xf287}} the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Hex UTF-8 bytes} are \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{EF 8A 87}}.

\item {} 
Create a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{define}} from the UTF8 values: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\#define MY\_USB\_SYMBOL "\textbackslash{}xEF\textbackslash{}x8A\textbackslash{}x87"}}

\item {} 
Create a label and set the text. Eg. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_text(label, MY\_USB\_SYMBOL)}}

\end{enumerate}

Note - \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_text(label, MY\_USB\_SYMBOL)}} searches for this symbol in the font defined in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.text.font}} properties. To use the symbol you may need to change it. Eg \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ style.text.font = my\_font\_name}}


\subsection{Add a new font engine}
\label{\detokenize{overview/font:add-a-new-font-engine}}
LVGL's font interface is designed to be very flexible.
You don't need to use LVGL's internal font engine but, you can add your own.
For example, use \sphinxhref{https://www.freetype.org/}{FreeType} to real-time render glyphs from TTF fonts or use an external flash to store the font's bitmap and read them when the library needs them.

A raedy to use FreeType can be found in \sphinxhref{https://github.com/lvgl/lv\_lib\_freetype}{lv\_freetype} repository.

To do this a custom \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_font\_t}} variable needs to be created:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+cm}{/*Describe the properties of a font*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}font\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}font}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}font}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}glyph\PYGZus{}dsc} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}get\PYGZus{}glyph\PYGZus{}dsc\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}        \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set a callback to get info about gylphs*/}
\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}font}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}glyph\PYGZus{}bitmap} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}get\PYGZus{}glyph\PYGZus{}bitmap\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set a callback to get bitmap of a glyp*/}
\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}font}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{line\PYGZus{}height} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{height}\PYG{p}{;}                       \PYG{c+cm}{/*The real line height where any text fits*/}
\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}font}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{base\PYGZus{}line} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{base\PYGZus{}line}\PYG{p}{;}                      \PYG{c+cm}{/*Base line measured from the top of line\PYGZus{}height*/}
\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}font}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{dsc} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{something\PYGZus{}required}\PYG{p}{;}                   \PYG{c+cm}{/*Store any implementation specific data here*/}
\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}font}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{user\PYGZus{}data} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{user\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{;}                      \PYG{c+cm}{/*Optionally some extra user data*/}

\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}

\PYG{c+cm}{/* Get info about glyph of {}`unicode\PYGZus{}letter{}` in {}`font{}` font.}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * Store the result in {}`dsc\PYGZus{}out{}`.}
\PYG{c+cm}{ * The next letter ({}`unicode\PYGZus{}letter\PYGZus{}next{}`) might be used to calculate the width required by this glyph (kerning)}
\PYG{c+cm}{ */}
\PYG{k+kt}{bool} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}get\PYGZus{}glyph\PYGZus{}dsc\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{k}{const} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}font\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{font}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}font\PYGZus{}glyph\PYGZus{}dsc\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{dsc\PYGZus{}out}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k+kt}{uint32\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{unicode\PYGZus{}letter}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k+kt}{uint32\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{unicode\PYGZus{}letter\PYGZus{}next}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{c+cm}{/*Your code here*/}

    \PYG{c+cm}{/* Store the result.}
\PYG{c+cm}{     * For example ...}
\PYG{c+cm}{     */}
    \PYG{n}{dsc\PYGZus{}out}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{adv\PYGZus{}w} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{12}\PYG{p}{;}        \PYG{c+cm}{/*Horizontal space required by the glyph in [px]*/}
    \PYG{n}{dsc\PYGZus{}out}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{box\PYGZus{}h} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{;}         \PYG{c+cm}{/*Height of the bitmap in [px]*/}
    \PYG{n}{dsc\PYGZus{}out}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{box\PYGZus{}w} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{6}\PYG{p}{;}         \PYG{c+cm}{/*Width of the bitmap in [px]*/}
    \PYG{n}{dsc\PYGZus{}out}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{ofs\PYGZus{}x} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{;}         \PYG{c+cm}{/*X offset of the bitmap in [pf]*/}

\section{Images}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:images}}\label{\detokenize{overview/image::doc}}
An image can be a file or variable which stores the bitmap itself and some metadata.


\subsection{Store images}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:store-images}}
You can store images in two places
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
as a variable in the internal memory (RAM or ROM)

\item {} 
as a file

\end{itemize}


\subsubsection{Variables}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:variables}}
The images stored internally in a variable is composed mainly of an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_dsc\_t}} structure with the following fields:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{header}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{cf} Color format. See {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/image:color-format}]{\emph{below}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{w} width in pixels (\textless{}= 2048)

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{h} height in pixels (\textless{}= 2048)

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{always zero} 3 bits which need to be always zero

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{reserved} reserved for future use

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{data} pointer to an array where the image itself is stored

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{data\_size} length of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{data}} in bytes

\end{itemize}

These are usually stored within a project as C files. They are linked into the resulting executable like any other constant data.


\subsubsection{Files}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:files}}
To deal with files you need to add a \sphinxstyleemphasis{Drive} to LVGL. In short, a \sphinxstyleemphasis{Drive} is a collection of functions (\sphinxstyleemphasis{open}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{read}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{close}, etc.) registered in LVGL to make file operations.
You can add an interface to a standard file system (FAT32 on SD card) or you create your simple file system to read data from an SPI Flash memory.
In every case, a \sphinxstyleemphasis{Drive} is just an abstraction to read and/or write data to a memory.
See the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/file-system::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{File system}}}} section to learn more.

Images stored as files are not linked into the resulting executable, and must be read to RAM before being drawn. As a result, they are not as resource-friendly as variable images. However, they are easier to replace without needing to recompile the main program.


\subsection{Color formats}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:color-formats}}
Various built-in color formats are supported:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR} Simply stores the RGB colors (in whatever color depth LVGL is configured for).

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR\_ALPHA} Like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR}} but it also adds an alpha (transparency) byte for every pixel.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR\_CHROMA\_KEYED} Like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR}} but if a pixel has \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_TRANSP}} (set in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}) color the pixel will be transparent.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMG\_CF\_INDEXED\_1/2/4/8BIT} Uses a palette with 2, 4, 16 or 256 colors and stores each pixel in 1, 2, 4 or 8 bits.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMG\_CF\_ALPHA\_1/2/4/8BIT} \sphinxstylestrong{Only stores the Alpha value on 1, 2, 4 or 8 bits.} The pixels take the color of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.image.color}} and the set opacity. The source image has to be an alpha channel. This is ideal for bitmaps similar to fonts (where the whole image is one color but you'd like to be able to change it).

\end{itemize}

The bytes of the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR}} images are stored in the following order.

For 32-bit color depth:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Byte 0: Blue

\item {} 
Byte 1: Green

\item {} 
Byte 2: Red

\item {} 
Byte 3: Alpha

\end{itemize}

For 16-bit color depth:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Byte 0: Green 3 lower bit, Blue 5 bit

\item {} 
Byte 1: Red 5 bit, Green 3 higher bit

\item {} 
Byte 2: Alpha byte (only with LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR\_ALPHA)

\end{itemize}

For 8-bit color depth:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Byte 0: Red 3 bit, Green 3 bit, Blue 2 bit

\item {} 
Byte 2: Alpha byte (only with LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR\_ALPHA)

\end{itemize}

You can store images in a \sphinxstyleemphasis{Raw} format to indicate that, it's not a built-in color format and an external {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/image:image-decoder}]{\emph{Image decoder}}} needs to be used to decode the image.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMG\_CF\_RAW} Indicates a basic raw image (e.g. a PNG or JPG image).

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMG\_CF\_RAW\_ALPHA} Indicates that the image has alpha and an alpha byte is added for every pixel.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_IMG\_CF\_RAW\_CHROME\_KEYED} Indicates that the image is chrome keyed as described in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR\_CHROMA\_KEYED}} above.

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Add and use images}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:add-and-use-images}}
You can add images to LVGL in two ways:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
using the online converter

\item {} 
manually create images

\end{itemize}


\subsubsection{Online converter}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:online-converter}}
The online Image converter is available here: https://lvgl.io/tools/imageconverter

Adding an image to LVGL via online converter is easy.
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
You need to select a \sphinxstyleemphasis{BMP}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{PNG} or \sphinxstyleemphasis{JPG} image first.

\item {} 
Give the image a name that will be used within LVGL.

\item {} 
Select the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/image:color-formats}]{\emph{Color format}}}.

\item {} 
Select the type of image you want. Choosing a binary will generate a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.bin}} file that must be stored separately and read using the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/image:files}]{\emph{file support}}}. Choosing a variable will generate a standard C file that can be linked into your project.

\item {} 
Hit the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Convert} button. Once the conversion is finished, your browser will automatically download the resulting file.

\end{enumerate}

In the converter C arrays (variables), the bitmaps for all the color depths (1, 8, 16 or 32) are included in the C file, but only the color depth that matches \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_DEPTH}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h} will actually be linked into the resulting executable.

In case of binary files, you need to specify the color format you want:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
RGB332 for 8-bit color depth

\item {} 
RGB565 for 16-bit color depth

\item {} 
RGB565 Swap for 16-bit color depth (two bytes are swapped)

\item {} 
RGB888 for 32-bit color depth

\end{itemize}


\subsubsection{Manually create an image}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:manually-create-an-image}}
If you are generating an image at run-time, you can craft an image variable to display it using LVGL. For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kt}{uint8\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+m+mh}{0x00}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mh}{0x01}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mh}{0x02}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{k}{static} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}dsc\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}dsc} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{header}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{always\PYGZus{}zero} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{header}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{w} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{80}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{header}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{h} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{60}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{data\PYGZus{}size} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{80} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{l+m+mi}{60} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}COLOR\PYGZus{}DEPTH} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{header}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{cf} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}IMG\PYGZus{}CF\PYGZus{}TRUE\PYGZus{}COLOR}\PYG{p}{,}          \PYG{c+cm}{/*Set the color format*/}
    \PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{data} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

If the color format is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR\_ALPHA}} you can set \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{data\_size}} like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{80 * 60 * LV\_IMG\_PX\_SIZE\_ALPHA\_BYTE}}.

Another (possibly simpler) option to create and display an image at run-time is to use the {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/canvas::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Canvas}}}} object.


\subsubsection{Use images}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:use-images}}
The simplest way to use an image in LVGL is to display it with an {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/img::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{lv\_img}}}} object:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{icon} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}scr\PYGZus{}act}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{c+cm}{/*From variable*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}src}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{icon}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}icon\PYGZus{}dsc}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{c+cm}{/*From file*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}src}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{icon}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{S:my\PYGZus{}icon.bin}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

If the image was converted with the online converter, you should use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_DECLARE(my\_icon\_dsc)}} to declare the image in the file where you want to use it.


\subsection{Image decoder}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:image-decoder}}
As you can see in the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/image:color-formats}]{\emph{Color formats}}} section, LVGL supports several built-in image formats. In many cases, these will be all you need. LVGL doesn't directly support, however, generic image formats like PNG or JPG.

To handle non-built-in image formats, you need to use external libraries and attach them to LVGL via the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Image decoder} interface.

The image decoder consists of 4 callbacks:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{info} get some basic info about the image (width, height and color format).

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{open} open the image: either store the decoded image or set it to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} to indicate the image can be read line-by-line.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{read} if \sphinxstyleemphasis{open} didn't fully open the image this function should give some decoded data (max 1 line) from a given position.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{close} close the opened image, free the allocated resources.

\end{itemize}

You can add any number of image decoders. When an image needs to be drawn, the library will try all the registered image decoder until finding one which can open the image, i.e. knowing that format.

The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR\_...}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_INDEXED\_...}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_ALPHA\_...}} formats (essentially, all non-\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{RAW}} formats) are understood by the built-in decoder.


\subsubsection{Custom image formats}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:custom-image-formats}}
The easiest way to create a custom image is to use the online image converter and set \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Raw}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Raw with alpha}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Raw with chrome keyed}} format. It will just take every byte of the binary file you uploaded and write it as the image "bitmap". You then need to attach an image decoder that will parse that bitmap and generate the real, renderable bitmap.

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{header.cf}} will be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_RAW}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_RAW\_ALPHA}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_RAW\_CHROME\_KEYED}} accordingly. You should choose the correct format according to your needs: fully opaque image, use alpha channel or use chroma keying.

After decoding, the \sphinxstyleemphasis{raw} formats are considered \sphinxstyleemphasis{True color} by the library. In other words, the image decoder must decode the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Raw} images to \sphinxstyleemphasis{True color} according to the format described in {[}\#color-formats{]}(Color formats) section.

If you want to create a custom image, you should use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_USER\_ENCODED\_0..7}} color formats. However, the library can draw the images only in \sphinxstyleemphasis{True color} format (or \sphinxstyleemphasis{Raw} but finally it's supposed to be in \sphinxstyleemphasis{True color} format).
So the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_USER\_ENCODED\_...}} formats are not known by the library, therefore, they should be decoded to one of the known formats from {[}\#color-formats{]}(Color formats) section.
It's possible to decode the image to a non-true color format first, for example, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_INDEXED\_4BITS}}, and then call the built-in decoder functions to convert it to \sphinxstyleemphasis{True color}.

With \sphinxstyleemphasis{User encoded} formats, the color format in the open function (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dsc-\textgreater{}header.cf}}) should be changed according to the new format.


\subsubsection{Register an image decoder}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:register-an-image-decoder}}
Here's an example of getting LVGL to work with PNG images.

First, you need to create a new image decoder and set some functions to open/close the PNG files. It should looks like this:

\PYG{c+cm}{ * Get info about a PNG image}

So in summary:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
In \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{decoder\_info}}, you should collect some basic information about the image and store it in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{header}}.

\item {} 
In \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{decoder\_open}}, you should try to open the image source pointed by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dsc-\textgreater{}src}}. Its type is already in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dsc-\textgreater{}src\_type == LV\_IMG\_SRC\_FILE/VARIABLE}}.
If this format/type is not supported by the decoder, return \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_RES\_INV}}.
However, if you can open the image, a pointer to the decoded \sphinxstyleemphasis{True color} image should be set in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dsc-\textgreater{}img\_data}}.
If the format is known but, you don't want to decode while image (e.g. no memory for it) set \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dsc-\textgreater{}img\_data = NULL}} to call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{read\_line}} to get the pixels.

\item {} 
In \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{decoder\_close}} you should free all the allocated resources.

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{decoder\_read}} is optional. Decoding the whole image requires extra memory and some computational overhead.
However, if can decode one line of the image without decoding the whole image, you can save memory and time.
To indicate that, the \sphinxstyleemphasis{line read} function should be used, set \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dsc-\textgreater{}img\_data = NULL}} in the open function.

\end{itemize}


\subsubsection{Manually use an image decoder}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:manually-use-an-image-decoder}}
LVGL will use the registered image decoder automatically if you try and draw a raw image (i.e. using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img}} object) but you can use them manually too. Create a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_decoder\_dsc\_t}} variable to describe the decoding session and call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_decoder\_open()}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_decoder\_open()}}.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}res\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{res}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}dsc\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{dsc}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{res} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}open}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{dsc}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}dsc}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}plain}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{res} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}OK}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Do something with {}`dsc\PYGZhy{}\PYGZgt{}img\PYGZus{}data{}`*/}
  \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}img\PYGZus{}decoder\PYGZus{}close}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{dsc}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Image caching}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:image-caching}}
Sometimes it takes a lot of time to open an image.
Continuously decoding a PNG image or loading images from a slow external memory would be inefficient and detrimental to the user experience.

Therefore, LVGL caches a given number of images. Caching means some images will be left open, hence LVGL can quickly access them from \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dsc-\textgreater{}img\_data}} instead of needing to decode them again.

Of course, caching images is resource-intensive as it uses more RAM (to store the decoded image). LVGL tries to optimize the process as much as possible (see below), but you will still need to evaluate if this would be beneficial for your platform or not. If you have a deeply embedded target which decodes small images from a relatively fast storage medium, image caching may not be worth it.


\subsubsection{Cache size}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:cache-size}}
The number of cache entries can be defined in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CACHE\_DEF\_SIZE}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}. The default value is 1 so only the most recently used image will be left open.

The size of the cache can be changed at run-time with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_cache\_set\_size(entry\_num)}}.


\subsubsection{Value of images}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:value-of-images}}
When you use more images than cache entries, LVGL can't cache all of the images. Instead, the library will close one of the cached images (to free space).

To decide which image to close, LVGL uses a measurement it previously made of how long it took to open the image. Cache entries that hold slower-to-open images are considered more valuable and are kept in the cache as long as possible.

If you want or need to override LVGL's measurement, you can manually set the \sphinxstyleemphasis{time to open} value in the decoder open function in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dsc-\textgreater{}time\_to\_open = time\_ms}} to give a higher or lower value. (Leave it unchanged to let LVGL set it.)

Every cache entry has a \sphinxstyleemphasis{"life"} value. Every time an image opening happens through the cache, the \sphinxstyleemphasis{life} of all entries are decreased to make them older.
When a cached image is used, its \sphinxstyleemphasis{life} is increased by the \sphinxstyleemphasis{time to open} value to make it more alive.

If there is no more space in the cache, always the entry with the smallest life will be closed.


\subsubsection{Memory usage}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:memory-usage}}
Note that, the cached image might continuously consume memory. For example, if 3 PNG images are cached, they will consume memory while they are opened.

Therefore, it's the user's responsibility to be sure there is enough RAM to cache, even the largest images at the same time.


\subsubsection{Clean the cache}
\label{\detokenize{overview/image:clean-the-cache}}
Let's say you have loaded a PNG image into a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_dsc\_t my\_png}} variable and use it in an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img}} object. If the image is already cached and you then change the underlying PNG file, you need to notify LVGL to cache the image again. Otherwise, there is no easy way of detecting that the underlying file changed and LVGL will still draw the old image.

To do this, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_cache\_invalidate\_src(\&my\_png)}}. If \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} is passed as a parameter, the whole cache will be cleaned.

\section{File system}
\label{\detokenize{overview/file-system:file-system}}\label{\detokenize{overview/file-system::doc}}
LVGL has a 'File system' abstraction module that enables you to attach any type of file systems.
The file system is identified by a drive letter.
For example, if the SD card is associated with the letter \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{'S'}}, a file can be reached like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"S:path/to/file.txt"}}.


\subsection{Add a driver}
\label{\detokenize{overview/file-system:add-a-driver}}
To add a driver, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_fs\_drv\_t}} needs to be initialized like this:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}fs\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}fs\PYGZus{}drv\PYGZus{}init}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}                     \PYG{c+cm}{/*Basic initialization*/}

\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{letter} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+sc}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+sc}{S}\PYG{l+s+sc}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{;}                         \PYG{c+cm}{/*An uppercase letter to identify the drive */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{file\PYGZus{}size} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k}{sizeof}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}file\PYGZus{}object}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}   \PYG{c+cm}{/*Size required to store a file object*/}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{rddir\PYGZus{}size} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k}{sizeof}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}dir\PYGZus{}object}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}   \PYG{c+cm}{/*Size required to store a directory object (used by dir\PYGZus{}open/close/read)*/}

\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{close\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}close\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}               \PYG{c+cm}{/*Callback to close a file */}

\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{trunc\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}trunc\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}               \PYG{c+cm}{/*Callback to delete a file */}

\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{dir\PYGZus{}read\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}dir\PYGZus{}read\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}         \PYG{c+cm}{/*Callback to read a directory\PYGZsq{}s content */}
\PYG{n}{drv}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{dir\PYGZus{}close\PYGZus{}cb} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}dir\PYGZus{}close\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{;}       \PYG{c+cm}{/*Callback to close a directory */}

Any of the callbacks can be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} to indicate that that operation is not supported.

As an example of how the callbacks are used, if you use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_fs\_open(\&file, "S:/folder/file.txt", LV\_FS\_MODE\_WR)}}, LVGL:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
Verifies that a registered drive exists with the letter \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{'S'}}.

\item {} 
Checks if it's \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{open\_cb}} is implemented (not \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}}).

\item {} 
Calls the set \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{open\_cb}} with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"folder/file.txt"}} path.

\end{enumerate}


\subsection{Usage example}
\label{\detokenize{overview/file-system:usage-example}}
The example below shows how to read from a file:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}fs\PYGZus{}file\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{f}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}fs\PYGZus{}res\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{res}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{res} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}fs\PYGZus{}open}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{f}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{S:folder/file.txt}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}FS\PYGZus{}MODE\PYGZus{}RD}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{res} \PYG{o}{!}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}FS\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}OK}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}error\PYGZus{}handling}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{k+kt}{uint32\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{read\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{k+kt}{uint8\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{buf}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{res} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}fs\PYGZus{}read}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{f}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{buf}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{read\PYGZus{}num}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{res} \PYG{o}{!}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}FS\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}OK} \PYG{o}{\textbar{}}\PYG{o}{\textbar{}} \PYG{n}{read\PYGZus{}num} \PYG{o}{!}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}error\PYGZus{}handling}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}fs\PYGZus{}close}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{f}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxstyleemphasis{The mode in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_fs\_open}} can be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FS\_MODE\_WR}} to open for write or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FS\_MODE\_RD \textbar{} LV\_FS\_MODE\_WR}} for both}

This example shows how to read a directory's content. It's up to the driver how to mark the directories, but it can be a good practice to insert a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{'/'}} in front of the directory name.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}fs\PYGZus{}dir\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{dir}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}fs\PYGZus{}res\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{res}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{res} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}fs\PYGZus{}dir\PYGZus{}open}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{dir}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{S:/folder}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{res} \PYG{o}{!}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}FS\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}OK}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}error\PYGZus{}handling}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{k+kt}{char} \PYG{n}{fn}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{256}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{k}{while}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{n}{res} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}fs\PYGZus{}dir\PYGZus{}read}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{dir}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{fn}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{res} \PYG{o}{!}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}FS\PYGZus{}RES\PYGZus{}OK}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}error\PYGZus{}handling}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
        \PYG{k}{break}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

    \PYG{c+cm}{/*fn is empty, if not more files to read*/}
    \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{strlen}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{fn}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{k}{break}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

    \PYG{n}{printf}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZpc{}s}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{fn}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}fs\PYGZus{}dir\PYGZus{}close}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{dir}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Use drivers for images}
\label{\detokenize{overview/file-system:use-drivers-for-images}}
{\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/img::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Image}}}} objects can be opened from files too (besides variables stored in the flash).

To initialize the image, the following callbacks are required:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
open

\item {} 
close

\item {} 
read

\item {} 
seek

\item {} 
tell

\end{itemize}

\section{Animations}
\label{\detokenize{overview/animation:animations}}\label{\detokenize{overview/animation::doc}}
You can automatically change the value of a variable between a start and an end value using animations.
The animation will happen by the periodical call of an "animator" function with the corresponding value parameter.

The \sphinxstyleemphasis{animator} functions has the following prototype:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{n+nf}{func}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{var}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}var\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{value}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

This prototype is compatible with the majority of the \sphinxstyleemphasis{set} function of LVGL. For example \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_x(obj, value)}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_width(obj, value)}}


\subsection{Create an animation}
\label{\detokenize{overview/animation:create-an-animation}}
To create an animation an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_anim\_t}} variable has to be initialized and configured with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_anim\_set\_...()}} functions.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\PYG{c+cm}{/* INITIALIZE AN ANIMATION}
\PYG{c+cm}{ *\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}*/}

\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}init}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{c+cm}{/* MANDATORY SETTINGS}
\PYG{c+cm}{ *\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}*/}

\PYG{c+cm}{/*Set the animator function and variable to animate*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}exec\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{btn1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}exec\PYGZus{}xcb\PYGZus{}t}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}x}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;} 

\PYG{c+cm}{/*Length of the animation [ms]*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}time}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{duration}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{c+cm}{/*Set start and end values. E.g. 0, 150 [ms]*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}values}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{start}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{end}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{c+cm}{/* OPTIONAL SETTINGS}
\PYG{c+cm}{ *\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}*/}

\PYG{c+cm}{/*Time to wait before starting the animation [ms]*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}delay}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{delay}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{c+cm}{/*Set path (curve). Default is linear*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}path}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{path}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{c+cm}{/*Set a callback to call when animation is ready.*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}ready\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{ready\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{c+cm}{/*Set a callback to call when animation is started (after delay).*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}start\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{start\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{c+cm}{/*Play the animation backward too with this duration. Default is 0 (disabled) [ms]*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}playback\PYGZus{}time}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{wait\PYGZus{}time}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;} 

\PYG{c+cm}{/*Delay before playback. Default is 0 (disabled) [ms]*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}playback\PYGZus{}delay}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{wait\PYGZus{}time}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{c+cm}{/*Number of repetitions. Default is 1.  LV\PYGZus{}ANIM\PYGZus{}REPEAT\PYGZus{}INFINIT for infinite repetition*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}repeat\PYGZus{}count}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{wait\PYGZus{}time}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{c+cm}{/*Delay before repeat. Default is 0 (disabled) [ms]*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}repeat\PYGZus{}delay}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{wait\PYGZus{}time}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{c+cm}{/*true (default): apply the start vale immediately, false: apply start vale after delay when then anim. really starts. */}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}early\PYGZus{}apply}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{true}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n+nb}{false}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{c+cm}{/* START THE ANIMATION}
\PYG{c+cm}{ *\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}start}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}                             \PYG{c+cm}{/*Start the animation*/}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

You can apply \sphinxstylestrong{multiple different animations} on the same variable at the same time.
For example, animate the x and y coordinates with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_x}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_y}}. However, only one animation can exist with a given variable and function pair.
Therefore \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_anim\_start()}} will delete the already existing variable-function animations.


\subsection{Animation path}
\label{\detokenize{overview/animation:animation-path}}
You can determinate the \sphinxstylestrong{path of animation}. In the most simple case, it is linear, which means the current value between \sphinxstyleemphasis{start} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{end}  is changed linearly.
A \sphinxstyleemphasis{path} is mainly a function which calculates the next value to set based on the current state of the animation. Currently, there are the following built-in paths functions:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_anim\_path\_linear} linear animation

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_anim\_path\_step} change in one step at the end

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_anim\_path\_ease\_in} slow at the beginning

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_anim\_path\_ease\_out} slow at the end

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_anim\_path\_ease\_in\_out} slow at the beginning and end too

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_anim\_path\_overshoot} overshoot the end value

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{lv\_anim\_path\_bounce} bounce back a little from the end value (like hitting a wall)

\end{itemize}

A path can be initialized like this:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}path\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{path}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}path\PYGZus{}init}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{path}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}path\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}cb}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{path}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}path\PYGZus{}overshoot}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}path\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}user\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{path}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{foo}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;} \PYG{c+cm}{/*Optional for custom functions*/}

\PYG{c+cm}{/*Set the path in an animation*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}anim\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}path}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{a}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{path}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Speed vs time}
\label{\detokenize{overview/animation:speed-vs-time}}
By default, you can set the animation time. But, in some cases, the \sphinxstylestrong{animation speed} is more practical.

The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_anim\_speed\_to\_time(speed, start, end)}} function calculates the required time in milliseconds to reach the end value from a start value with the given speed.
The speed is interpreted in \sphinxstyleemphasis{unit/sec} dimension. For example,  \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_anim\_speed\_to\_time(20,0,100)}} will give 5000 milliseconds. For example, in case of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_x}} \sphinxstyleemphasis{unit} is pixels so \sphinxstyleemphasis{20} means \sphinxstyleemphasis{20 px/sec} speed.


\subsection{Delete animations}
\label{\detokenize{overview/animation:delete-animations}}
You can \sphinxstylestrong{delete an animation} by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_anim\_del(var, func)}} by providing the animated variable and its animator function.
