\section{Tasks}
\label{\detokenize{overview/task:tasks}}\label{\detokenize{overview/task::doc}}
LVGL has a built-in task system. You can register a function to have it be called periodically. The tasks are handled and called in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler()}}, which needs to be called periodically every few milliseconds.
See {\hyperref[\detokenize{porting/task-handler::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Porting}}}} for more information.

The tasks are non-preemptive, which means a task cannot interrupt another task. Therefore, you can call any LVGL related function in a task.


\subsection{Create a task}
\label{\detokenize{overview/task:create-a-task}}
To create a new task, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_create(task\_cb, period\_ms, LV\_TASK\_PRIO\_OFF/LOWEST/LOW/MID/HIGH/HIGHEST, user\_data)}}. It will create an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_t *}} variable, which can be used later to modify the parameters of the task.
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_create\_basic()}} can also be used. It allows you to create a new task without specifying any parameters.

A task callback should have \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{void (*lv\_task\_cb\_t)(lv\_task\_t *);}} prototype.

For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{n+nf}{my\PYGZus{}task}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}task\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{task}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Use the user\PYGZus{}data*/}
  \PYG{k+kt}{uint32\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{user\PYGZus{}data} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{task}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{user\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{n}{printf}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{my\PYGZus{}task called with user data: \PYGZpc{}d}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{user\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Do something with LVGL*/}
  \PYG{k}{if}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{something\PYGZus{}happened}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{n}{something\PYGZus{}happened} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{false}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}btn\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}scr\PYGZus{}act}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
  \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}

\PYG{k}{static} \PYG{k+kt}{uint32\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{user\PYGZus{}data} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}task\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{task} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}task\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}task}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{500}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}TASK\PYGZus{}PRIO\PYGZus{}MID}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{user\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Ready and Reset}
\label{\detokenize{overview/task:ready-and-reset}}
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_ready(task)}} makes the task run on the next call of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler()}}.

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_reset(task)}} resets the period of a task. It will be called again after the defined period of milliseconds has elapsed.


\subsection{Set parameters}
\label{\detokenize{overview/task:set-parameters}}
You can modify some parameters of the tasks later:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_set\_cb(task, new\_cb)}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_set\_period(task, new\_period)}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_set\_prio(task, new\_priority)}}

\end{itemize}


\subsection{One-shot tasks}
\label{\detokenize{overview/task:one-shot-tasks}}
You can make a task to run only once by calling\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_once(task)}}. The task will automatically be deleted after being called for the first time.


\subsection{Measure idle time}
\label{\detokenize{overview/task:measure-idle-time}}
You can get the idle percentage time \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler}} with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_get\_idle()}}. Note that, it doesn't measure the idle time of the overall system, only \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler}}.
It can be misleading if you use an operating system and call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler}} in an  task, as it won't actually measure the time the OS spends in an idle thread.


\subsection{Asynchronous calls}
\label{\detokenize{overview/task:asynchronous-calls}}
In some cases, you can't do an action immediately. For example, you can't delete an object right now because something else is still using it or you don't want to block the execution now.
For these cases, you can use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_async\_call(my\_function, data\_p)}} to make \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{my\_function}} be called on the next call of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler}}. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{data\_p}} will be passed to function when it's called.
Note that, only the pointer of the data is saved so you need to ensure that the variable will be "alive" while the function is called. You can use \sphinxstyleemphasis{static}, global or dynamically allocated data.

For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{n+nf}{my\PYGZus{}screen\PYGZus{}clean\PYGZus{}up}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{scr}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Free some resources related to {}`scr{}`*/}

  \PYG{c+cm}{/*Finally delete the screen*/}
  \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}del}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{scr}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}  
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}

\PYG{c+cm}{/*Do somethings with the object on the current screen*/}

\PYG{c+cm}{/*Delete screen on next call of {}`lv\PYGZus{}task\PYGZus{}handler{}`. So not now.*/}
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}async\PYGZus{}call}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}screen\PYGZus{}clean\PYGZus{}up}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}scr\PYGZus{}act}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{c+cm}{/*The screen is still valid so you can do other things with it*/}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

If you just want to delete an object, and don't need to clean anything up in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{my\_screen\_cleanup}}, you could just use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_del\_async}}, which will delete the object on the next call to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_task\_handler}}.

\section{Drawing}
\label{\detokenize{overview/drawing:drawing}}\label{\detokenize{overview/drawing::doc}}
With LVGL, you don't need to draw anything manually. Just create objects (like buttons and labels), move and change them and LVGL will refresh and redraw what is required.

However, it might be useful to have a basic understanding of how drawing happens in LVGL.

The basic concept is to not draw directly to the screen, but draw to an internal buffer first and then copy that buffer to screen when the rendering is ready. It has two main advantages:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Avoids flickering} while layers of the UI are drawn. For example, when drawing a \sphinxstyleemphasis{background + button + text}, each "stage" would be visible for a short time.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{It's faster} to modify a buffer in RAM and finally write one pixel once
than read/write a display directly on each pixel access. (e.g. via a display controller with SPI interface). Hence, it's suitable for pixels that are redrawn multiple times (e.g. background + button + text).

\end{enumerate}


\subsection{Buffering types}
\label{\detokenize{overview/drawing:buffering-types}}
As you already might learn in the {\hyperref[\detokenize{porting/display::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Porting}}}} section, there are 3 types of buffers:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{One buffer} -  LVGL draws the content of the screen into a buffer and sends it to the display. The buffer can be smaller than the screen. In this case, the larger areas will be redrawn in multiple parts. If only small areas changes (e.g. button press), then only those areas will be refreshed.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Two non-screen-sized buffers} -  having two buffers, LVGL can draw into one buffer while the content of the other buffer is sent to display in the background.
DMA or other hardware should be used to transfer the data to the display to let the CPU draw meanwhile.
This way, the rendering and refreshing of the display become parallel. If the buffer is smaller than the area to refresh, LVGL will draw the display's content in chunks similar to the \sphinxstyleemphasis{One buffer}.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Two screen-sized buffers} -
In contrast to \sphinxstyleemphasis{Two non-screen-sized buffers}, LVGL will always provide the whole screen's content, not only chunks. This way, the driver can simply change the address of the frame buffer to the buffer received from LVGL.
Therefore, this method works best when the MCU has an LCD/TFT interface and the frame buffer is just a location in the RAM.

\end{enumerate}


\subsection{Mechanism of screen refreshing}
\label{\detokenize{overview/drawing:mechanism-of-screen-refreshing}}\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
Something happens on the GUI which requires redrawing. For example, a button has been pressed, a chart has been changed or an animation happened, etc.

\item {} 
LVGL saves the changed object's old and new area into a buffer, called an \sphinxstyleemphasis{Invalid area buffer}. For optimization, in some cases, objects are not added to the buffer:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Hidden objects are not added.

\item {} 
Objects completely out of their parent are not added.

\item {} 
Areas out of the parent are cropped to the parent's area.

\item {} 
The object on other screens are not added.

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
In every \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_DISP\_DEF\_REFR\_PERIOD}} (set in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}):
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
LVGL checks the invalid areas and joins the adjacent or intersecting areas.

\item {} 
Takes the first joined area, if it's smaller than the \sphinxstyleemphasis{display buffer}, then simply draw the areas' content to the \sphinxstyleemphasis{display buffer}. If the area doesn't fit into the buffer, draw as many lines as possible to the \sphinxstyleemphasis{display buffer}.

\item {} 
When the area is drawn, call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{flush\_cb}} from the display driver to refresh the display.

\item {} 
If the area was larger than the buffer, redraw the remaining parts too.

\item {} 
Do the same with all the joined areas.

\end{itemize}

\end{enumerate}

While an area is redrawn, the library searches the most top object which covers the area to redraw, and starts to draw from that object.
For example, if a button's label has changed, the library will see that it's enough to draw the button under the text, and it's not required to draw the background too.

The difference between buffer types regarding the drawing mechanism is the following:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{One buffer} - LVGL needs to wait for \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_flush\_ready()}} (called at the end of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{flush\_cb}}) before starting to redraw the next part.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Two non-screen-sized buffers} -  LVGL can immediately draw to the second buffer when the first is sent to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{flush\_cb}} because the flushing should be done by DMA (or similar hardware) in the background.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Two screen-sized buffers} -  After calling \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{flush\_cb}}, the first buffer, if being displayed as frame buffer. Its content is copied to the second buffer and all the changes are drawn on top of it.

\end{enumerate}


\subsection{Masking}
\label{\detokenize{overview/drawing:masking}}
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Masking} is the basic concept of LVGL's drawing engine.
To use LVGL it's not required to know about the mechanisms described here,
but you might find interesting to know how the drawing works under hood.

To learn masking let's learn the steps of drawing first:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
Create a draw descriptor from an object's styles (e.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_draw\_rect\_dsc\_t}}).
It tells the parameters of drawing, for example the colors, widths, opacity, fonts, radius, etc.

\item {} 
Call the draw function with the initialized descriptor and some other parameters.
It renders the primitive shape to the current draw buffer.

\item {} 
If the shape is very simple and doesn't require masks go to \#5.
Else create the required masks (e.g. a rounded rectangle mask)

\item {} 
Apply all the created mask(s) for one or a few lines.
It create 0..255 values into a \sphinxstyleemphasis{mask buffer} with the "shape" of the created masks.
E.g. in case of a "line mask" according to the parameters of the mask,
keep one side of the buffer as it is (255 by default) and set the rest to 0 to indicate that the latter side should be removed.

\item {} 
Blend the image or rectangle to the screen.
During blending masks (make some pixels transparent or opaque), blending modes (additive, subtractive, etc), opacity are handled.

\item {} 
Repeat from  \#4.

\end{enumerate}

Masks are used the create almost every basic primitives:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{letters} create a mask from the letter and draw a “letter-colored” rectangle using the mask.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{line} created from 4 l"ine masks", to mask out the left, right, top and bottom part of the line to get perfectly perpendicular line ending

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{rounded rectangle} a mask is created real-time for each line of a rounded rectangle and a normal filled rectangle is drawn according to the mask.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{clip corner} to clip to overflowing content on the rounded corners also a rounded rectangle mask is applied.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{rectangle border} same as a rounded rectangle, but inner part is masked out too

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{arc drawing} a circle border is drawn, but an arc mask is applied.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{ARGB images} the alpha channel is separated into a mask and the image is drawn as a normal RGB image.

\end{itemize}

As mentioned in \#3 above in some cases no mask is required:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
a mono colored, not rounded rectangles

\item {} 
RGB images

\end{itemize}

LVGL has the following built-in mask types which can be calculated and applied real-time:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_DRAW\_MASK\_TYPE\_LINE} Removes a side of a line (top, bottom, left or right). \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_draw\_line}} uses 4 of it.
Essentially, every (skew) line is bounded with 4 line masks by forming a rectangle.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_DRAW\_MASK\_TYPE\_RADIUS} Removes the inner or outer parts of a rectangle which can have radius too. It's also used to create circles by setting the radius to large value (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_RADIUS\_CIRCLE}})

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_DRAW\_MASK\_TYPE\_ANGLE} Removes a circle sector. It is used by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_draw\_arc}} to remove the "empty" sector.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_DRAW\_MASK\_TYPE\_FADE} Create a vertical fade (change opacity)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_DRAW\_MASK\_TYPE\_MAP} The mask is stored in an array and the necessary parts are applied

\end{itemize}

Masks are create and removed automatically during drawing but the {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/objmask::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{lv\_objmask}}}} allows the user to add masks.

    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}bg\PYGZus{}grad\PYGZus{}dir}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{style\PYGZus{}bg}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}STATE\PYGZus{}DEFAULT}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}GRAD\PYGZus{}DIR\PYGZus{}HOR}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

    \PYG{c+cm}{/* Create and object with the gradient style on the object mask.}
\PYG{c+cm}{     * The text will be masked from the gradient*/}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{bg} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{om}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}reset\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}list}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{bg}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}OBJ\PYGZus{}PART\PYGZus{}MAIN}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}add\PYGZus{}style}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{bg}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}OBJ\PYGZus{}PART\PYGZus{}MAIN}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{style\PYGZus{}bg}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}size}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{bg}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{MASK\PYGZus{}WIDTH}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{MASK\PYGZus{}HEIGHT}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{c+cp}{\PYGZsh{}}\PYG{c+cp}{endif}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\chapter{Widgets}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/index:widgets}}\label{\detokenize{widgets/index::doc}}

\section{Base object (lv\_obj)}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/obj:base-object-lv-obj}}\label{\detokenize{widgets/obj::doc}}

\subsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/obj:overview}}
The 'Base Object' implements the basic properties of widgets on a screen, such as:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
coordinates

\item {} 
parent object

\item {} 
children

\item {} 
main style

\item {} 
attributes like \sphinxstyleemphasis{Click enable}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{Drag enable}, etc.

\end{itemize}

In object-oriented thinking, it is the base class from which all other objects in LVGL are inherited. This, among another things, helps reduce code duplication.

The functions and functionalities of Base object can be used with other widgets too. For example \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_width(slider, 100)}}

The Base object can be directly used as a simple widgets. It nothing else then a rectangle.


\subsubsection{Coordinates}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/obj:coordinates}}

\paragraph{Size}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/obj:size}}
The object size can be modified on individual axes with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_width(obj, new\_width)}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_height(obj, new\_height)}}, or both axes can be modified at the same time with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_size(obj, new\_width, new\_height)}}.

Styles can add \sphinxhref{/overview/style/\#properties}{Margin} to the objects. Margin tells that "I want this space around me".
To set width or height reduced by the margin \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_width\_margin(obj, new\_width)}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_height\_margin(obj, new\_height)}}.
In more exact way: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{new\_width = left\_margin + object\_width + right\_margin}}.

To get the width or height which includes the margins use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_get\_width/height\_margin(obj)}}.

Styles can add \sphinxhref{/overview/style/\#properties}{Padding} to the object as well. Padding means "I don't want my children too close to my sides, so keep this space".
To set width or height reduced by the padding \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_width\_fit(obj, new\_width)}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_height\_fit(obj, new\_height)}}.In a more exact way: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{new\_width = left\_pad + object\_width + right\_pad}}
To get the width or height which is REDUCED by padding use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_get\_width/height\_fit(obj)}}. It can be considered the "useful size of the object".

Margin and padding gets important when \sphinxhref{/widget/cont\#layout}{Layout} or \sphinxhref{/wisgets/cont\#fit}{Auto-fit} is used by other widgets.


\paragraph{Position}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/obj:position}}
You can set the x and y coordinates relative to the parent with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_x(obj, new\_x)}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_y(obj, new\_y)}}, or both at the same time with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_pos(obj, new\_x, new\_y)}}.


\paragraph{Alignment}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/obj:alignment}}
You can align the object to another with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_align(obj, obj\_ref, LV\_ALIGN\_..., x\_ofs, y\_ofs)}}.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{obj}} is the object to align.

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{obj\_ref}} is a reference object. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{obj}} will be aligned to it. If \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{obj\_ref = NULL}}, then the parent of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{obj}} will be used.

\item {} 
The third argument is the \sphinxstyleemphasis{type} of alignment. These are the possible options:
\sphinxincludegraphics{{align}.png}

The alignment types build like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_ALIGN\_OUT\_TOP\_MID}}.

\item {} 
The last two arguments allow you to shift the object by a specified number of pixels after aligning it.

\end{itemize}

For example, to align a text below an image: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_align(text, image, LV\_ALIGN\_OUT\_BOTTOM\_MID, 0, 10)}}.
Or to align a text in the middle of its parent: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_align(text, NULL, LV\_ALIGN\_CENTER, 0, 0)}}.

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_align\_origo}} works similarly to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_align}} but it aligns the center of the object.

For example, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_align\_origo(btn, image, LV\_ALIGN\_OUT\_BOTTOM\_MID, 0, 0)}} will align the center of the button the bottom of the image.

The parameters of the alignment will be saved in the object if \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_USE\_OBJ\_REALIGN}} is enabled in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}. You can then realign the objects simply by calling \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_realign(obj)}}.
It's equivalent to calling \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_align}} again with the same parameters.

If the alignment happened with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_align\_origo}}, then it will be used when the object is realigned.

If \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_auto\_realign(obj, true)}} is used the object will be realigned automatically, if its size changes in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_width/height/size()}} functions.
It's very useful when size animations are applied to the object and the original position needs to be kept.

\sphinxstylestrong{Note that the coordinates of screens can't be changed. Attempting to use these functions on screens will result in undefined behavior.}


\subsubsection{Parents and children}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/obj:parents-and-children}}
You can set a new parent for an object with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_parent(obj, new\_parent)}}. To get the current parent, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_get\_parent(obj)}}.

To get the children of an object, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_get\_child(obj, child\_prev)}} (from last to first) or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_get\_child\_back(obj, child\_prev)}} (from first to last).
To get the first child, pass \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} as the second parameter and use the return value to iterate through the children. The function will return \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} if there are no more children. For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{child} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}get\PYGZus{}child}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{parent}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{k}{while}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{child}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{c+cm}{/*Do something with \PYGZdq{}child\PYGZdq{} */}
    \PYG{n}{child} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}get\PYGZus{}child}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{parent}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{child}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_count\_children(obj)}} tells the number of children on an object. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_count\_children\_recursive(obj)}} also tells the number of children but counts children of children recursively.


\subsubsection{Screens}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/obj:screens}}
When you have created a screen like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_t * screen = lv\_obj\_create(NULL, NULL)}}, you can load it with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_scr\_load(screen)}}. The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_scr\_act()}} function gives you a pointer to the current screen.

If you have more display then it's important to know that these functions operate on the lastly created or the explicitly selected (with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_disp\_set\_default}}) display.

To get an object's screen use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_get\_screen(obj)}} function.


\subsubsection{Layers}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/obj:layers}}
There are two  automatically generated layers:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
top layer

\item {} 
system layer

\end{itemize}

They are independent of the screens and they will be shown on every screen. The \sphinxstyleemphasis{top layer} is above every object on the screen and the \sphinxstyleemphasis{system layer} is above the \sphinxstyleemphasis{top layer} too.
You can add any pop-up windows to the \sphinxstyleemphasis{top layer} freely. But, the \sphinxstyleemphasis{system layer} is restricted to system-level things (e.g. mouse cursor will be placed here in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_indev\_set\_cursor()}}).

The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_layer\_top()}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_layer\_sys()}} functions gives a pointer to the top or system layer.

You can bring an object to the foreground or send it to the background with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_move\_foreground(obj)}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_move\_background(obj)}}.

Read the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/layer::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Layer overview}}}} section to learn more about layers.


\subsubsection{Events}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/obj:events}}
To set an event callback for an object, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_event\_cb(obj, event\_cb)}},

To manually send an event to an object, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_event\_send(obj, LV\_EVENT\_..., data)}}

Read the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Event overview}}}} to learn more about the events.


\subsection{Parts}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/obj:parts}}
The widgets can have multiple parts. For example a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/btn::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Button}}}} has only a main part but a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/slider::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Slider}}}} is built from a background, an indicator and a knob.

The name of the parts is constructed like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_ + \textless{}TYPE\textgreater{} \_PART\_ \textless{}NAME\textgreater{}}}. For example \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BTN\_PART\_MAIN}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_SLIDER\_PART\_KNOB}}. The parts are usually used when styles are add to the objects.
Using parts different styles can be assigned to the different parts of the objects.

To learn more about the parts read the related section of the \sphinxhref{/overview/style\#parts}{Style overview}.


\subsubsection{States}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/obj:states}}
The object can be in a combinations of the following states:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_DEFAULT}  Normal, released

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_CHECKED} Toggled or checked

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_FOCUSED} Focused via keypad or encoder or clicked via touchpad/mouse

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_EDITED}  Edit by an encoder

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_HOVERED} Hovered by mouse (not supported now)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_PRESSED} Pressed

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_STATE\_DISABLED} Disabled or inactive

\end{itemize}

The states are usually automatically changed by the library as the user presses, releases, focuses etc an object.
However, the states can be changed manually too. To completely overwrite the current state use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_state(obj, part, LV\_STATE...)}}.
To set or clear given state (but leave to other states untouched) use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_add/clear\_state(obj, part, LV\_STATE\_...)}}
In both cases ORed state values can be used as well. E.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_state(obj, part, LV\_STATE\_PRESSED \textbar{} LV\_PRESSED\_CHECKED)}}.

To learn more about the states read the related section of the \sphinxhref{/overview/style\#states}{Style overview}.


\subsubsection{Style}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/obj:style}}
Be sure to read the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/style::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Style overview}}}} first.

To add a style to an object use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_add\_style(obj, part, \&new\_style)}} function. The Base object use all the rectangle-like style properties.

To remove all styles from an object use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_reset\_style\_list(obj, part)}}

If you modify a style, which is already used by objects, in order to refresh the affected objects you can use either \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_refresh\_style(obj)}} on each object using it or
to notify all objects with a given style use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_report\_style\_mod(\&style)}}. If the parameter of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_report\_style\_mod}} is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}}, all objects will be notified.


\subsubsection{Attributes}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/obj:attributes}}
There are some attributes which can be enabled/disabled by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_...(obj, true/false)}}:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{hidden} -  Hide the object. It will not be drawn and will be considered by input devices as if it doesn't exist., Its children will be hidden too.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{click} -  Allows you to click the object via input devices. If disabled, then click events are passed to the object behind this one. (E.g. {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/label::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Labels}}}} are not clickable by default)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{top} -  If enabled then when this object or any of its children is clicked then this object comes to the foreground.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{drag} - Enable dragging (moving by an input device)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{drag\_dir} - Enable dragging only in specific directions. Can be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_DRAG\_DIR\_HOR/VER/ALL}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{drag\_throw} - Enable "throwing" with dragging as if the object would have momentum

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{drag\_parent} - If enabled then the object's parent will be moved during dragging. It will look like as if the parent is dragged. Checked recursively, so can propagate to grandparents too.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{parent\_event} - Propagate the events to the parents too. Checked recursively, so can propagate to grandparents too.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{opa\_scale\_enable} - Enable opacity scaling. See the {[}\#opa-scale{]}(Opa scale) section.

\end{itemize}


\subsubsection{Protect}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/obj:protect}}
There are some specific actions which happen automatically in the library.
To prevent one or more that kind of actions, you can protect the object against them. The following protections exists:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_PROTECT\_NONE} No protection

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_PROTECT\_POS}  Prevent automatic positioning (e.g.  Layout in {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/cont::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Containers}}}})

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_PROTECT\_FOLLOW} Prevent the object be followed (make a "line break") in automatic ordering (e.g. Layout in {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/cont::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Containers}}}})

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_PROTECT\_PARENT} Prevent automatic parent change. (e.g. {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/page::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Page}}}} moves the children created on the background to the scrollable)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_PROTECT\_PRESS\_LOST} Prevent losing press when the press is slid out of the objects. (E.g. a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/btn::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Button}}}} can be released out of it if it was being pressed)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_PROTECT\_CLICK\_FOCUS} Prevent automatically focusing the object if it's in a \sphinxstyleemphasis{Group} and click focus is enabled.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_PROTECT\_CHILD\_CHG} Disable the child change signal. Used internally by the library

\end{itemize}

The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set/clear\_protect(obj, LV\_PROTECT\_...)}} sets/clears the protection. You can use \sphinxstyleemphasis{'OR'ed} values of protection types too.


\subsubsection{Groups}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/obj:groups}}
Once, an object is added to \sphinxstyleemphasis{group} with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_group\_add\_obj(group, obj)}} the object's current group can be get with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_get\_group(obj)}}.

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_is\_focused(obj)}} tells if the object is currently focused on its group or not. If the object is not added to a group, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{false}} will be returned.

Read the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Input devices overview}}}} to learn more about the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Groups}.


\subsubsection{Extended click area}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/obj:extended-click-area}}
By default, the objects can be clicked only on their coordinates, however, this area can be extended with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_ext\_click\_area(obj, left, right, top, bottom)}}.
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{left/right/top/bottom}} describes how far the clickable area should extend past the default in each direction.

This feature needs to enabled in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h} with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_USE\_EXT\_CLICK\_AREA}}. The possible values are:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EXT\_CLICK\_AREA\_FULL} store all 4 coordinates as \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_coord\_t}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EXT\_CLICK\_AREA\_TINY} store only horizontal and vertical coordinates (use the greater value of left/right and top/bottom) as \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{uint8\_t}}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EXT\_CLICK\_AREA\_OFF} Disable this feature

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Events}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/obj:id1}}
Only the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} are sent by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\subsection{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/obj:keys}}
No \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.


\subsection{Example}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/obj:example}}

\subsubsection{C}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/obj:c}}

\paragraph{Base obejcts with custom styles}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/obj:base-obejcts-with-custom-styles}}
\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{lv_ex_obj_1}.png}

code

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+cp}{\PYGZsh{}}\PYG{c+cp}{include} \PYG{c+cpf}{\PYGZdq{}../../../lv\PYGZus{}examples.h\PYGZdq{}}

\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{n+nf}{lv\PYGZus{}ex\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}1}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{k+kt}{void}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{obj1}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{obj1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}scr\PYGZus{}act}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}size}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{obj1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{100}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{50}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}align}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{obj1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}ALIGN\PYGZus{}CENTER}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{60}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{30}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

    \PYG{c+cm}{/*Copy the previous object and enable drag*/}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{obj2}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{obj2} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}scr\PYGZus{}act}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{obj1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\section{Arc (lv\_arc)}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/arc:arc-lv-arc}}\label{\detokenize{widgets/arc::doc}}

\subsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/arc:overview}}
The Arc are consists of a background and a foreground arc. Both can have start and end angles and thickness.


\subsection{Parts and Styles}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/arc:parts-and-styles}}
The Arc's main part is called \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_ARC\_PART\_MAIN}}. It draws a background using the typical background style properties and an arc using the \sphinxstyleemphasis{line} style properties.
The arc's size and position will respect the \sphinxstyleemphasis{padding} style properties.

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_ARC\_PART\_INDIC}} is virtual part and it draws an other arc using the \sphinxstyleemphasis{line} style proeprties. It's padding values are interpreted relative to the background arc.
The radius of the indicator arc will be modified according to the greatest padding value.


\subsection{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/arc:usage}}

\subsubsection{Angles}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/arc:angles}}
To set the angles of the background, use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_arc\_set\_bg\_angles(arc, start\_angle, end\_angle)}} function or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_arc\_set\_bg\_start/end\_angle(arc, start\_angle)}}.
Zero degree is at the middle right (3 o'clock) of the object and the degrees are increasing in a clockwise direction.
The angles should be in {[}0;360{]} range.

Similarly, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_arc\_set\_angles(arc, start\_angle, end\_angle)}} function or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_arc\_set\_start/end\_angle(arc, start\_angle)}} sets the angles of the indicator arc.


\subsection{Events}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/arc:events}}
Only the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} are sent by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\subsection{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/arc:keys}}
No \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.


\subsection{Example}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/arc:example}}

\subsubsection{C}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/arc:c}}

\section{Bar (lv\_bar)}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/bar:bar-lv-bar}}\label{\detokenize{widgets/bar::doc}}

\subsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/bar:overview}}
The bar object has a background and an indicator on it. The width of the indicator is set according to the current value of the bar.

Vertical bars can be created if the width of the object is smaller than its height.

Not only end, but the start value of the bar can be set which changes the start position of the indicator.


\subsection{Parts and Styles}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/bar:parts-and-styles}}
The Bar's main part is called \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BAR\_PART\_BG}} and it uses the typical background style properties.

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BAR\_PART\_INDIC}} is a virtual part which also uses all the typical background properties.
By default the indicator maximal size is the same as the background's size but setting positive padding values in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BAR\_PART\_BG}} will make the indicator smaller. (negative values will make it larger)
If the \sphinxstyleemphasis{value} style property is used on the indicator the alignment will be calculated based on the current size of the indicator.
For example a center aligned value is always shown in the middle of the indicator regardless it's current size.


\subsection{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/bar:usage}}

\subsubsection{Value and range}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/bar:value-and-range}}
A new value can be set by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_bar\_set\_value(bar, new\_value, LV\_ANIM\_ON/OFF)}}.
The value is interpreted in a range (minimum and maximum values) which can be modified with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_bar\_set\_range(bar, min, max)}}.
The default range is 1..100.

The new value in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_bar\_set\_value}} can be set with or without an animation depending on the last parameter (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_ANIM\_ON/OFF}}).
The time of the animation can be adjusted by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_bar\_set\_anim\_time(bar, 100)}}. The time is in milliseconds unit.

It's also possible to set the start value of the bar using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_bar\_set\_start\_value(bar, new\_value, LV\_ANIM\_ON/OFF)}}


\subsubsection{Modes}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/bar:modes}}
The bar can be drawn symmetrical to zero (drawn from zero, left to right), if it's enabled with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_bar\_set\_type(bar, LV\_BAR\_TYPE\_SYMMETRICAL)}}.


\subsection{Events}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/bar:events}}
Only the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} are sent by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\subsection{Keys}

\section{Button (lv\_btn)}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/btn:button-lv-btn}}\label{\detokenize{widgets/btn::doc}}

\subsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/btn:overview}}
Buttons are simple rectangle-like objects. They are derived from {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/cont::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Containers}}}} so \sphinxhref{/widgets/cont\#layout}{layout} and \sphinxhref{/widgets/cont\#fit}{fit} are also available.
Besides, it can be enabled to automatically go to checked state on click.


\subsection{Parts and Styles}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/btn:parts-and-styles}}
The buttons has only a main style called \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BTN\_PART\_MAIN}} and it can use all the properties from the following groups:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
background

\item {} 
border

\item {} 
outline

\item {} 
shadow

\item {} 
value

\item {} 
pattern

\item {} 
transitions

\end{itemize}

It also uses the \sphinxstyleemphasis{padding} properties when \sphinxstyleemphasis{layout} or \sphinxstyleemphasis{fit} is enabled.


\subsection{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/btn:usage}}

\subsubsection{States}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/btn:states}}
To make buttons usage simpler the button's state can be get with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btn\_get\_state(btn)}}. It returns one of the following values:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTN\_STATE\_RELEASED}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTN\_STATE\_PRESSED}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTN\_STATE\_CHECKED\_RELEASED}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTN\_STATE\_CHECKED\_PRESSED}

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTN\_STATE\_DISABLED}

\end{itemize}

With \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btn\_get\_state(btn, LV\_BTN\_STATE\_...)}} the buttons state can be changed manually.

If a more precise description of the state is required (e.g. focused) the general \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_get\_state(btn)}} can be used.


\subsubsection{Checkable}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/btn:checkable}}
You can configure the buttons as \sphinxstyleemphasis{toggle button} with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btn\_set\_checkable(btn, true)}}. In this case, on click, the button goes to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_STATE\_CHECKED}} state automatically, or back when clicked again.


\subsubsection{Layout and Fit}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/btn:layout-and-fit}}
Similarly to {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/cont::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Containers}}}}, buttons also have layout and fit attributes.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btn\_set\_layout(btn, LV\_LAYOUT\_...) }}set a layout. The default is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LAYOUT\_CENTER}}.
So, if you add a label, then it will be automatically aligned to the middle and can't be moved with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_pos()}}.
You can disable the layout with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btn\_set\_layout(btn, LV\_LAYOUT\_OFF)}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btn\_set\_fit/fit2/fit4(btn, LV\_FIT\_..)}} enables to set the button width and/or height automatically according to the children, parent, and fit type.

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Events}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/btn:events}}
Besides the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} the following \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#special-events}{Special events} are sent by the buttons:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_VALUE\_CHANGED} - sent when the button is toggled.

\end{itemize}

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\subsection{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/btn:keys}}
The following \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the Buttons:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_RIGHT/UP} - Go to toggled state if toggling is enabled.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_LEFT/DOWN} - Go to non-toggled state if toggling is enabled.

\end{itemize}

Note that, the state of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_KEY\_ENTER}} is translated to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_EVENT\_PRESSED/PRESSING/RELEASED}} etc.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.


\subsection{Example}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/btn:example}}

\subsubsection{C}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/btn:c}}

\section{Button matrix (lv\_btnmatrix)}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/btnmatrix:button-matrix-lv-btnmatrix}}\label{\detokenize{widgets/btnmatrix::doc}}

\subsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/btnmatrix:overview}}
The Button Matrix objects can display \sphinxstylestrong{multiple buttons} in rows and columns.

The main reasons for wanting to use a button matrix instead of a container and individual button objects are:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
The button matrix is simpler to use for grid-based button layouts.

\item {} 
The button matrix consumes a lot less memory per button.

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Parts and Styles}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/btnmatrix:parts-and-styles}}
The Button matrix's main part is called \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BTNMATRIX\_PART\_BG}}. It draws a background using the typical background style properties.

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BTNMATRIX\_PART\_BTN}} is virtual part and it refers to the buttons on the button matrix. It also uses all the typical background properties.

The top/bottom/left/right padding values from the background are used to keep some space on the sides. Inner padding is applied between the buttons.


\subsection{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/btnmatrix:usage}}

\subsubsection{Button's text}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/btnmatrix:button-s-text}}
There is a text on each button. To specify them a descriptor string array, called \sphinxstyleemphasis{map}, needs to be used.
The map can be set with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btnmatrix\_set\_map(btnm, my\_map)}}.
The declaration of a map should look like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{const char * map{[}{]} = \{"btn1", "btn2", "btn3", ""\}}}.
Note that \sphinxstylestrong{the last element has to be an empty string}!

Use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"\textbackslash{}n"}} in the map  to make \sphinxstylestrong{line break}. E.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{"btn1", "btn2", "\textbackslash{}n", "btn3", ""\}}}. Each line's buttons have their width calculated automatically.


\subsubsection{Control buttons}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/btnmatrix:control-buttons}}
The \sphinxstylestrong{buttons width} can be set relative to the other button in the same line with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btnmatrix\_set\_btn\_width(btnm, btn\_id, width)}}
E.g. in a line with two buttons: \sphinxstyleemphasis{btnA, width = 1} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{btnB, width = 2}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{btnA} will have 33 \% width and \sphinxstyleemphasis{btnB} will have 66 \% width.
It's similar to how the \sphinxhref{https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/flex-grow}{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{flex-grow}}} property works in CSS.

In addition to width, each button can be customized with the following parameters:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTNMATRIX\_CTRL\_HIDDEN} - make a button hidden (hidden buttons still take up space in the layout, they are just not visible or clickable)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTNMATRIX\_CTRL\_NO\_REPEAT} - disable repeating when the button is long pressed

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTNMATRIX\_CTRL\_DISABLED} - make a button disabled

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTNMATRIX\_CTRL\_CHECKABLE} - enable toggling of a button

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTNMATRIX\_CTRL\_CHECK\_STATE} - set the toggle state

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_BTNMATRIX\_CTRL\_CLICK\_TRIG} - if 0, the button will react on press, if 1, will react on release

\end{itemize}

The set or clear a button's control attribute, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btnmatrix\_set\_btn\_ctrl(btnm, btn\_id, LV\_BTNM\_CTRL\_...)}} and
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btnmatrix\_clear\_btn\_ctrl(btnm, btn\_id, LV\_BTNM\_CTRL\_...)}} respectively. More \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BTNM\_CTRL\_...}} values can be \sphinxstyleemphasis{Or}ed

The set/clear the same control attribute for all buttons of a button matrix, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btnmatrix\_set\_btn\_ctrl\_all(btnm, btn\_id, LV\_BTNM\_CTRL\_...)}} and
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btnmatrix\_clear\_btn\_ctrl\_all(btnm, btn\_id, LV\_BTNM\_CTRL\_...)}}.

The set a control map for a button matrix (similarly to the map for the text), use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btnmatrix\_set\_ctrl\_map(btnm, ctrl\_map)}}.
An element of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ctrl\_map}} should look like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ctrl\_map{[}0{]} = width \textbar{} LV\_BTNM\_CTRL\_NO\_REPEAT \textbar{}  LV\_BTNM\_CTRL\_TGL\_ENABLE}}.
The number of elements should be equal to the number of buttons (excluding newlines characters).


\subsubsection{One check}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/btnmatrix:one-check}}
The "One check" feature can be enabled with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btnmatrix\_set\_one\_check(btnm, true)}} to allow only one button to be checked (toggled) at once.


\subsubsection{Recolor}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/btnmatrix:recolor}}
The \sphinxstylestrong{texts} on the button can be \sphinxstylestrong{recolored} similarly to the recolor feature for {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/label::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Label}}}} object. To enable it, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btnmatrix\_set\_recolor(btnm, true)}}.
After that a button with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\#FF0000 Red\#}} text will be red.


\subsubsection{Aligning the button's text}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/btnmatrix:aligning-the-button-s-text}}
To align the text on the buttons, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btnmatrix\_set\_align(roller, LV\_LABEL\_ALIGN\_LEFT/CENTER/RIGHT)}}.
All text items in the button matrix will conform to the alignment proprty as it is set.


\subsubsection{Notes}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/btnmatrix:notes}}
The Button matrix object is very light weighted because the buttons are not created just virtually drawn on the fly.
This way, 1 button use only 8 extra bytes instead of the \textasciitilde{}100-150 byte size of a normal {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/btn::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Button}}}} object (plus the size of its container and a label for each button).

The disadvantage of this setup is that the ability to style individual buttons to be different from others is limited (aside from the toggling feature).
If you require that ability, using individual buttons is very likely to be a better approach.


\subsection{Events}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/btnmatrix:events}}
Besides the \sphinxhref{/overview/events.html\#generic-event}{Generic events}, the following \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#special-events}{Special events} are sent by the button matrices:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_VALUE\_CHANGED} - sent when the button is pressed/released or repeated after long press. The event data is set to the ID of the pressed/released button.

\end{itemize}

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\subsection{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/btnmatrix:keys}}
The following \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the Buttons:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_RIGHT/UP/LEFT/RIGHT} - To navigate among the buttons to select one

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_ENTER} - To press/release the selected button

\end{itemize}

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.

\pysigstopmultiline
Set a new map. Buttons will be created/deleted according to the map. The button matrix keeps a reference to the map and so the string array must not be deallocated during the life of the matrix. \begin{description}
\item[{\sphinxstylestrong{Parameters}}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{btnm}}: pointer to a button matrix object 

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{map}}: pointer a string array. The last string has to be: "". Use "\textbackslash{}n" to make a line break. 

\end{itemize}

\end{description}


\end{fulllineitems}

\pysigstopmultiline
Set the button control map (hidden, disabled etc.) for a button matrix. The control map array will be copied and so may be deallocated after this function returns. \begin{description}
\item[{\sphinxstylestrong{Parameters}}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{btnm}}: pointer to a button matrix object 

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ctrl\_map}}: pointer to an array of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btn\_ctrl\_t}} control bytes. The length of the array and position of the elements must match the number and order of the individual buttons (i.e. excludes newline entries). An element of the map should look like e.g.: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ctrl\_map{[}0{]} = width \textbar{} LV\_BTNMATRIX\_CTRL\_NO\_REPEAT \textbar{} LV\_BTNMATRIX\_CTRL\_TGL\_ENABLE}} 

\end{itemize}

\end{description}


\end{fulllineitems}

\section{Calendar (lv\_calendar)}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/calendar:calendar-lv-calendar}}\label{\detokenize{widgets/calendar::doc}}

\subsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/calendar:overview}}
The Calendar object is a classic calendar which can:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
highlight the current day

\item {} 
highlight any user-defined dates

\item {} 
display the name of the days

\item {} 
go the next/previous month by button click

\item {} 
highlight the clicked day

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Parts and Styles}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/calendar:parts-and-styles}}
The calendar's main part is called \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_CALENDAR\_PART\_BG}}. It draws a background using the typical background style properties.

Besides the following virtual parts exist:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_CALENDAR\_PART\_HEADER}} The upper area where the current year and month's name is shown. It also has buttons to move the next/previous month.
It uses typical background properties and padding to keep some distance from the background (top, left, right) and the day names (bottom).

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_CALENDAR\_PART\_DAY\_NAMES}} Shows the name of the days below the header. It uses the \sphinxstyleemphasis{text} style properties padding to keep some distance from the background (left, right), header (top) and dates (bottom).

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_CALENDAR\_PART\_DATES}} Show the date numbers from 1..28/29/30/31 (depending on current month). Different "state" of the states are drawn according to the states defined in this part:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
normal dates: drawn with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_STATE\_DEFAULT}} style

\item {} 
pressed date: drawn with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_STATE\_PRESSED}} style

\item {} 
today: drawn with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_STATE\_FOCUSED}} style

\item {} 
highlighted dates: drawn with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_STATE\_CHECKED}} style

\end{itemize}

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/calendar:usage}}

\subsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/calendar:id1}}
To set and get dates in the calendar, the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_calendar\_date\_t}} type is used which is a structure with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{year}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{month}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{day}} fields.


\subsubsection{Current date}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/calendar:current-date}}
To set the current date (today), use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_calendar\_set\_today\_date(calendar, \&today\_date)}} function.


\subsubsection{Shown date}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/calendar:shown-date}}
To set the shown date, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_calendar\_set\_shown\_date(calendar, \&shown\_date)}};


\subsubsection{Highlighted days}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/calendar:highlighted-days}}
The list of highlighted dates should be stored in a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_calendar\_date\_t}} array loaded by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_calendar\_set\_highlighted\_dates(calendar, \&highlighted\_dates)}}.Only the arrays pointer will be saved so the array should be a static or global variable.


\subsubsection{Name of the days}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/calendar:name-of-the-days}}
The name of the days can be adjusted with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_calendar\_set\_day\_names(calendar, day\_names)}} where \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{day\_names}} looks like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{const char * day\_names{[}7{]} = \{"Su", "Mo", ...\};}}


\subsubsection{Name of the months}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/calendar:name-of-the-months}}
Similarly to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{day\_names}}, the name of the month can be set with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_calendar\_set\_month\_names(calendar, month\_names\_array)}}.


\subsection{Events}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/calendar:events}}
Besides the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events}, the following \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#special-events}{Special events} are sent by the calendars:
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_VALUE\_CHANGED} is sent when the current month has changed.

In \sphinxstyleemphasis{Input device related} events, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_calendar\_get\_pressed\_date(calendar)}} tells which day is currently being pressed or return \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} if no date is pressed.


\subsection{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/calendar:keys}}
No \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.


\subsection{Example}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/calendar:example}}

\label{\detokenize{widgets/calendar:c}}

\section{Canvas (lv\_canvas)}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/canvas:canvas-lv-canvas}}\label{\detokenize{widgets/canvas::doc}}

\subsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/canvas:overview}}
A Canvas inherites from {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/img::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Image}}}} where the user can draw anything. Rectangles, texts, images, lines arcs can be drawn here using lvgl's drawing engine.
Besides some "effects" can be applied as well like rotation, zoom and blur.


\subsection{Parts and Styles}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/canvas:parts-and-styles}}
The Canvas has on one main part called \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_CANVAS\_PART\_MAIN}} and only the \sphinxstyleemphasis{image\_recolor} property is used to give a color to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_ALPHA\_1/2/4/8BIT}} images.


\subsection{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/canvas:usage}}

\subsubsection{Buffer}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/canvas:buffer}}
The Canvas needs a buffer which stores the drawn image.
To assign a buffer to a Canvas, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_set\_buffer(canvas, buffer, width, height, LV\_IMG\_CF\_...)}}.
Where  \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{buffer}} is a static buffer (not just a local variable) to hold the image of the canvas.
For example,
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{static lv\_color\_t buffer{[}LV\_CANVAS\_BUF\_SIZE\_TRUE\_COLOR(width, height){]}}}. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_CANVAS\_BUF\_SIZE\_...}} macros help to determine the size of the buffer with different color formats.

The canvas supports all the built-in color formats like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_INDEXED\_2BIT}}.
See the full list in the \sphinxhref{/overview/image.html\#color-formats}{Color formats} section.


\subsubsection{Palette}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/canvas:palette}}
For \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_INDEXED\_...}} color formats, a palette needs to be initialized with  \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_set\_palette(canvas, 3, LV\_COLOR\_RED)}}. It sets pixels with \sphinxstyleemphasis{index=3} to red.


\subsubsection{Drawing}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/canvas:drawing}}
To set a pixel on the canvas, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_set\_px(canvas, x, y, LV\_COLOR\_RED)}}.
With \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_INDEXED\_...}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_ALPHA\_...}}, the index of the color or the alpha value needs to be passed as color. E.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_color\_t c; c.full = 3;}}

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_fill\_bg(canvas, LV\_COLOR\_BLUE, LV\_OPA\_50)}} fills the whole canvas to blue with 50\% opacity. Note that, if the current color format doesn't support colors (e.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_ALPHA\_2BIT}}) teh color will be ignored.
Similarly, if opacity is not supported (e.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_TRUE\_COLOR}}) it will be ignored.

An array of pixels can be copied to the canvas with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_copy\_buf(canvas, buffer\_to\_copy, x, y, width, height)}}. The color format of the buffer and the canvas need to match.

To draw something to the canvas use
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_draw\_rect(canvas, x, y, width, heigth, \&draw\_dsc)}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_draw\_text(canvas, x, y, max\_width, \&draw\_dsc, txt, LV\_LABEL\_ALIGN\_LEFT/CENTER/RIGHT)}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_draw\_img(canvas, x, y, \&img\_src, \&draw\_dsc)}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_draw\_line(canvas, point\_array, point\_cnt, \&draw\_dsc)}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_draw\_polygon(canvas, points\_array, point\_cnt, \&draw\_dsc)}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_draw\_arc(canvas, x, y, radius, start\_angle, end\_angle, \&draw\_dsc)}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{draw\_dsc}} is a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_draw\_rect/label/img/line\_dsc\_t}} variable which should be first initialized with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_draw\_rect/label/img/line\_dsc\_init()}} function and then it's filed should be modified with the desired colors and other values.

The draw function can draw to any color format. For example, it's possible to draw a text to an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_VF\_ALPHA\_8BIT}} canvas and use the result image as a mask in {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/objmask::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{lv\_objmask}}}} later.


\subsubsection{Transformations}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/canvas:transformations}}
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_transform()}} can be used to rotate and/or scale the image of an image and store the result on the canvas. The function needs the following parameters:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{canvas}} pointer to a canvas object to store the result of the transformation.

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{img pointer}} to an image descriptor to transform. Can be the image descriptor of an other canvas too (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_get\_img()}}).

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{angle}} the angle of rotation (0..3600), 0.1 deg resolution

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{zoom}} zoom factor (256 no zoom, 512 double size, 128 half size);

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{offset\_x}} offset X to tell where to put the result data on destination canvas

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{offset\_y}} offset X to tell where to put the result data on destination canvas

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pivot\_x}} pivot X of rotation. Relative to the source canvas. Set to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{source width / 2}} to rotate around the center

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pivot\_y}} pivot Y of rotation. Relative to the source canvas. Set to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{source height / 2}} to rotate around the center

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{antialias}} true: apply anti-aliasing during the transformation. Looks better but slower.

\end{itemize}

Note that a canvas can't be rotated on itself.  You need a source and destination canvas or image.


\subsection{Blur}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/canvas:blur}}
A given area of the canvas can be blurred horizontally with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_blur\_hor(canvas, \&area, r)}} ot vertically with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_canvas\_blur\_ver(canvas, \&area, r)}}.
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{r}} is the radius of the blur (greater value means more intensive burring). \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{area}} is the area where the blur should be applied (interpreted relative to the canvas)


\subsection{Events}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/canvas:events}}
As default the clicking of a canvas is disabled (inherited by {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/img::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Image}}}}) and therefore no events are generated.

If clicking is enabled (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_click(canvas, true)}}) only the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} are sent by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\subsection{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/canvas:keys}}
No \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.


\subsection{Example}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/canvas:example}}

\subsubsection{C}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/canvas:c}}

\section{Checkbox (lv\_cb)}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/checkbox:checkbox-lv-cb}}\label{\detokenize{widgets/checkbox::doc}}

\subsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/checkbox:overview}}
The Checkbox objects are built from a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/btn::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Button}}}} background which contains an also Button \sphinxstyleemphasis{bullet} and a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/label::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Label}}}} to realize a classical checkbox.


\subsection{Parts and Styles}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/checkbox:parts-and-styles}}
The Check box's main part is called \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_CHECKBOX\_PART\_BG}}. It's a container for a "bullet" and a text next to it. The background uses all the typical background style properties.

The bullet is real {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/obj::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{lv\_obj}}}} object and can be referred with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_CHACKBOX\_PART\_BULLET}}.
The bullet automatically inherits the state of the background. So the background is pressed the bullet goes to pressed state as well.
The bullet also uses all the typical background style properties.

There is not dedicated part for the label. Its styles can be set in the background's styles because the \sphinxstyleemphasis{text} styles properties are always inherited.


\subsection{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/checkbox:usage}}

\subsubsection{Text}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/checkbox:text}}
The text can be modified by the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_checkbox\_set\_text(cb, "New text")}} function. It will dynamically allocate the text.

To set a static text, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_checkbox\_set\_static\_text(cb, txt)}}. This way, only a pointer of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{txt}} will be stored and it shouldn't be deallocated while the checkbox exists.


\subsubsection{Check/Uncheck}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/checkbox:check-uncheck}}
You can manually check / un-check the Checkbox  via \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_checkbox\_set\_checked(cb, true/false)}}. Setting \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{true}} will check the checkbox and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{false}} will un-check the checkbox.


\subsubsection{Disabled}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/checkbox:disabled}}
To make the Checkbox disabled, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_checkbox\_set\_disabled(cb, true)}}.


\subsection{Events}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/checkbox:events}}
Besides the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} the following \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#special-events}{Special events} are sent by the Checkboxes:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_VALUE\_CHANGED} - sent when the checkbox is toggled.

\end{itemize}

Note that, the generic input device-related events (like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_EVENT\_PRESSED}}) are sent in the inactive state too. You need to check the state with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_cb\_is\_inactive(cb)}} to ignore the events from inactive Checkboxes.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\subsection{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/checkbox:keys}}
The following \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the 'Buttons':
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_RIGHT/UP} - Go to toggled state if toggling is enabled

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_LEFT/DOWN} - Go to non-toggled state if toggling is  enabled

\end{itemize}

Note that, as usual, the state of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_KEY\_ENTER}} is translated to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_EVENT\_PRESSED/PRESSING/RELEASED}} etc.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.


\subsection{Example}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/checkbox:example}}

\subsubsection{C}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/checkbox:c}}

\paragraph{Simple Checkbox}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/checkbox:simple-checkbox}}
