\section{Chart (lv\_chart)}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/chart:chart-lv-chart}}\label{\detokenize{widgets/chart::doc}}

\subsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/chart:overview}}
Charts are basic object to visualize data points.
It support \sphinxstyleemphasis{Line} charts (connect points with lines and/or draw points on them) and \sphinxstyleemphasis{Column} chart.

Chart also support division lines, 2 y axis, axis ticks, and texts on ticks.


\subsection{Parts and Styles}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/chart:parts-and-styles}}
The Chart's main part is called \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_CHART\_PART\_BG}} and it uses all the typical background properties.
The \sphinxstyleemphasis{text} style properties determine the style of the axis texts and the \sphinxstyleemphasis{line} properties determine ticks' style.
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Padding} values add some space on the sides thus it makes \sphinxstyleemphasis{series area} smaller. Padding also can be used to make space for axis texts and ticks.

The background of the series is called \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_CHART\_PART\_SERIES\_BG}} and it's placed on the main background.
The division lines, and series data is drawn on this part. Besides the typical background style properties
the \sphinxstyleemphasis{line} style properties are used by the division lines. The \sphinxstyleemphasis{padding} values tells the space between the this part and the axis texts.

The style of the series can be referenced by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_CHART\_PART\_SERIES}}. In case of column type the following properties are used:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{radius}: radius of the bars

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{padding\_inner}: space between the columns of the same x coordinate

\end{itemize}

In case of Line type these properties are used:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{line properties} to describe the lines

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{size} radius of the points

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{bg\_opa}: the overall opacity of the area below the lines

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{bg\_main\_stop}: \% of \sphinxstyleemphasis{bg\_opa} at the top to create an alpha fade (0: transparent at the top, 255: \sphinxstyleemphasis{bg\_opa} at the top)

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{bg\_grad\_stop}: \%  of \sphinxstyleemphasis{bg\_opa} at the bottom to create an alpha fade  (0: transparent at the bottom, 255: \sphinxstyleemphasis{bg\_opa} at the top)

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{bg\_drag\_dir}: should be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_GRAD\_DIR\_VER}} to allow alpha fading with \sphinxstyleemphasis{bg\_main\_stop} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{bg\_grad\_stop}

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/chart:usage}}

\subsubsection{Data series}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/chart:data-series}}
You can add any number of series to the charts by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_add\_series(chart, color)}}.
It allocates data for a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_series\_t}} structure which contains the chosen \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{color}} and an array for the data points.


\subsubsection{Series' type}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/chart:series-type}}
The following \sphinxstylestrong{data display types} exist:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CHART\_TYPE\_NONE} - Do not display any data. It can be used to hide a series.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CHART\_TYPE\_LINE} - Draw lines between the points.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CHART\_TYPE\_COLUMN} - Draw columns.

\end{itemize}

You can specify the display type with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_type(chart, LV\_CHART\_TYPE\_...)}}. The types can be 'OR'ed (like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_CHART\_TYPE\_LINE}}).


\subsubsection{Modify the data}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/chart:modify-the-data}}
You have several options to set the data of series:
\begin{enumerate}
\def\theenumi{\arabic{enumi}}
\def\labelenumi{\theenumi .}
\makeatletter\def\p@enumii{\p@enumi \theenumi .}\makeatother
\item {} 
Set the values manually in the array like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ser1-\textgreater{}points{[}3{]} = 7}} and refresh the chart with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_refresh(chart)}}.

\item {} 
Use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_next(chart, ser, value)}}.

\item {} 
Initialize all points to a given value with: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_init\_points(chart, ser, value)}}.

\item {} 
Set all points from an array with: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_points(chart, ser, value\_array)}}.

\end{enumerate}

Use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_CHART\_POINT\_DEF}} as value to make the library skip drawing that point, column, or line segment.


\subsubsection{Update modes}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/chart:update-modes}}
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_next}} can behave in two ways depending on \sphinxstyleemphasis{update mode}:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CHART\_UPDATE\_MODE\_SHIFT} - Shift old data to the left and add the new one o the right.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_CHART\_UPDATE\_MODE\_CIRCULAR} - Circularly add the new data (Like an ECG diagram).

\end{itemize}

The update mode can be changed with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_update\_mode(chart, LV\_CHART\_UPDATE\_MODE\_...)}}.


\subsubsection{Number of points}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/chart:number-of-points}}
The number of points in the series can be modified by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_point\_count(chart, point\_num)}}. The default value is 10.


\subsubsection{Vertical range}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/chart:vertical-range}}
You can specify the minimum and maximum values in y-direction with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_range(chart, y\_min, y\_max)}}. The value of the points will be scaled proportionally. The default range is: 0..100.


\subsubsection{Division lines}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/chart:division-lines}}
The number of horizontal and vertical division lines can be modified by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_div\_line\_count(chart, hdiv\_num, vdiv\_num)}}. The default settings are 3 horizontal and 5 vertical division lines.


\subsubsection{Tick marks and labels}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/chart:tick-marks-and-labels}}
Ticks and labels can be added to the axis.

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_x\_tick\_text(chart, list\_of\_values, num\_tick\_marks, LV\_CHART\_AXIS\_...)}} set the ticks and texts on x axis.
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{list\_of\_values}} is a string with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{'\textbackslash{}n'}} terminated text (expect the last) with text for the ticks. E.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{const char * list\_of\_values = "first\textbackslash{}nsec\textbackslash{}nthird"}}. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{list\_of\_values}} can be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}}.
If \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{list\_of\_values}} is set then \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{num\_tick\_marks}} tells the number of ticks between two labels.  If \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{list\_of\_values}} is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} then it specifies the total number of ticks.

\sphinxstyleemphasis{Major tick lines} are drawn where text is placed, and \sphinxstyleemphasis{minor tick lines} are drawn elsewhere. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_x\_tick\_length(chart, major\_tick\_len, minor\_tick\_len)}} sets the length of tick lines on the x-axis.

The same functions exists for the y axis too: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_y\_tick\_text}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_chart\_set\_y\_tick\_length}}.


\subsection{Events}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/chart:events}}
Only the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} are sent by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\subsection{Keys}

\section{Container (lv\_cont)}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/cont:container-lv-cont}}\label{\detokenize{widgets/cont::doc}}

\subsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/cont:overview}}
The containers are essentially a \sphinxstylestrong{basic object} with some special features.


\subsubsection{Layout}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/cont:layout}}
You can apply a layout on the containers to automatically order their children. The layout spacing comes from \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{style.body.padding. ...}} properties. The possible layout options:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LAYOUT\_OFF} - Do not align the children.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LAYOUT\_CENTER} - Align children to the center in column and keep \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.inner}} space between them.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LAYOUT\_COL\_} - Align children in a left-justified column. Keep \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.left}} space on the left, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pad.top}} space on the top and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.inner}} space between the children.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LAYOUT\_COL\_M} - Align children in centered column. Keep \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.top}} space on the top and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.inner}} space between the children.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LAYOUT\_COL\_R} - Align children in a right-justified column. Keep \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.right}} space on the right, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.top}} space on the top and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.inner}} space between the children.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LAYOUT\_ROW\_T} - Align children in a top justified row. Keep \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.left}} space on the left, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.top}} space on the top and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.inner}} space between the children.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LAYOUT\_ROW\_M} - Align children in centered row. Keep \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.left}} space on the left and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.inner}} space between the children.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LAYOUT\_ROW\_B} - Align children in a bottom justified row. Keep \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.left}} space on the left, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.bottom}} space on the bottom and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.inner}} space between the children.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LAYOUT\_PRETTY} - Put as many objects as possible in a row (with at least \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.inner}} space and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.left/right}} space on the sides). Divide the space in each line equally between the children.
Keep \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.top}} space on the top and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pad.inner}} space between the lines.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LAYOUT\_GRID} - Similar to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LAYOUT\_PRETTY}} but not divide horizontal space equally just let \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.left/right}} on the edges and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.inner}} space between the elements.

\end{itemize}


\subsubsection{Autofit}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/cont:autofit}}
Container have an autofit feature which can automatically change the size of the container according to its children and/or parent. The following options exist:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_FIT\_NONE} - Do not change the size automatically.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_FIT\_TIGHT} - Shrink-wrap the container around all of its children, while keeping \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.top/bottom/left/right}} space on the edges.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_FIT\_FLOOD} - Set the size to the parent's size minus \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{padding.top/bottom/left/right}} (from the parent's style) space.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_FIT\_FILL} - Use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FIT\_FLOOD}} while smaller than the parent and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FIT\_TIGHT}} when larger. It will ensure that the container is, at minimum, the size of its parent.

\end{itemize}

To set the auto fit mode for all directions, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_cont\_set\_fit(cont, LV\_FIT\_...)}}.
To use different auto fit horizontally and vertically, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_cont\_set\_fit2(cont, hor\_fit\_type, ver\_fit\_type)}}.
To use different auto fit in all 4 directions, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_cont\_set\_fit4(cont, left\_fit\_type, right\_fit\_type, top\_fit\_type, bottom\_fit\_type)}}.


\subsection{Styles}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/cont:styles}}
You can set the styles with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_cont\_set\_style(btn, LV\_CONT\_STYLE\_MAIN, \&style)}}.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{style.body} properties are used.

\end{itemize}

\section{color picker (lv\_cpicker)}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/cpicker:color-picker-lv-cpicker}}\label{\detokenize{widgets/cpicker::doc}}

\subsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/cpicker:overview}}
As its name implies \sphinxstyleemphasis{Color picker} allows to select color. The Hue, Saturation and Value of the color can be selected after each other.

The widget has two forms: circle (disc) and rectangle.

In both forms, be long pressing the object, the color picker will change to the next parameter of the color (hue, saturation or value).
Besides, double click will reset the current parameter.


\subsection{Parts and Styles}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/cpicker:parts-and-styles}}
The Color picker's main part is called \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_CPICKER\_PART\_BG}}. In circular form it uses \sphinxstyleemphasis{scale\_width} to set the the width of the circle and \sphinxstyleemphasis{pad\_inner} for padding between the circle and the inner preview circle.
In rectangle mode \sphinxstyleemphasis{radius} can be used to apply a radius on the rectangle.

The object has  virtual part called \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_CPICKER\_PART\_KNOB}} which is rectangle (or circle) drawn on the current value.
It uses all the rectangle like style properties and padding to make it larger than the width of the circle or rectangle background.


\subsection{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/cpicker:usage}}

\subsubsection{Type}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/cpicker:type}}
The type of the Color picker can be changed with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_cpicker\_set\_type(cpicker, LV\_CPICKER\_TYPE\_RECT/DISC)}}


\subsubsection{Set color}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/cpicker:set-color}}
The colro can be set manually with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_cpicker\_set\_hue/saturation/value(cpicker, x)}} or all at once with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_cpicker\_set\_hsv(cpicker, hsv)}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_cpicker\_set\_color(cpicker, rgb)}}


\subsubsection{Color mode}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/cpicker:color-mode}}
The current color moed can be manually selected with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_cpicker\_set\_color\_mode(cpicker, LV\_CPICKER\_COLOR\_MODE\_HUE/SATURATION/VALUE)}}.

The color moe be fixed (do not change with long press) using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_cpicker\_set\_color\_mode\_fixed(cpicker, true)}}


\subsubsection{Knob color}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/cpicker:knob-color}}
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_cpicker\_set\_knob\_colored(cpicker, true)}} make the knob to automatically show the selected color as background color.


\subsection{Events}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/cpicker:events}}
Only the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} are sent by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\subsection{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/cpicker:keys}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_UP}, \sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_RIGHT} Increment the current parameter's value by 1

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_DOWN}, \sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_LEFT} Decrement the current parameter's by 1

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_ENTER} By long press the next mode will be shown. By double click the current parameter will be reset.

\end{itemize}

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.


\subsection{Example}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/cpicker:example}}

\section{Drop-down list (lv\_dropdown)}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/dropdown:drop-down-list-lv-dropdown}}\label{\detokenize{widgets/dropdown::doc}}

\subsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/dropdown:overview}}
The drop-down list allows the user to select one value from a list.

The drop-down list is closed by default and displays a single value or a predefined text.
When activated (by click on the drop-down list), a list is created from which the user may select one option.
When the user selects a new value, the list is deleted.


\subsection{Parts and Styles}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/dropdown:parts-and-styles}}
The drop-down list's main part is called \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_DROPDOWN\_PART\_MAIN}} which is a simple {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/obj::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{lv\_obj}}}} object.
It uses all the typical background properties. \sphinxstyleemphasis{Pressed}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{Focused}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{Edited} etc. stiles are also applied as usual.

The list, which is created when the main object is clicked, is an {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/page::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Page}}}}.
Its background part can be referenced with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_DROPDOWN\_PART\_LIST}} and uses all the typical background properties for the rectangle itself and text properties for the options.
To adjust the space between the options use the \sphinxstyleemphasis{text\_line\_space} style property.
Padding values can be used to make some space on the edges.

The scrollable part of the page is hidden and its styles are always empty (so transparent with no padding).

The scrollbar can be referenced with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_DROPDOWN\_PART\_SCRLBAR}} and uses all the typical background properties.

The selected option can be referenced with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_DROPDOWN\_PART\_SELECTED}} and uses all the typical background properties.
It will used in its default state to draw a rectangle on the selected option, and in pressed state to draw a rectangle on the being pressed option.


\subsection{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/dropdown:usage}}

\subsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/dropdown:id1}}

\subsubsection{Set options}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/dropdown:set-options}}
The options are passed to the drop-down list as a string with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_dropdown\_set\_options(dropdown, options)}}. The options should be separated by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textbackslash{}n}}. For example: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"First\textbackslash{}nSecond\textbackslash{}nThird"}}.
The string will be saved in the drop-down list, so it can in local variable too.

The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_dropdown\_add\_option(dropdown, "New option", pos)}} function inserts a new option to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pos}} index.

To save memory the options can set from a static(constant) string too with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_dropdown\_set\_static\_options(dropdown, options)}}.
In this case the options string should be alive while the drop-down list exists and  \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_dropdown\_add\_option}} can't be used

You can select an option manually with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_dropdown\_set\_selected(dropdown, id)}}, where \sphinxstyleemphasis{id} is the index of an option.


\subsubsection{Get selected option}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/dropdown:get-selected-option}}
The get the currently selected option, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_dropdown\_get\_selected(dropdown)}}. It will return the \sphinxstyleemphasis{index} of the selected option.

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_dropdown\_get\_selected\_str(dropdown, buf, buf\_size)}} copies the name of the selected option to a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{buf}}.


\subsubsection{Direction}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/dropdown:direction}}
The list can be created on any side. The default \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_DROPDOWN\_DOWN}} can be modified by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_dropdown\_set\_dir(dropdown, LV\_DROPDOWN\_DIR\_LEFT/RIGHT/UP/DOWN)}} function.

If the list would be vertically out of the screen, it will aligned to the edge.


\subsubsection{Symbol}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/dropdown:symbol}}
A symbol (typically an arrow) can be added to the drop down list with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_dropdown\_set\_symbol(dropdown, LV\_SYMBOL\_...)}}

If the direction of the drop-down list is  \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_DROPDOWN\_DIR\_LEFT}} the symbol will be shown on the left, else on the right.


\subsubsection{Maximum height}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/dropdown:maximum-height}}
The maximum height of drop-down list can be set via \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_dropdown\_set\_max\_height(dropdown, height)}}. By default it's set to 3/4 vertical resolution.


\subsubsection{Show selected}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/dropdown:show-selected}}
The main part can either show the selected option or a static text. It can  controlled with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_dropdown\_set\_show\_selected(sropdown, true/false)}}.

The static text can be set with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_dropdown\_set\_text(dropdown, "Text")}}. Only the pointer of the text is saved.


\subsubsection{Animation time}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/dropdown:animation-time}}
The drop-down list's open/close animation time is adjusted by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_dropdown\_set\_anim\_time(ddlist, anim\_time)}}. Zero animation time means no animation.


\subsubsection{Manually open/close}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/dropdown:manually-open-close}}
To manually open or close the drop-down list the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_dropdown\_open/close(dropdown, LV\_ANIM\_ON/OFF)}} function can be used.


\subsection{Events}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/dropdown:events}}
Besides the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events}, the following \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#special-events}{Special events} are sent by the drop-down list:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_VALUE\_CHANGED} - Sent when the new option is selected.

\end{itemize}

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\subsection{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/dropdown:keys}}
The following \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the Buttons:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_RIGHT/DOWN} - Select the next option.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_LEFT/UP} - Select the previous option.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LY\_KEY\_ENTER} - Apply the selected option (Send \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_EVENT\_VALUE\_CHANGED}} event and close the drop-down list).

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Example}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/dropdown:example}}

\section{Gauge (lv\_gauge)}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/gauge:gauge-lv-gauge}}\label{\detokenize{widgets/gauge::doc}}

\subsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/gauge:overview}}
The gauge is a meter with scale labels and one or more needles.


\subsection{Parts and Styles}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/gauge:parts-and-styles}}
The Gauge's main part is called \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_GAUGE\_PART\_MAIN}}. It draws a background using the typical background style properties and "minor" scale lines using the \sphinxstyleemphasis{line} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{scale} style properties.
It also uses the \sphinxstyleemphasis{text} properties to set the style of the scale labels. \sphinxstyleemphasis{pad\_inner} is used to set space between the scale lines and the scale labels.

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_GAUGE\_PART\_MAJOR}} is a virtual part which describes the  major scale lines (where labels are added) using the \sphinxstyleemphasis{line} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{scale} style properties.

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_GAUGE\_PART\_NEEDLE}} is also virtual part and it describes the needle(s) via the \sphinxstyleemphasis{line} style properties.
\sphinxstyleemphasis{size} and the typical background properties are used to describe a rectangle (or circle) in the picot point of the needle(s).
\sphinxstyleemphasis{pad\_inner} is used to to make the needle(s) smaller than the outer radius of the scale lines.


\subsection{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/gauge:usage}}

\subsubsection{Set value and needles}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/gauge:set-value-and-needles}}
The gauge can show more than one needle.
Use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_gauge\_set\_needle\_count(gauge, needle\_num, color\_array)}} function to set the number of needles and an array with colors for each needle.
The array must be static or global variable because only its pointer is stored.

You can use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_gauge\_set\_value(gauge, needle\_id, value)}} to set the value of a needle.


\subsubsection{Scale}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/gauge:scale}}
You can use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_gauge\_set\_scale(gauge, angle, line\_num, label\_cnt)}} function to adjust the scale angle and the number of the scale lines and labels.
The default settings are 220 degrees, 6 scale labels, and 21 lines.

The scale of the Gauge can have offset. It can be adjusted with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_gauge\_set\_angle\_offset(gauge, angle)}}.


\subsubsection{Range}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/gauge:range}}
The range of the gauge can be specified by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_gauge\_set\_range(gauge, min, max)}}. The default range is 0..100.


\subsubsection{Critical value}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/gauge:critical-value}}
To set a critical value, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_gauge\_set\_critical\_value(gauge, value)}}. The scale color will be changed to \sphinxstyleemphasis{scale\_end\_color} after this value. The default critical value is 80.


\subsection{Events}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/gauge:events}}
Only the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} are sent by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\subsection{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/gauge:keys}}
No \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.


\subsection{Example}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/gauge:example}}

\subsubsection{C}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/gauge:c}}

\section{Image (lv\_img)}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/img:image-lv-img}}\label{\detokenize{widgets/img::doc}}

\subsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/img:overview}}
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Images} are the basic object to display from the flash (as arrays) or externally as files. Images can display symbols (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_SYMBOL\_...}}) too.

Using the \sphinxhref{/overview/images/\#image-decoder}{Image decoder interface} custom image formats can be supported as well.


\subsection{Parts and Styles}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/img:parts-and-styles}}
The images has only a main part called \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_PART\_MAIN}} which uses the typical background style propeties to draw a background rectangle and the \sphinxstyleemphasis{image} properties.
The padding values are used to make the background virtually larger. (It won't change the image's real size but the size modification is applied only during drawing)


\subsection{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/img:usage}}

\subsubsection{Image source}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/img:image-source}}
To provide maximum flexibility, the source of the image can be:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
a variable in the code (a C array with the pixels).

\item {} 
a file stored externally (like on an SD card).

\item {} 
a text with {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/font::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Symbols}}}}.

\end{itemize}

To set the source of an image, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_set\_src(img, src)}}.

To generate a \sphinxstylestrong{pixel array} from a PNG, JPG or BMP image, use the \sphinxhref{https://lvgl.io/tools/imageconverter}{Online image converter tool} and set the converted image with its pointer: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_set\_src(img1, \&converted\_img\_var);}}
To make the variable visible in the C file, you need to declare it with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_DECLARE(converted\_img\_var)}}.

To use \sphinxstylestrong{external files}, you also need to convert the image files using the online converter tool but now you should select the binary Output format.
You also need to use LVGL's file system module and register a driver with some functions for the basic file operation. Got to the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/file-system::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{File system}}}} to learn more.
To set an image sourced from a file, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_set\_src(img, "S:folder1/my\_img.bin")}}.

You can set a \sphinxstylestrong{symbol} similarly to {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/label::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Labels}}}}. In this case, the image will be rendered as text according to the \sphinxstyleemphasis{font} specified in the style.  It enables to use of light-weighted mono-color
"letters" instead of real images. You can set symbol like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_set\_src(img1, LV\_SYMBOL\_OK)}}.


\subsubsection{Label as an image}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/img:label-as-an-image}}
Images and labels are sometimes used to convey the same thing. For example, to describe what a button does. Therefore, images and labels are somewhat interchangeable.
To handle these images can even display texts by using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_SYMBOL\_DUMMY}} as the prefix of the text. For example, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_set\_src(img, LV\_SYMBOL\_DUMMY "Some text")}}.


\subsubsection{Transparency}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/img:transparency}}
The internal (variable) and external images support 2 transparency handling methods:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Chrome keying} - Pixels with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_COLOR\_TRANSP}} (\sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}) color will be transparent.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Alpha byte} - An alpha byte is added to every pixel.

\end{itemize}


\subsubsection{Palette and Alpha index}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/img:palette-and-alpha-index}}
Besides \sphinxstyleemphasis{True color} (RGB) color format, the following formats are also supported:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Indexed} - Image has a palette.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Alpha indexed} - Only alpha values are stored.

\end{itemize}

These options can be selected in the font converter. To learn more about the color formats, read the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/image::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Images}}}} section.


\subsubsection{Recolor}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/img:recolor}}
The images can be re-colored in run-time to any color according to the brightness of the pixels.
It is very useful to show different states (selected, inactive, pressed, etc.) of an image without storing more versions of the same image.
This feature can be enabled in the style by setting \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{img.intense}} between \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_OPA\_TRANSP}} (no recolor, value: 0) and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_OPA\_COVER}} (full recolor, value: 255).
The default value is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_OPA\_TRANSP}} so this feature is disabled.


\subsubsection{Auto-size}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/img:auto-size}}
It is possible to automatically set the size of the image object to the image source's width and height if enabled by the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_set\_auto\_size(image, true)}} function.
If \sphinxstyleemphasis{auto-size} is enabled, then when a new file is set, the object size is automatically changed. Later, you can modify the size manually. The \sphinxstyleemphasis{auto-size} is enabled by default if the image is not a screen.


\subsubsection{Mosaic}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/img:mosaic}}
If the object size is greater than the image size in any directions, then the image will be repeated like a mosaic.
It's a very useful feature to create a large image from only a very narrow source.
For example, you can have a \sphinxstyleemphasis{300 x 1} image with a special gradient and set it as a wallpaper using the mosaic feature.


\subsubsection{Offset}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/img:offset}}
With \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_set\_offset\_x(img, x\_ofs)}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_set\_offset\_y(img, y\_ofs)}}, you can add some offset to the displayed image.
It is useful if the object size is smaller than the image source size.
Using the offset parameter a \sphinxhref{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texture\_atlas}{Texture atlas} or a "running image" effect can be created by {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/animation::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Animating}}}} the x or y offset.


\subsection{Transformations}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/img:transformations}}
Using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_set\_zoom(img, factor)}} the images will be zoomed. Set \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{factor}} to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{256}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_ZOOM\_NONE}} to disable zooming.
A larger value enlarges the images (e.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{512}} double size), a smaller value shrinks it (e.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{128}} half size).
Fractional scale works as well. E.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{281}} for 10\% enlargement.

To rotate the image use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_set\_angle(img, angle)}}. Angle has 0.1 degree precision, so for 45.8° set 458.

By default, the pivot point of the rotation is the center of the image. It can be changed with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_set\_pivot(img, pivot\_x, pivot\_y)}}. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{0;0}} is the top left corner.

The quality of the transformation can be adjusted with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_img\_set\_antialias(img, true/false)}}. With enabled anti-aliasing the transformations has a higher quality but they are slower.

The transformations require the whole image to be available. Therefore indexed images (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_INDEXED\_...}}), alpha only images (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_CF\_ALPHA\_...}}) or images from files can be transformed.
In other words transformations work only on true color images stored as C array, or if a custom \sphinxhref{/overview/images\#image-edecoder}{Image decoder} returns the whole image.

Note that, the real coordinates of image object won't change during transformation. That is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_get\_width/height/x/y()}} will returned the original, non-zoomed coordinates.


\subsection{Rotate}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/img:rotate}}
The images can be rotated with


\subsection{Events}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/img:events}}
Only the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} are sent by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\subsection{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/img:keys}}
No \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.

\label{\detokenize{widgets/img:example}}

\section{Image button (lv\_imgbtn)}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/imgbtn:image-button-lv-imgbtn}}\label{\detokenize{widgets/imgbtn::doc}}

\subsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/imgbtn:overview}}
The Image button is very similar to the simple 'Button' object. The only difference is that, it displays user-defined images in each state instead of drawing a rectangle.
Before reading this section, please read the {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/btn::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Button}}}} section for better understanding.


\subsection{Parts and Styles}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/imgbtn:parts-and-styles}}
The Image button object has only a main part called \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMG\_BTN\_PART\_MAIN}} from where all \sphinxstyleemphasis{image} style properties are used.
It's possible to recolor the image in each state with \sphinxstyleemphasis{image\_recolor} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{image\_recolor\_opa} proeprties. For example, to make the image darker if it is pressed.


\subsection{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/imgbtn:usage}}

\subsubsection{Image sources}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/imgbtn:image-sources}}
To set the image in a state, use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_imgbtn\_set\_src(imgbtn, LV\_BTN\_STATE\_..., \&img\_src)}}.
The image sources works the same as described in the {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/img::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Image object}}}} except that, "Symbols" are not supported by the Image button.

If \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMGBTN\_TILED}} is enabled in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}, then \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_imgbtn\_set\_src\_tiled(imgbtn, LV\_BTN\_STATE\_..., \&img\_src\_left, \&img\_src\_mid, \&img\_src\_right)}} becomes available.
Using the tiled feature the \sphinxstyleemphasis{middle} image will be repeated to fill the width of the object.
Therefore with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_IMGBTN\_TILED}}, you can set the width of the Image button using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_width()}}. However, without this option, the width will be always the same as the image source's width.


\subsubsection{Button features}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/imgbtn:button-features}}
Similarly to normal Buttons \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_imgbtn\_set\_checkable(imgbtn, true/false)}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_imgbtn\_toggle(imgbtn)}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_imgbtn\_set\_state(imgbtn, LV\_BTN\_STATE\_...)}} also works.


\subsection{Events}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/imgbtn:events}}
Beside the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events}, the following \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#special-events}{Special events} are sent by the buttons:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_VALUE\_CHANGED} - Sent when the button is toggled.

\end{itemize}

Note that, the generic input device related events (like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_EVENT\_PRESSED}}) are sent in the inactive state too. You need to check the state with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_btn\_get\_state(btn)}} to ignore the events from inactive buttons.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\subsection{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/imgbtn:keys}}
The following \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the Buttons:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_RIGHT/UP} - Go to toggled state if toggling is enabled.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_LEFT/DOWN} - Go to non-toggled state if toggling is  enabled.

\end{itemize}

Note that, as usual, the state of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_KEY\_ENTER}} is translated to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_EVENT\_PRESSED/PRESSING/RELEASED}} etc.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.


\subsection{Example}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/imgbtn:example}}

\subsubsection{C}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/imgbtn:c}}

\paragraph{Simple Image button}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/imgbtn:simple-image-button}}
\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{lv_ex_imgbtn_1}.png}

code

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+cp}{\PYGZsh{}}\PYG{c+cp}{include} \PYG{c+cpf}{\PYGZdq{}../../../lv\PYGZus{}examples.h\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{c+cp}{\PYGZsh{}}\PYG{c+cp}{if LV\PYGZus{}USE\PYGZus{}IMGBTN}

\PYG{k+kt}{void} \PYG{n+nf}{lv\PYGZus{}ex\PYGZus{}imgbtn\PYGZus{}1}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{k+kt}{void}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}IMG\PYGZus{}DECLARE}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{imgbtn\PYGZus{}green}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}IMG\PYGZus{}DECLARE}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{imgbtn\PYGZus{}blue}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

    \PYG{c+cm}{/*Darken the button when pressed*/}
    \PYG{k}{static} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{style}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}style\PYGZus{}init}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{style}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

\section{Keyboard (lv\_keyboard)}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/keyboard:keyboard-lv-keyboard}}\label{\detokenize{widgets/keyboard::doc}}

\subsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/keyboard:overview}}
The Keyboard object is a special {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/btnmatrix::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Button matrix}}}} with predefined keymaps and other features to realize a virtual keyboard to write text.


\subsection{Parts and Styles}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/keyboard:parts-and-styles}}
Similarly to Button matices Keyboards consist of 2 part:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_KEYBOARD\_PART\_BG}} which is the main part and uses all the typical background properties

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_KEYBOARD\_PART\_BTN}} which is virtual part for the buttons. It also uses all typical backround proeprties and the \sphinxstyleemphasis{text} properties.

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/keyboard:usage}}

\subsubsection{Modes}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/keyboard:modes}}
The Keyboards have thefollowing modes:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEYBOARD\_MODE\_TEXT\_LOWER} - Display lower case letters

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEYBOARD\_MODE\_TEXT\_UPPER} - Display upper case letters

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEYBOARD\_MODE\_TEXT\_SPECIAL} - Display special characters

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEYBOARD\_MODE\_NUM} - Display numbers, +/- sign, and decimal dot.

\end{itemize}

The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{TEXT}} modes' layout contains buttons to change mode.

To set the mode manually, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_keyboard\_set\_mode(kb, mode)}}. The default more is  \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_KEYBOARD\_MODE\_TEXT\_UPPER}}.


\subsubsection{Assign Text area}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/keyboard:assign-text-area}}
You can assign a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/textarea::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Text area}}}} to the Keyboard to automatically put the clicked characters there.
To assign the text area, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_keyboard\_set\_textarea(kb, ta)}}.

The assigned text area's \sphinxstylestrong{cursor can be managed} by the keyboard: when the keyboard is assigned, the previous text area's cursor will be hidden and the new one will be shown.
When the keyboard is closed by the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Ok} or \sphinxstyleemphasis{Close} buttons, the cursor also will be hidden. The cursor manager feature is enabled by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_keyboard\_set\_cursor\_manage(kb, true)}}. The default is not managed.


\subsubsection{New Keymap}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/keyboard:new-keymap}}
You can specify a new map (layout) for the keyboard with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_keyboard\_set\_map(kb, map)}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_keyboard\_set\_ctrl\_map(kb, ctrl\_map)}}.
Learn more about the {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/btnmatrix::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Button matrix}}}} object.
Keep in mind that, using following keywords will have the same effect as with the original map:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{LV\_SYMBOL\_OK} - Apply.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{LV\_SYMBOL\_CLOSE} - Close.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{LV\_SYMBOL\_BACKSPACE} - Delete on the left.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{LV\_SYMBOL\_LEFT} - Move the cursor left.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{LV\_SYMBOL\_RIGHT} - Move the cursor right.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{"ABC"} - Load the uppercase map.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{"abc"} - Load the lower case map.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{"Enter"} - New line.

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Events}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/keyboard:events}}
Besides the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events}, the following \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#special-events}{Special events} are sent by the keyboards:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_VALUE\_CHANGED} - Sent when the button is pressed/released or repeated after long press. The event data is set to the ID of the pressed/released button.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_APPLY} - The \sphinxstyleemphasis{Ok} button is clicked.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_CANCEL} - The \sphinxstyleemphasis{Close} button is clicked.

\end{itemize}

The keyboard has a \sphinxstylestrong{default event handler} callback called \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_keyboard\_def\_event\_cb}}.
It handles the button pressing, map changing, the assigned text area, etc.
You can completely replace it with your custom event handler however, you can call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_keyboard\_def\_event\_cb}} at the beginning of your event handler to handle the same things as before.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\subsection{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/keyboard:keys}}
The following \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the buttons:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_RIGHT/UP/LEFT/RIGHT} - To navigate among the buttons and select one.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_ENTER} - To press/release the selected button.

\end{itemize}

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.


\subsection{Examples}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/keyboard:examples}}

\section{Label (lv\_label)}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/label:label-lv-label}}\label{\detokenize{widgets/label::doc}}

\subsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/label:overview}}
A label is the basic object type that is used to display text.


\subsection{Parts and Styles}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/label:parts-and-styles}}
The label has only a main part, called \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LABEL\_PART\_MAIN}}. It uses all the typical background properties and the \sphinxstyleemphasis{text} properties.
The padding values can be used to make the area for the text small in the related direction.


\subsection{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/label:usage}}

\subsubsection{Set text}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/label:set-text}}
You can set the text on a label at runtime with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_text(label, "New text")}}.
It will allocate a buffer dynamically, and the provided string will be copied into that buffer.
Therefore, you don't need to keep the text you pass to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_text}} in scope after that function returns.

With \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_text\_fmt(label, "Value: \%d", 15)}} \sphinxstylestrong{printf formatting} can be used to set the text.

Labels are able to show text from a \sphinxstylestrong{static character buffer} which is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textbackslash{}0}}-terminated.
To do so, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_static\_text(label, "Text")}}.
In this case, the text is not stored in the dynamic memory and the given buffer is used directly instead.
This means that the array can't be a local variable which goes out of scope when the function exits.
Constant strings are safe to use with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_static\_text}} (except when used with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LABEL\_LONG\_DOT}}, as it modifies the buffer in-place), as they are stored in ROM memory, which is always accessible.

You can also use a \sphinxstylestrong{raw array} as label text.
The array doesn't have to be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textbackslash{}0}} terminated.
In this case, the text will be saved to the dynamic memory like with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_text}}.
To set a raw character array, use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_array\_text(label, char\_array, size)}} function.


\subsubsection{Line break}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/label:line-break}}
Line breaks are handled automatically by the label object. You can use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textbackslash{}n}} to make a line break. For example: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"line1\textbackslash{}nline2\textbackslash{}n\textbackslash{}nline4"}}


\subsubsection{Long modes}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/label:long-modes}}
By default, the width of the label object automatically expands to the text size. Otherwise, the text can be manipulated according to several long mode policies:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LABEL\_LONG\_EXPAND} - Expand the object size to the text size (Default)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LABEL\_LONG\_BREAK} - Keep the object width, break (wrap) the too long lines and expand the object height

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LABEL\_LONG\_DOT} - Keep the object size, break the text and write dots in the last line (\sphinxstylestrong{not supported when using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_static\_text}}})

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LABEL\_LONG\_SROLL} - Keep the size and scroll the label back and forth

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LABEL\_LONG\_SROLL\_CIRC} - Keep the size and scroll the label circularly

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_LABEL\_LONG\_CROP} - Keep the size and crop the text out of it

\end{itemize}

You can specify the long mode with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_long\_mode(label, LV\_LABEL\_LONG\_...)}}

It's important to note that, when a label is created and its text is set, the label's size already expanded to the text size.
In addition with the default \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LABEL\_LONG\_EXPAND}}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{long mode} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_width/height/size()}} has no effect.

So you need to change the \sphinxstyleemphasis{long mode} first set the new \sphinxstyleemphasis{long mode} and then set the size with  \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_set\_width/height/size()}}.

Another important note is that \sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LABEL\_LONG\_DOT}} manipulates the text buffer in-place} in order to add/remove the dots.
When \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_text}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_array\_text}} are used, a separate buffer is allocated and this implementation detail is unnoticed.
This is not the case with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_static\_text}}! \sphinxstylestrong{The buffer you pass to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_static\_text}} must be writable if you plan to use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LABEL\_LONG\_DOT}}.}


\subsubsection{Text align}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/label:text-align}}
The lines of the text can be aligned to the left, right or center with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_align(label, LV\_LABEL\_ALIGN\_LEFT/RIGHT/CENTER)}}. Note that, it will align only the lines, not the label object itself.

Vertical alignment is not supported by the label itself; you should place the label inside a larger container and align the whole label object instead.


\subsubsection{Text recolor}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/label:text-recolor}}
In the text, you can use commands to recolor parts of the text. For example: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"Write a \#ff0000 red\# word"}}.
This feature can be enabled individually for each label by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_label\_set\_recolor()}} function.

Note that, recoloring work only in a single line. Therefore, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textbackslash{}n}} should not use in a recolored text or it should be wrapped by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LABEL\_LONG\_BREAK}} else, the text in the new line won't be recolored.


\subsubsection{Very long texts}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/label:very-long-texts}}
Lvgl can efficiently handle very long (\textgreater{} 40k characters) by saving some extra data (\textasciitilde{}12 bytes) to speed up drawing. To enable this feature, set \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LABEL\_LONG\_TXT\_HINT   1}} in \sphinxstyleemphasis{lv\_conf.h}.


\subsubsection{Symbols}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/label:symbols}}
The labels can display symbols alongside letters (or on their own). Read the {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/font::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Font}}}} section to learn more about the symbols.


\subsection{Events}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/label:events}}
Only the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} are sent by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\subsection{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/label:keys}}
No \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.


\subsection{Example}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/label:example}}

\subsubsection{C}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/label:c}}

\label{\detokenize{widgets/label:label-recoloring-and-scrolling}}

\section{LED (lv\_led)}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/led:led-lv-led}}\label{\detokenize{widgets/led::doc}}

\subsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/led:overview}}
The LEDs are rectangle-like (or circle) object. It's brightness can be adjusted. With lower brightness the the colors of the LED become darker.


\subsection{Parts and Styles}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/led:parts-and-styles}}
The LEDs have only one main part, called \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LED\_PART\_MAIN}} and it uses all the typical background style properties.


\subsection{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/led:usage}}

\subsubsection{Brightness}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/led:brightness}}
You can set their brightness with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_led\_set\_bright(led, bright)}}. The brightness should be between 0 (darkest) and 255 (lightest).


\subsubsection{Toggle}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/led:toggle}}
Use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_led\_on(led)}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_led\_off(led)}} to set the brightness to a predefined ON or OFF value. The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_led\_toggle(led)}} toggles between the ON and OFF state.


\subsection{Events}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/led:events}}
Only the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} are sent by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\subsection{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/led:keys}}
No \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.


\subsection{Example}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/led:example}}

\subsubsection{C}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/led:c}}

\paragraph{LED with custom style}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/led:led-with-custom-style}}

\section{Line (lv\_line)}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/line:line-lv-line}}\label{\detokenize{widgets/line::doc}}

\subsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/line:overview}}
The Line object is capable of drawing straight lines between a set of points.


\subsection{Parts and Styles}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/line:parts-and-styles}}
The Line has only a main part, called \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LABEL\_PART\_MAIN}}. It uses all the \sphinxstyleemphasis{line} style properties.


\subsection{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/line:usage}}

\subsubsection{Set points}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/line:set-points}}
The points has to be stored in an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_point\_t}} array and passed to the object by the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_line\_set\_points(lines, point\_array, point\_cnt)}} function.


\subsubsection{Auto-size}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/line:auto-size}}
It is possible to automatically set the size of the line object according to its points.
It can be enable with the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_line\_set\_auto\_size(line, true)}} function.
If enabled then when the points are set the object's width and height will be changed according to the maximal x and y coordinates among the points. The \sphinxstyleemphasis{auto size} is enabled by default.


\subsubsection{Invert y}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/line:invert-y}}
By deafult, the \sphinxstyleemphasis{y == 0} point is in the top of the object. It might be conter-intuitive in some cases so the y coordinates can be inverted with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_line\_set\_y\_invert(line, true)}}. In this case,  \sphinxstyleemphasis{y == 0} will be the bottom of teh obejct.
The \sphinxstyleemphasis{y invert} is disabled by default.


\subsection{Events}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/line:events}}
Only the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} are sent by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\subsection{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/line:keys}}
No \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.


\subsection{Example}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/line:example}}

\section{List (lv\_list)}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/list:list-lv-list}}\label{\detokenize{widgets/list::doc}}

\subsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/list:overview}}
The Lists are built from a background {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/page::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Page}}}} and {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/btn::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Buttons}}}} on it.
The Buttons contain an optional icon-like {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/img::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Image}}}} (which can be a symbol too) and a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/label::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Label}}}}.
When the list becomes long enough it can be scrolled.


\subsection{Parts and Styles}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/list:parts-and-styles}}
The List has the same parts as the {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/page::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Page}}}}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LIST\_PART\_BG}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LIST\_PART\_SCRL}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LIST\_PART\_SCRLBAR}}

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LIST\_PART\_EDGE\_FLASH}}

\end{itemize}

Refer to the {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/page::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Page}}}} documentation for details.

The buttons on the list are treated as normal buttons and they only have a main part called \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BTN\_PART\_MAIN}}.


\subsection{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/list:usage}}

\subsubsection{Add buttons}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/list:add-buttons}}
You can add new list elements (button) with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_list\_add\_btn(list, \&icon\_img, "Text")}} or with symbol \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_list\_add\_btn(list, SYMBOL\_EDIT, "Edit text")}}.
If you do not want to add image use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NULL}} as image source. The function returns with a pointer to the created button to allow further configurations.

The width of the buttons is set to maximum according to the object width.
The height of the buttons are adjusted automatically according to the content. (\sphinxstyleemphasis{content height} + \sphinxstyleemphasis{padding\_top} + \sphinxstyleemphasis{padding\_bottom}).

The labels are created with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LABEL\_LONG\_SROLL\_CIRC}} long mode to automatically scroll the long labels circularly.

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_list\_get\_btn\_label(list\_btn)}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_list\_get\_btn\_img(list\_btn)}} can be used to get the label and the image of a list button.
The text can be et directly with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_list\_get\_btn\_text(list\_btn)}}.


\subsubsection{Delete buttons}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/list:delete-buttons}}
To delete a list element just use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_obj\_del(btn)}} on the return value of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_list\_add\_btn()}}.

To clean the list (remove all buttons) use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_list\_clean(list)}}


\subsubsection{Manual navigation}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/list:manual-navigation}}
You can navigate manually in the list with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_list\_up(list)}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_list\_down(list)}}.

You can focus on a button directly using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_list\_focus(btn, LV\_ANIM\_ON/OFF)}}.

The \sphinxstylestrong{animation time} of up/down/focus movements can be set via: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_list\_set\_anim\_time(list, anim\_time)}}. Zero animation time means not animations.


\subsubsection{Layout}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/list:layout}}
By default the list is vertical. To get a horizontal list use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_list\_set\_layout(list, LV\_LAYOUT\_ROW\_MID)}}.


\subsubsection{Edge flash}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/list:edge-flash}}
A circle-like effect can be shown when the list reaches the most top or bottom position.
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_list\_set\_edge\_flash(list, true)}} enables this feature.


\subsubsection{Scroll propagation}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/list:scroll-propagation}}
If the list is created on an other scrollable element (like a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/page::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Page}}}}) and the list can't be scrolled further the scrolling can be propagated to the parent.
This way the scroll will be continued on the parent. It can be enabled with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_list\_set\_scroll\_propagation(list, true)}}


\subsection{Events}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/list:events}}
Only the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} are sent by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\subsection{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/list:keys}}
The following \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the Lists:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_RIGHT/DOWN} Select the next button

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_LEFT/UP} Select the previous button

\end{itemize}

Note that, as usual, the state of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_KEY\_ENTER}} is translated to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_EVENT\_PRESSED/PRESSING/RELEASED}} etc.

The Selected buttons are in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_BTN\_STATE\_PR/TG\_PR}} state.

To manually select a button use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_list\_set\_btn\_selected(list, btn)}}. When the list is defocused and focused again it will restore the last selected button.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.

\section{Line meter (lv\_lmeter)}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/linemeter:line-meter-lv-lmeter}}\label{\detokenize{widgets/linemeter::doc}}

\subsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/linemeter:overview}}
The Line meter object consists of some radial lines which draw a scale. Setting a value for the Line meter will change the color of the scale lines proportionally.


\subsection{Parts and Styles}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/linemeter:parts-and-styles}}
The Line meter has only a main part, called \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LINEMETER\_PART\_MAIN}}. It uses all the typical background properties the draw a rectangle-like or circle background and the \sphinxstyleemphasis{line} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{scale} properties to draw the scale lines.
The active lines (which are related to smaller values the the current value) are colored from \sphinxstyleemphasis{line\_color} to \sphinxstyleemphasis{scale\_grad\_color}. The lines in the end (after the current value) are set to \sphinxstyleemphasis{scale\_end\_color} color.


\subsection{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/linemeter:usage}}

\subsubsection{Set value}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/linemeter:set-value}}
When setting a new value with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_linemeter\_set\_value(linemeter, new\_value)}} the proportional part of the scale will be recolored.


\subsubsection{Range and Angles}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/linemeter:range-and-angles}}
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_linemeter\_set\_range(linemeter, min, max)}} function sets the range of the line meter.

You can set the angle of the scale and the number of the lines by: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_linemeter\_set\_scale(linemeter, angle, line\_num)}}.
The default angle is 240 and the default line number is 31.


\subsubsection{Angle offset}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/linemeter:angle-offset}}
By default the scale angle is interpreted symmetrically to the y axis. It results in "standing" line meter. With \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_linemeter\_set\_angle\_offset}} an offset can be added the scale angle.
It can used e.g to put a quarter line meter into a corner or a half line meter to the right or left side.


\subsubsection{Mirror}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/linemeter:mirror}}
By default the Line meter's lines are activated clock-wise. It can be changed using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_linemeter\_set\_mirror(linemeter, true/false)}}.


\subsection{Events}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/linemeter:events}}
Only the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} are sent by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\subsection{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/linemeter:keys}}
No \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.


\subsection{Example}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/linemeter:example}}

\section{Message box (lv\_msdbox)}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/msgbox:message-box-lv-msdbox}}\label{\detokenize{widgets/msgbox::doc}}

\subsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/msgbox:overview}}
The Message boxes act as pop-ups.
They are built from a background {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/cont::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Container}}}}, a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/label::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Label}}}} and a {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/btnmatrix::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Button matrix}}}} for buttons.

The text will be broken into multiple lines automatically (has \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_LABEL\_LONG\_MODE\_BREAK}}) and the height will be set automatically to involve the text and the buttons (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_FIT\_TIGHT}} fit vertically)-


\subsection{Parts and Styles}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/msgbox:parts-and-styles}}
The Message box's main part is called \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_MSGBOX\_PART\_MAIN}} and it uses all the typical background style properties. Using padding will add space on the sides. \sphinxstyleemphasis{pad\_inner} will add space between the text and the buttons.
The \sphinxstyleemphasis{label} style properties affect the style of text.

The buttons parts are the same as in case of {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/btnmatrix::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Button matrix}}}}:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_MSGBOX\_PART\_BTN\_BG}} the background of the buttons

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_MSGBOX\_PART\_BTN}} the buttons

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/msgbox:usage}}

\subsubsection{Set text}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/msgbox:set-text}}
To set the text use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_msgbox\_set\_text(msgbox, "My text")}} function. Not only the pointer of the text will be saved, so the the text can be in a local variable too.


\subsubsection{Add buttons}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/msgbox:add-buttons}}
To add buttons use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_msgbox\_add\_btns(msgbox, btn\_str)}} function. The button's text needs to be specified like \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{const char * btn\_str{[}{]} = \{"Apply", "Close", ""\}}}.
For more information visit the {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/btnmatrix::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Button matrix}}}} documentation.

The button matrix will be created only when \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_msgbox\_add\_btns()}} is called for the first time.


\subsubsection{Auto-close}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/msgbox:auto-close}}
With \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_msgbox\_start\_auto\_close(mbox, delay)}} the message box can be closed automatically after \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{delay}} milliseconds with an animation. The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_mbox\_stop\_auto\_close(mbox)}} function stops a started auto close.

The duration of the close animation can be set by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_mbox\_set\_anim\_time(mbox, anim\_time)}}.


\subsection{Events}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/msgbox:events}}
Besides the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} the following \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#special-events}{Special events} are sent by the Message boxes:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_EVENT\_VALUE\_CHANGED} sent when the button is clicked. The event data is set to ID of the clicked button.

\end{itemize}

The Message box has a default event callback which closes itself when a button is clicked.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.

\#\#Keys

The following \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the Buttons:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_RIGHT/DOWN} Select the next button

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_LEFT/TOP} Select the previous button

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{LV\_KEY\_ENTER} Clicks the selected button

\end{itemize}

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.

\section{Object mask (lv\_objmask)}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/objmask:object-mask-lv-objmask}}\label{\detokenize{widgets/objmask::doc}}

\subsection{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/objmask:overview}}
The \sphinxstyleemphasis{Object mask} is capable of add some mask to drawings when its children is drawn.


\subsection{Parts and Styles}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/objmask:parts-and-styles}}
The Object mask has only a main part called \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LV\_OBJMASK\_PART\_BG}} and it uses the typical background style properties.


\subsection{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/objmask:usage}}

\subsubsection{Adding mask}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/objmask:adding-mask}}
Before adding a mask to the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Object mask} the mask should be initialized:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}draw\PYGZus{}mask\PYGZus{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{type}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{\PYGZus{}param\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{mask\PYGZus{}param}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}draw\PYGZus{}mask\PYGZus{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{type}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{n}{\PYGZus{}init}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{mask\PYGZus{}param}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}objmask\PYGZus{}mask\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{mask\PYGZus{}p} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}objmask\PYGZus{}add\PYGZus{}mask}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{objmask}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{mask\PYGZus{}param}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Lvgl supports the following mask types:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{line} clip the pixels on the top/bottom left/right of a line. Can be initialized from two points or a point and an angle:

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{angle} keep the pixels only between a given start and end angle

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{radius} keep the pixel only inside a rectangle which can have radius (can for a circle too). Can be inverted to keep the pixel outside of the rectangle.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{fade} fade vertically (change the pixels opacity according to their y position)

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{map} use an alpha mask (a byte array) to describe the pixels opacity.

\end{itemize}

The coordinates in the mask are relative to the Object. That is if the object moves the masks move with it.

For the details of the mask \sphinxstyleemphasis{init} function see the {\hyperref[\detokenize{widgets/objmask:api}]{\emph{API}}} documentation below.


\subsubsection{Update mask}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/objmask:update-mask}}
AN existing mask can be updated with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_objmask\_update\_mask(objmask, mask\_p, new\_param)}}, where \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mask\_p}} is return value of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_objmask\_add\_mask}}.


\subsubsection{Remove mask}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/objmask:remove-mask}}
A mask can be removed with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{lv\_objmask\_remove\_mask(objmask, mask\_p)}}


\subsection{Events}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/objmask:events}}
Only the \sphinxhref{/overview/event.html\#generic-events}{Generic events} are sent by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/event::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Events}}}}.


\subsection{Keys}
\label{\detokenize{widgets/objmask:keys}}
No \sphinxstyleemphasis{Keys} are processed by the object type.

Learn more about {\hyperref[\detokenize{overview/indev::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc,doc,doc}{Keys}}}}.

\paragraph{Text mask}

code

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}

    \PYG{c+cm}{/* Create the mask of a text by drawing it to a canvas*/}

    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}canvas\PYGZus{}fill\PYGZus{}bg}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{canvas}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}COLOR\PYGZus{}BLACK}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}OPA\PYGZus{}TRANSP}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

    \PYG{c+cm}{/*Draw a label to the canvas. The result \PYGZdq{}image\PYGZdq{} will be used as mask*/}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}draw\PYGZus{}label\PYGZus{}dsc\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{n}{label\PYGZus{}dsc}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}draw\PYGZus{}label\PYGZus{}dsc\PYGZus{}init}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{label\PYGZus{}dsc}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{label\PYGZus{}dsc}\PYG{p}{.}\PYG{n}{color} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}COLOR\PYGZus{}WHITE}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}canvas\PYGZus{}draw\PYGZus{}text}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{canvas}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{MASK\PYGZus{}WIDTH}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n}{label\PYGZus{}dsc}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Text with gradient}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{LV\PYGZus{}LABEL\PYGZus{}ALIGN\PYGZus{}CENTER}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

    \PYG{c+cm}{/*The mask is reads the canvas is not required anymore*/}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}del}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{canvas}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}

    \PYG{c+cm}{/*Create an object mask which will use the created mask*/}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}t} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{om} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}objmask\PYGZus{}create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}scr\PYGZus{}act}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{NULL}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
    \PYG{n}{lv\PYGZus{}obj\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}size}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{om}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{MASK\PYGZus{}WIDTH}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{MASK\PYGZus{}HEIGHT}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
